text.wiki:
Quattro Canti, officially known as Piazza Vigliena, is a Baroque square in Palermo, Sicily, Southern Italy.
It was laid out on the orders of the Viceroys between 1608-1620 by Giulio Lasso and Mariano Smiriglio at the crossing of the two principal streets in Palermo, the Via Maqueda and the Corso Vittorio Emanuele.
The piazza is octagonal, four sides being the streets; the remaining four sides are Baroque buildings, the near-identical facades of which contain fountains with statues of the four seasons, the four Spanish kings of Sicily, and of the patronesses of Palermo, (Christina, Ninfa, Olivia and Agata). The facades onto the interchange are curved, and  rise to four floors; the fountains rise to the height of the second floor, the third and fourth floors contain the statues in niches. At the time the piazza was built, it was one of the first major examples of town planning in Europe.


== Gallery ==

		
		
		
		
		
		
		
		
		
		


== Notes ==
text.quote: Baroque, octagonal square with 4 fountains topped by statues in niches that are spotlit at night.
trip:
Overview The traditional center of Palermo called "Quattro Canti" (Four Corners) is located at the intersection of Corso Vittorio Emanuele and Via Maqueda, making it the heart of this city's old historic district. Suggested Duration:< 1 hour Address:
Corso Vittorio Emanuelle Via Maqueda, 90100, Palermo, Sicily ItalyMap

At the intersection of two of the most prominent streets in Palermo, Via Maqueda & Via Vittorio Emanuele is the location of the 4 corners square. This amazing square is known as Villena Square in honor of…

It is all about four baroque facades, displaying four Spanish viceroys of Sicily, four (out of five) protective saints of Palermo, four female statues symbolizing the seasons and four fountains. The crossroad between Maqueda and Vittorio Emanuelle boulevards is the meeting point

We came during the year end festive period and the areas around Quattro Canti were especially atmospheric, with Christmas light up, street busking and lots of activities. I personally think this is one of the most iconic piazzas in Sicily. The concept of the four facades

This took our breath away. A road junction - intersection where four roads meet hence the word Quattro. Everyone who arrives here has to stop and take a photo. The architecture on these facades is quite stunning and quite a selfie spot
Just walking along the Via Maqueda is a great experience but this junction has some lovely architecture and is well worth a visit. Lots of bars and cafes nearby.

Quattro Canti, officially known as Piazza Vigliena, is a Baroque square in Palermo, Sicily, Southern Italy. It was laid out on the orders of the Viceroys between 1608-1620 by Giulio Lasso and Mariano Smiriglio at the crossing of the two principal streets in Palermo, the Via

Previously, the center of Palermo was located where the Cathedral stands. However, the Quattro Canti composition is ideal for performing the role of the center. The idea of a symmetrical arrangement of buildings at an intersection is not new. There is something similar in Rome

This is an easily identifiable, and striking grand intersection in the heart of Palermo. It has richly decorated curved facades of buildings, with fountains, facing the intersection. It is an important crossroads int he heart of the city and can be a useful point for meeting

A great focal point in Palermo. All 4 streets meeting at the 4 corners are bustling and energetic areas,filled with all kinds of shops,for locals and tourists. The corners are also a great spot to enjoy local musicians,who seem to appear there everyday. Just up the road is the

Impressive and detailed center that definitely warrants a stop. Very reminiscent of the Quattro Fontane in Rome. We only saw the Quattro Canto at night due to our schedule but it was still lovely to see.

The intersection of of two roads in the centre of the old city, this is hard to miss. Four buildings, each with a facade on the corner of the four quarters of the city each of which in turn depicts a saint, a season, a king and a patron. The facades are curved and each has a

Lovely to look , with live music in the evening . All four corners are different :4 saints, 4 seasons , 4 kings , 4 districts , 4 rivers ... It's impossible not to get to Quattro Canti - but first read about the symbols you'll see!
Difficult not visit this given its central location! Well worth a short stop to give it a proper viewing
Very nice intersection. The four corners are basically sculptured facades, artwork at its best, to be contemplated and admired.
This spot gives you a real feel for Palermo and Sicily's history. If you are not on a tour, look up the significance in an online guide, or your guidebook. It is truly stunning in person.

Each corner is a variation on the same themes: 4 baroque palaces, 4 fountains, 4 seasons, 4 Spanish Kings, 4 female patron saints of the city. As an early example of town planning, Quattro Canti can be compared to Place Vosges in Paris (originally Place Royale). Place Royale
The map provided is not the four corners. It's the vegetable market. If you follow other reviews those are correct where the location of the four corners is.
Standing in the middle of the cross roads, you can't help but look at the four corners, the architecture and beautiful corners. Looking down the streets you see the mountains. Beautiful

It's simple enouth, reminiscent of one in Rome. A fountain on each corner represents a season. There's a real bustle and it's the last respite before the busy almost pedestrian road beyond. The sculptures are excellent.

The Quattro Canti is a pedestrian area dating back to 1600 where the two main streets of Palermo, Via Maqueda, and the Corso Vittorio Emanuele intersect. The curved facades of the buildings, each representing a season, and the statues of Spanish kings and patron saints A good
An interesting cross road in the city, now pedestrianised. Look at the monuments, listen to buskers or just watch the world go by. It is on the route to many places.

These are beautiful crossroads with elaborate sculptures at the four corners. Each has different themes and fountains. They stretch up at least three storeys high and create an historic and compelling meeting point . It’s always busy here with lots of guided tours having talks

I was disappointed with the centro. I always thought Palermo would look like a faded opera set. There's a great buzz and some unusual street food experiences but it lacks the harmony of South East Sicily.

This is the heart of Palermo and it is busiest intersection in town our apartment was only a couple blocks away near Plaza Marina so we were able to visit on several occasions. I think they should light up the statue’s at night but it is still a beautiful site,

For the center of the city it could be in better shape. Cars and people vie for the streets. Central location, you are 10 blocks in the four directions from there to the Teatro Massimo, Cattedrale, Train/bus station and the Cala. GREAT places to dine from here up to the

We only had 1.5 days in Palermo and I hadn't really read up on the city's sights. We stumbled across this by chance on our first walk around the city. It's very cool to see the four individual corners at this intersection. be careful not to get run over by cars when you're

In many ways, you do not visit Quattro Canti but you pass through it; being the intersection of two very central and busy streets leading to the Cathedral and Norman Palace when coming from either the Teatro Massimo or from the opposite end, which is the Stazione Centrale. In
The Four corners are actually four houses covered with beautiful different statues. the place is very impressive

We stayed at a place very close to this spot for several days so we walked by it quite a bit. The statues are pretty cool but I was glad I didn't have to make a special trip just to see it. I noticed that this area along with the pedestrian street by it were fine during the day.

We found the Quattro Canti crossroads during a one day stopover in Palermo as our ship was docked in the port here. We had opted to explore the city on foot and had prepared our own agenda with points of interest to visit. We walked here from the port on a weekday morning,

Beginning at the Four Corners give the opportunity to explore a wonderful pedestrian area in Palermo. Art in the streets, art on the buildings, even art in the treats offered in the shops. This area really gives visitors a taste of all parts of Palermo.

Typical Baroque example of xxvii century architecture. Spend time to observe 4 seasons, 4 Spanish kings of Sicilia and 4 patronesses of Palermo. There is also Bisso Bistrot, the place for lunch or dinner, highly recommended

The Quattro Canti is right in the center of a pedestrian walkway at the intersection of Via Maqueda and Corso Vittorio Emmanuele. The four corners represent the 4 seasons of the year. This area dates back to 1600. Each corner is done in a Baroque fashion and has a concave facade
You can't visit Palermo without seeing Quattero Conti. It's ana amazing site and is right in the center of the many pedestrian walkway with street vendors, singers, great food, etc.
Gorgeous square with the Quattro Canti that are just perfect Baroque architecture. In the city centre on your way to the cathedral

I expected a large regal intersection for the main roads of old Palermo.But No - what we got & we passed it daily was a small but perfectly formed intersection with some nice statues. It was not a show stopper but pleasant.

This Baroque square, at the intersection of the the principal streets Via Maqueda and the Corso Vittorio Emanuele, is dedicated to four Spanish kings. Representing an early example of town planning, passersby can use the way the sun hits statues of the seasons to roughly tell
Like so many of the ‘sights’ in Palermo this one casually sneaks up on you. Fascinating architecture and also a great place for people watching.
The Heart of the city of Palermo Is surely the historical zone of "I Quattro Canti", from this side you can reach the theaters, the Cathedral and Piazza della Vergogna.

At the juncture of Corso Vittorio Emanuelle and Via Maqueda this corner is unique in the architecture of the four buildings that mark this intersection.. A great many sights to see nearby but don't miss the opportunity to just stop here for a moment and brouse.

These crossroads mark the division of the four main regions of Palermo and are noted for many statues. Its main interest now tho' is as the beginning of the popular pedestrioanised street Via Maqueda, with its bars, restaurants and street food and lots of milling people.

The Quattro Canti is a pedestrian area where the two main streets of Palermo intersect. Those interested in architecture will appreciate the curved facades of the buildings, each representing a season, and the statues of Spanish kings and patron saints. If you chose a hotel

A very remarkable intersection of two main streets, Via Maqueda, and the Corso Vittorio Emanuele. The buildings have a baroque architecture with a partial c-curved side facing the intersection and built-in statues and fountains. The statues include four Spanish kings of Sicily,
Walk up Via Maqueda, and stop at the Quattro Canti. Interesting architecture, great place to people watch, generally some music being played somewhere. Spend a few minutes here, it's worth it.
The very small 'square' represents the four seasons of a year. Very cute and artistical buildings. It is few steps away from Piazza Pretoria so it is impossible to miss or skip the place. Must see!

The main crossroads in the pedestrianised area of Old Palermo, this is a very grand crossroads where Via Maqueda and Corso Vittorio Emanuele intersect and the town is divided into four quarters dating back to 1600. The buildings in each of the four corners has a concave facade
Four identical buildings on each side of a crossroads of the city. Beautiful carvings and statues on fronts.
I loved just walking up and down this area. I also loved sitting with a gelato and just people watching. It is pedestrian only and lined with many shops. I walked here every day while in Palermo
On the way to or from the Teatro Massimo, the Catedrale and the Palazzo dei Normani. A real must see
The 4 streets that intersect here in the historic center are close to many shops, restaurants, and historic buildings. Study the niches and the architecture: interesting stories.

These beautiful corners of Baroque-Spanish are the facades of the 4 buildings around the Piazza. Each facade has 3 levels with 3 statues representing the seasons, kings and Santas Patronas of Sicily. For example, the eastern façade has Winter on the first level, the second on
WE went by this area a few times . It is in the historic area in the central part of Palermo. So much to see in this area. Statues on each corner.

If you visit Palermo, you must go to the Quattro Canti piazza to see the four season statues. They represent the four Spanish kings of Sicily. Enjoy the view of beautiful facades and take lots of pictures...
Beautiful side of Palermo, right in the centre of the city. If you visit you will walk by this place many times.

Not that much to say other than this feels like the true centre of Palermo. The real bustle is in Via Maqueda (not sure about the spelling) plenty of bars and restaurants all around. Nice carvings not sure if teh sun shines all day.
It really is quite a surprise to see this place/junction. I have not seen anything like it- beautiful & great planning.

Tall, impressive, beautiful buildings on each corner of a busy crossroad in central Palermo. The intersection is smaller than you imagine but still makes an impact. Worth stopping for a few photos and to admire the facades.

At the junction of the main road, usually very busy area. Fantastic sculptures, apparently one is always in the sunshine! Sometimes a local group will be performing on one of the corners. On a visit to Palermo you can’t miss it.

This four corner intersection is the epicenter of historic Palermo. A walk to each of the four corners and a glance at your guidebook will cover it nicely. It’s a great point of reference for a walking tour and a superior rendezvous spot. As a tourist site, it’s a ten minute
Very interesting historical monuments and the crossroads to some of Palermo's attractions. Visit Teatro Massimo and go to the opera if you can get tickets or the Oratorio of San Lorenzo.
Quite an historical building in 4 splits. Nearby are very interesting sires too. Just a few minutes walking distance to Teatro Massimo and virtually links moat major parts of Sicily by foot
The work that's gone into theses four corners the statues on a ledges all detailed to perfection on each corner
This is the intersection of two major roads forming an octagonal plaza with four ornate buildings each with three levels of sculptures - 4 Kings, 4 Saints, and 4 Seasons.
four quarters - like the rest of Palermo look up - early evenings and afternoons there is live music
We just happened upon this on our way back to our hotel . It is absolutely gorgeous. Dating back to the 1600’s it stands at the intersection of two very prominent streets.
It is very unusual to see the four corners of the intersection so ornate bd sculptured. Never seen anything like this before.

Walked through this after Pretoria fountain on our way to Palamos cathedral. It is located on an intersection (hence the 4 corners). The architecture of the buildings is very grand and there is a little fountain. Worth walking this way to or from wherever you may be going –
A real landmark and an architectural gem symbolising the four parts of the city and the four rivers. How many times did we walk past? Admired it each time.
Statues, fountains, carvings at the intersection of 4 streets in historic Palermo. Very impressive street art, worth a look.
A must see when in Palermo. The 4 corners represent a unique insight into the history of Palermo. Located a short walk down the main Street enabled us to enjoy both shopping and sight seeing.
Central to Palermo, the Quattro Canti is lovely to see and an ideal place to meet....everybody can point you in the right direction. Architecturally stunning, well worth a picture or two!

The grandeur of these buildings is blighted by the endless fridge magnet sellers and the "traditional" band which seems to be there at all hours of the day and night. Try to block out the noise, and just look at the buildings.

Where all city explorations should begin and end. We first saw it ourselves and later with a local who explained the meaning of the various sculptures at each corner. So much to see, do and eat around each corner

This octogonal square (is it really possible?) has 4 sides being the streets and 4 sides being buildings built and designed by Guilio Lasso in 1608-1660. The 4 Baroque buildings contain 4 fountains, 4 statues of 4 seasons, 4 Spanish kings of Sicily and 4 patronesses of Palermo:

One of the many attractions the ancient city of Palermo has to offer. Placed on a most popular street in town, Quattro Quanti is the most spectacular crossroad I have ever witnessed. Not to be missed!

The square dates to 1609 when it was commissioned by the Spanish Viceroy in Sicily, Marquis de Juan Fernández Pacheco de Villena y Ascalon. (The name just rolls off the tongue). It is located at the intersection of Via Maqueda and Via Vittorio Emanuele, two of the most

You will surely pass this a bunch of times during your stay in Palermo. It's a much grander version of the four corner fountains in Rome. It's layered and very lively. Right around the corner from the fountain at Piazza Pretoria and the San Cataldo church and Piazza Bellini.
On your way to the Fountain of Shame, you will walk by the Quattro Canti, showcasing various historical figures in the history of Palermo.
All four corners are different. Such style, such grace, take time to closely examine all the sculptures, but beware of the traffic

If you like architecture and symmetry this is a must visit. Located in the old city of Palermo, it is almost like Palermo's version of Time Square. It is a small square surrounded by four similar buildings at each of the four corners. It is in the middle of a lot of souvenir
This an interesting square which you can’t miss on the way to the Palermo Cathedral. It is good to visit toward the afternoon which has less traffic which makes it easier for photo shots.

At the junction of Via Vittorio Emmanuele and Via Maqueda, the four corners provide one of the earliest examples of coordinated town planning (something we have lost today). The curving baroque facades were created im between 1608 and 1620 by Guilio Lasso with fountains

The famous Quattro Canti is one of those squares/intersections that is unlike anywhere else in the world..It's like the "Times Square" of Palermo. It's in the heart of the historic district of the city. Fortunately we had a guide to explain the meaning behind these 17th century
Interesting square with its unusual old buildings. You will encounter this when walking around the old town. Palermo’s old city is easy to walk and the sites are amazing. Make sure u have a map

Created to bisect the already important Corso VittorioEmanuelle, the glorious 4 Seasons facades of the (sadly) vacant buildings behind each corner are in reasonable condition..just a little grubby, that's all. One might only hope for some smart developer to take hold of this

Quattro Canti is at the center of the "Old City". One book described this intersection as "a fusion of architecture and sculpture". It is very awe inspiring to see the depth of Palermo's ancient homage to the four seasons, four Spanish rulers, and four angels, layered ever
This is the heart of Palermo: four almost identical building framing a little square and representing the history of the city, highly symbolic and dear to the heart of its citizens.

For whatever reason I wanted photos of all four corners of this interestingg "canti" or intersection. Need to exercise some caution as a main street flows through the middle. However, the Photos are splendid.
This is one of the things to see in Palermo, a beautiful intersection between 2 important streets , Vittorio Emanuele and via Marqueda.
It's a crossing of two main roads , on four parts of the cross, there is a statue each. It's beautiful and you may Take more looks when passing by .
Very spectacular four corners of four streets . Check the details of the sculptures. A real pleasure to discover Palermo.

We loved Palermo. Wide streets and foot paths, amazing monumental buildings and few hawkers - some beggars but compared to other towns not in your face. Roaming dogs old and young were extremely well behaved and well cared for my the locals. Saw one very old dog go to a tap -
So funny but we were just walking down the street and came across this magnificent intersection and we were floored. Tough trying to cross the street here!
A crazy little ‘square’, worthwhile experiencing by just standing on a corner and let the Sicilian world pass by. The mirror images of the statues is quite eerie.
Oh, what a beautiful city Palermo is! Quattro Canti is part of that charm: roads that create this lovely "four quarters" with lots of amazing details and interesting buildings around. A must!
beautiful 'square' with four sets of statues and fountains - honestly a crossroads, so mind the cars, crossing the streets is quite dangerous in this city...
The place is extremely beautiful, hard to see everything at once, lots of details. Very much recommended!
Can't really miss this location in Palermo, where the two old main roads intercept creating 'four quarters'. Some great buildings at this point and a beautiful fountain.

Via Maqueda, you'll find the Quattro Canti, an crossroads that has in the four corners of the buildings a beautiful carved walls... Also known as theatre of the Sun. I made this video to be able to represent the beauty of this place.
It is the famous city symbol of Palermo. You should go morning and afternoon to take all 4 builging with sunshine.

Even standalone quattro canti is very nice, with it's historic looking 4 corner buildings and lots of bustling shops and eateries to go to. What made it more special was us going right when there was a gelato festival with so many flavors of ice cream to have.

This is the 4 corners in the center of the tourist area, the best way to view it is to try to stand in the middle of the street and just turn around to see all the corners from that view. We saw people stopping in their cars to bless themselves, as they passed by.

My husband’s grandmother always said she lived in the center of the city. She did a few blocks away from here ! This is now a beautiful location to visit since it is mostly a pedestrIan walk way and near many sites. It also looks good from the last time we were in Palermo, 25
Interesting 'square' with four sets of statues and fountains - actually a crossroads, so watch out for traffic that d o especially not respect pedestrians.

Quattro Canti is an open square located in the centre of Palermo, constructed in 1608. The square provides a crossroads for Via Maqueda and VIa Vittorio Emannuel but it is the architecture that makes it famous. At each corner of the square lies a semi circular face that
I have come here at least 10 times and keep coming the experience is absolutely marvelous, you will not be disappointed, to feel the place and the history is truly breathtaking..

This was on our must see list when we visited Palermo. Quattro Canti is also known as Piazza Vigliena. It is a Baroque style square right in the main part of the city and was built in 1608. Located at the crossing of the two principal streets in Palermo, the Via Maqueda and the

Didn't know what to expect when we read about Quattro Canti in the guidebook but when we walked there, it was a beauty, four corners decorated with it own theme and special statue. It was fortunate that traffic is detoured away from this square because lot of tourist just are
Actually this is very hard to miss as it is the centre of the city. It has a very interesting history.

Officially known as Piazza Vigliena, this Baroque square was laid out on the Viceroys’ orders in the early 1600s, by Giulio Lasso. It’s at the crossing of two principal streets: Via Maqueda dn Corso Vittorio Emanuel. (Significant as NY's Times Square.) An octagonal design, the

Walking down the Corso Vittorio Emmanuel from the cathedral you will happen on a crossroads where the 4 corners are three levels of sculptures set in niches within the buildings. On the top level there are the patron saints of Palermo, then the 4 Spanish kings who ruled in the
I Love the stories of the Quattro Canti from the spanish kings, peculiar saints and the four seasons remarkable architecture and stories

This is a smaller version of the four fountains in Rome. Each corner has a statue dedicated to the seasons, the lower level has statues dedicated to something else. Just walking about you should just come across this crossroads as it's so central, not worth going out of your

What's better than seeing something unique, entertaining, thought provoking, and free? Chances you will be at or near this spot at some point, so spend a few minutes and drink it all in. Yes, it's shabby and needs to be restored (particularly the interiors of the buildings upon

I stumbled across this square while I was walking around Sicily. Absolutely lovely, you have to see the four corners. Each statue is different and the longer you look the more you see. This is a must see, and it doesn't cost a cent.
This baroque carrefour would probably be beautiful if restaured. However, the building are quite dark and unattractive
It is the center of Vittorio Emanuelle street, the main street of Palermo from Porta Felice to Porta Nuova. Going southward, from here there is the most picturesque part of the street

Just walk down the street and they are there in their natural beauty. Representing the 4 seasons, these beautiful statues each with their own fountain surround you. Up the street is the cathedral and the Palace. All should be seem when visiting Palermo.
Its impossible not to pass by Quattro Canti. :D Visit any time of the day. No payment needed. Intersection roads are closed.

OK, two of Palermo's oldest streets meet here and there are four corners each with a different season depicted in statues etc. You will stand where many conquerers stood, and walk down the street and choose which tourist stuff you will buy or eat. Its a must see.
Very attractive place for tourists, very noisy, has street musicians, its the place where the city streets meet. Has balconies with nice views.
Beautiful Baroque square on Maqueda street representing the four seasons. Nice area for a walk and to taste street food.

This square block of roads has a lot of history to it. Two great walking streets come to this intersection. All you do is walk around listen to the street music have lunch or dinner on the street corners and do a lot of shopping. The fountains they are very very old and there's

Also, I found out by the proud locals who love this spot, there is always a corner where the sun is shining. The Four Seasons, represented by fountains and beautiful statues, is a wonderful spot to visit. Close to other attractions, you should see this while in Palermo.
We came across this walking about the town in the intersection of two main roads. The sculptures are very beautiful and well worth a visit.
This was originally the main square in the old town. The architecture and statues tell the history of who governed during that era. Really impressive buildings at each of the 4 corners.
Yes, there are statues at each of the four corners on this busy intersection. The main road extends from the city gate to the beach, and it's 5 k long.
This is the center of the old town. It is well maintained, and vibrant. The walls are in great shape and define the area.

This is a happening place! Three pedestrian walkways converge here. Good people watching. Enjoyed seeing the four sculptures. Walking along Via Emmanuel you can buy almost any kind of tourist material and souvenir available.

Walking down this bustling street Vittorio Emanuele, one can not help but got excited when encounter the Four Corners. Impressive! Intriguing detailed art work. Just two minutes from Piazza Pretoria, in the heart of the old town centre. Incredible!
We knew about it - but it still surprised us by its beauty. Located at the corner of the two weeks-end pie tonal streets of Palermo it is a must see in Sicily.
The four corners are situated mid-way in the mainstreet and it's worth buying an excellent Italian ice cream and wandering around to look up at the statues - but watch out for the busy roads
When walking down the street, one but can't help pausing at this corner and taking in all four of the quadrants. Really beautiful.

Dont miss this impressive attraction in Palermo, we were a group on a guided tour of the city and had a stop while our guide told us the history of these super buildings. Nice place to stop on a rippling hot day, as although the sun is always shining on one of the four
"Quattro Canti" is one of icons of the city, for me the most beautiful. You can visit during the day or night because it's awesome. In the heart of the historic center near the Catedral.

Last time we came to Palermo we passed by this site on our coach and could only view it through the windows. Now it is in a mostly pedestrian area we were able to take time to view the Four Seasons, their Spanish kings & the guardian angels. I was even able to photograph them

This junction was surprisingly unbusy which meant that it was easy to stand and view the statues and the four corners several times a day as I stayed nearby. The sun clinging on the water features is wonderful. Loved the symetry too.
Admire the 4 corners of this square. Admire the balconies and the design. Spend a couple of minutes looking at details.
Visit the Quattro Canti by foot to be able to view the statues in the four corners long enough. Especially when the sun lights the statues they are nice to see.

This was located 50 yeards from our apartment. There are 4 corners all with water features and spectacular buildings. This is a must for all travellers to see. It is very crouded and on a main road, but there is no traffic after 10.00am in the morning as it is pedestrians only.

Great idea and unique set of buildings, composed of four buildings facing each other, each representing different period of the year: spring, summer, autumn and winter. Each building has its original set of symbols, depending of what period of year represents. Great architecture
For many this is the centre if Palermo. Graffiti, dodgy vendors and smell of urine nearby. This is a shame. Palermo should be an open museum, how can this be allowed?
A great intersection to orient your away about old Palermo Four corners leading to four neighbourhoods.
Tried to get in to see it but Dolce Gabbana had the entire city under lockdown due to some fancy affair they were having. We were able to peek down some streets and I bet it would've been great.
Be sure to look up when you're walking down the main street and pass this corner -- which you can't miss. Early example of European town planning.
Had see about the. Square on TV interesting, lovely achitecture. Be careful of the beger, woman saying lot her bus ticket only needs 2€ saw her 2 days on the trot working the tourists .

While walking around the city, I suddenly passed by an open space where everybody was looking up in the air - so I turned my head and did the same. And what a fascinating sight! At first I only noticed the one building straight ahead of me, but then I saw there are four of them,

We weren't specifically looking for this place of interest in Palermo but happened upon it, as it is located on a main cross roads in the centre of the old town. Spectacular site of four separate fountain structures on main roads. Very impressive.

This is a major intersection in Palermo of Via Maqueda and Corso Vittorio Emaqnuele. It is very interesting and historical. The building on the 4 corners make an octagonal piazza, the strees themselves being 4 sides and the Baroque buildings (with almost identical facades)
A beautiful touch to the old street of Vittorio Emanuele, lively, many tourists. Anyway, I can't give it five stars, the fountains are dirty and full of trash which is a shame.
A wonderful sight to see the four corner buildings and statues. Even the street lights are beautiful.
In this street corner there are four buildings looking the same, but they are not. They all have different figures and lovely details. It is one of the best sights in Palermo, worth visiting.

There is a wealth of detail in the elliptical facades that form the four corners of the crossroad on the v Vittorio Emmanuele. The work is a very high standard. If you're walking round Palermo, all you need to do is find it on the map; you are bound to go through it. It's worth

At the intersection of 2 of Palermo's busiest streets - Corso Vittorio Emanuele and Via Maqueda, this impressive square divides Palermo into 4 parts and the very impressive corner buildings which are rounded to make a more harmonious effect. Each corner facade is decorated with
the circular concept of the piazza is intersting, especially in the design of the 4 corner buildings fronts - providing the circle.
Excellent example of early Baroque town planning. Major crossroads in the old town, featuring four Spanish kings and fountains.

This is the “heart” of Palermo's old historic district. On each of four facades the sculptures and other details are nicely carved. From this location one could have pleasant/not so long walk along the Vittorio Emmanuele street towards the Palermo Cathedral and/or the Maqueda

Although many just call it the Four Corners, its official title is Piazza Vigliena. The Piazza Vigliena is an octagonal Baroque square at a crossroad that includes two of the most important intersecting roads in Palermo, Via Maqueda and Via Vittorio Emanuele. There is a great
The most beautiful junction in Palermo. yes by far. It's partly pedesrtian area so you have chance to get some great pictures. Try to go in late afternoon for the best light!.
If in Palermo for a few days you should come across this thoroughfare. It is not to be missed as it is pretty unique.
Quite an extraordinary crossroads in the middle of Palermo. Quite astounding given its location. A must visit place in this wonderful city

From Palermo Cruise Terminal it takes about 15 minutes walk to reach Quattro Canti. Very close are Piazza Pretoria and Martorana Church. Quattro Canti is officially known as Piazza Vigliena which is a Baroque square and had been constructed by Giulio Lasso between 1608 and 1620.

The Quattro Canti is a square in the centre of the city and one of the nicest street intersections which you can find. The four corner buildings are decorated with fountains and statues representing different seasons and patron saints of Palermo. Furthermore they show four

Four faces of houses, four streets meeting in this one intersection, a place not to be missed when sightseeing in Palermo. It's got its own unique atmosphere, people walk around and take pictures. Do so too and then decide which of the streets you'll take.
Beginning to get quite crowded in May, with tourists in huge troupes loping through the square. A must for orienting yourself in the city. Very close to many great churches, statues & monuments.
Don't miss this interesting architectural crossroad at Via Vittorio and Via Maqueda : A photographic gem .
Quattro Canti is building with Interesting Architectural . You can not miss it since it is centrali located.

An architectural feast this crossing is as special as one can be with facing multilevel columns and statues that give the place a special atmosphere and gather quite an audience of admirers all the time
Located on a main crossroads you take your life in your hands to get a good view of each of the four corners - each one part of former palaces. Impressive but a bit grubby.

Walking through a pedestrians-only part of the Corso Vittorio Emanuelle (where you can meet cars.... ) you surely will see the four beautiful buildings ornated with statues. A unique sight: statues dressed as roman emperors with the faces of 16th century monarchs. Nice.
You walk by these between via Roma and the Cathedral. It is really nice to take a few minutes to stop and have a look around the four corners.

Quattro Canti is a beautiful sight. As you walk down Vittorio Emanuele and take in so many of Pelermo's sights take a few minutes to stop at this crossing and appreciate the stunning architecture. Tip: Try and allocate 3-4 hours to walk along Vittorio Emanuele. You can start by

This is a crossroads in the middle of the old historic part of town with important statues and carvings. If you did not know you might miss it as it is a busy junction so you will be trying to dodge the traffic. If the area were properly cordoned off and pedestrianised it could

Quattro Canti or the Four Corners is a local landmark and a good place to take pictures. The buildings on each corner are very beautiful and ornate. The first level of each building represent the seasons, the second level are saints, and the third level are kings. The

Even though I am not an art or architecture appreciator, I will admit that these artistic building fronts at all four corners of this intersection ARE interesting. If you happen to be passing by this intersection, then it most certainly is worth taking a look at and taking some
The architecture is very harmonious and one is in the middle of the city here with good shopping walks in all directions. Good photo op.
Beautiful corners. It's incredible and a must to see in Palermo. This would be my top thing to see in Palermo.
On Vitt. Emanuel, a major street in the historical area. The architecture and statues of the concave building at the intersection were interesting and worth taking a few photos.

If you are meandering around Palermo, you can't help but see this intersection and go Wow! The four corners are centrally located from many must see sites, so you will probably walk through this spot several times if you are in Palermo for more than a few hours.
Ancient part of the city. I walked where my grandparents walked and I'm sure they too saw this ancient site. Breathtaking and a definite must see
An incredible crossroads with imposing buildings, sculptures, and fountains. This is Europe at its very best.
A mix of decadence and grandiosity. A beautiful central place in historical Palermo that is worth the visit and some photos.
You could spend hours or days here examining the handiwork on these 4 corners. Absolutely beautiful and amazing. Wonderful that this has been preserved
Quatro Canti or Four corners is a beatutiful baroque square with four buildings with quite similiar facade, fountains and statues of the four seasons in niches. Must to see!
So it's just a cross roads but what brilliant buildings. Each corner has statues on 2 floors and drinking fountains. Shame about the traffic

We stayed on the Via Maqueda near the Quattro Canti, so passed through this small intersection a number of times. Each time we noticed something different on each of the four facades on the four quarters of this small piazza. The people watching and street music is also fun. No

I drove passed this beauty many times, but this time we took the hop on hop off bus tour of Palermo, this was one stop we enjoyed. The four corners are beautiful, very detailed and historical, there's so much beauty in Palermo it's incredible. We walked all around and discovered
It can get quite busy with traffic at this corner for picture taking so be careful. Unusual site for statues.

This is a famous cross and good point of reference. There are 4 symmetrical new baroque buildings framing a little round square. Quite interesting, but the building could benefit of some cleaning. There is a tremendous amount of traffic so that it is difficult to look properly

The Quattro Canti is a stunning piece of architecture, you need to look very carefully at each corner to appreciate the details in the statues and fountains. It makes a great starting place to wander along the various streets to discover piazzas, churches, palaces etc.
It is a beautiful landmark to get my bearings in Palermo.. Impressive 4 corners that is mesmerizing.
This is a nice point of Via Vittorio Emanuele in Palermo. The four corners are monuments, beautiful ones, and imponents. Lots of shops and small restaurants nearby.

This 4 corners are mentioned in all the guidebooks and after seing this nobody has doubts it is a really place MUST-SEE. Place where the 2 main streets cross each other, where 4 corner buildings are ornate with sculptural groups of kings and saints is one of the most charming
Part of the old city of Palermo, a must see. The four corners of this intersection are amazing, representing the 4 seasons. Take a horse and buggy ride, and have them stop here.
You will find this at the intersection and what an intersection it is! Just look up and turn to the four corners and you will see the amazing sculptures! We loved it.
The baroque architecture at this crossroads of Palermo is stunning. Its scale is surprisingly small, and a pedestrian is overwhelmed by the beauty, not the size.

This intersection is the center of old Palermo and the neighborhoods of twisted streets radiate off of it. Nice pedestrianized strolling available and the Fontana della Vergogna is close by.
This is the historic center of Palermo and good for getting your bearings. The statues summarize Palermo history and always good for getting oriented.

The street itself leading to this picturesque corner has a lot to offer. The corner is very unique, while attracting lots of tourists in addition to traffic and chaotic mindset. Made us feel a bit flustered, but we managed to grab some great shots!
This is the most beautiful corner of old architecture and statues. Be sure to seek it out and there are many other beautiful sites nearby.
These small water fountains are built in to the facing of the baroque buildings on the corners of the streets. Little water is now coming out of the spouts but the workmanship of the figures is good.

Coming off the Piazza della vergogna you almost immediately hit the square dei quattro canti. one almost misses it because it is in a busy crossroad where few of the busiest shopping streets of Palermo meet. Take your time to watch the monuments. Absolutely worth to see.

Helpful staff who parked the car for us and dealt with the bags. The room was disappointingly small and not light enough for my taste but comfortable enough. We only stayed one night and could not access the spa as we had not booked. The lift is old and the staircase would not

Hotel positioned for tourists Arriving with vehicle proved difficult... But Anna met us and walked 10 blocks to where we parked... And assisted us to locate a park nearby... Free parking behind streets (car was there 3 days later when we arrived back... Ready to go to airport)

These four corners (quattro canti) are the heart of the city, from here you can walk anywhere, or just people watch, Old buildings with statues and fountains on all four corners, lots of shops on every block, large, beautiful, fountain just a few steps away.
This maybe a sight to admire very early otherwise expect crowds in the hundreds all wanting to glimpse these magnificent building exteriors, its an architectural visual feast.

This is a classic part of Palermo where the buildings on each corner mirror each other. The area around here has the roads blocked off so walking is easy and there are a lot of shops and restaurants here too.
A fine set of buildings with fantastic facades. Very typical buildings for the period - and captures the atmosphere of Palermo well.
The roads that intersect here are largely pedestrianised, hence very easy to negotiate. The 'Four Points' has four Baroque sculptural testaments to the Seasons and antique gods.
This is one of my favorite places in Palermo. The 4 corners in the Baroque square represent the near-identical facades of which contain fountains with statues of the four seasons. Must see!

Beautiful Intersection with 4 carved walls facing each other. Definitely worth looking at, it's much better than it sounds

A model was having a shoot here when I visited and no wonder really. One of those places that adds to the romance of an Italian holiday.

The four corners is a busy junction between some of the main streets in Palermo. The architecture is impressive and it tends to be a nice shaded spot to get out of the sun for a few minutes!

We were lucky to have a guide explain the significance of this place. four seasons statues, four patron (female saints) and the four kings of spain. yes it is busy so watch your back, but enjoy how well this intersection is put together.

Quattro Canti is one of the main attractions of Palermo and a must seen. It's a central spot in the historical center.

Nice to see but I doubt you would want to spend much time there as all the cars are rushing around. Take care when taking photos as we say people taking risks and the drivers will not stop for you. On the plus side it is easy to pop past when you are visiting other things as it

A must see in Palermo these four corner sculptures each representing a different season. Absolutely stunning, but like much of Palermo's treasures, in serious need of power washing. Great detail, each different, yet all welcoming in a similar manner.

Beautiful statues and monuments at each corner of the junction. Drove past looking for the needle in a haystack that is a parking spot in Palermo. Walked back for good look later. Tried to catch 2 corners in photo.

Set at a very busy road junction it is difficult to obtain a close view of the architectural figures of the Quattro Canti. This is a great shame for they are finely sculptured and deserve a better view. Well worth a visit.

You should see it by just walking around...it is the crossroads of two of the cities major road arteries...the old establishment in stone on a grand scale..4 fountains for emphasis...or book into the Hotel Eurostar and see it from your balcony..all the time

This is the neural center of Palermo. Teatro Massimo, San Cataldo church, etc. are very near by from here. You could spend at least an hour looking at all the detail of these four corners. A great place to start walking from around Palermo.

Intersection with buildings on each corner sporting elaborate baroque facades, displaying statues and fountains. Each building is in a different district of Palermo and the facades represent the saint of each corresponding district, the four seasons and Spanish Kings. Built in
Great architecture that outlines the history and lineage of Palermo, great detail, craftsmanship and design. worth putting up with incessant requests to go on a horse tour just to visit here.

We were lucky that the four corners was almost on the same street as where we were staying in Palermo, so we had the pleasure of walking past here almost everyday! It can get very busy with tourists, but it is definitely worth a visit. The architecture is beautiful and it always
Whatever the time of day the sun shines on one of these four corners. Beautiful location in the heart of the old city.
walk around all corners to get the best views - and then visit the Piazza Pretoria for the fountain (about 20 metres away)

Just round the corner from our hotel so used to just go there to sit on the steps on one of the fountains and watch and listen! Fascinating
Don't miss this intersection and the beautiful architecture and statues. One corner always has sunlight!

The four corners' intersection is the crossing of two major streets in the historic area, a great place from which to orient yourself to the city. Our hotel was just a short walk away, as is the pedestrian area. There is major shopping here in this clean and pleasant city.

each of the 4 corners has a series of 3 different symbolic Baroque Statues. It is the center of the city and the main cross roads of Via Maqueda which continues into the old part of the city and Corso Vittorio Emanuele which leads you down to the marina, sea and gardens.

If you are near Fontana della Vergogna, or on your way to the Norman Castle from Via Roma you will walk right through this intersection. In addition if you get here and it is late afternoon join the locals for their afternoon "stroll" - it seems half the town does this on the
Visiting Quattro Canti, the architecture and statues give you a good indication of what Palermo is all about.

when the four corners of the street come together at Piazza Pretoria and you can "take in" beautiful sculptures. We didn't spend much time here, but it's another item that makes Palermo uniquely Palermo.
You're walking in the middle of the city center and suddenly you see this amazing intersection with nice sculptures on each corner. Nice to have a good look at, but not to spend more than 10 minutes.

Located next to Piazza Pretoria the four corners of the street come together in a most amazing way. Each corner has beautiful sculptures that surround this busy intersection.You need to spend time taking photos and analyzing the fine details of the sculptures. The architecture

Quite amazing to see these beautiful sculptures that define this busy intersection in Palermo. Remember to look up and appreciate the entire length and breadth of each sculpture.
Great spot with lovely architecture. something you really should see when in Palermo. Lots of other interesting architecture in the neighborhood.
It's great to have art like this on a busy street. Just don't look up and wander into the road. The cars are rushing by.
Stumbled across the intersection by accident while sightseeing. Wonderful architecture and sculpture, each corner different.

This an intersection between two main roads in the city. The sculptures represent the four seasons and the attraction is easily viewed from the street . The east west road runs from here to the opera house in a pedestrianized area and in the other direction taking in various

This busy urban crossroads divides Palermo into four quadrants. At each corner is a fountain and three levels of statuary celebrating the Spanish rulers of Sicily and the city's patron saints. Great for people watching.

Each corner has its own style, and that's really good. However, one could enjoy it even more if there was a circle right in the middle of the street where one could stand in order to take great pictures, because of the traffic.
Really nice place to visit. Right in the center of the city of Palermo. Near of a lot of attractions.
First viewed on a market tour, this landmark became a compass point for our time in Palermo, and it was beautiful
Very interesting architectural ensemble. The corner facades of the buildings adhere to the same style but the buildings are all different. Wonder if there's a special term for this in architecture

It is of beautiful arquitecture but sadly maintened. The corner is very dirty, some of it even with grafittis... It is sad... No markings or explanations of any kind at the site, just a busy corner with frantic traffic. You go, you see, you cry for the utter lack of care for

Anyone visiting Palermo will eventually end up here. Beautiful four buildings set on each corner - from here you can walk up to the cathedral and the capuchin monks or down to the coast. Well worth a lovely stroll down any of the roads leaving the four corners.
On first sight very impressive. Not to be missed. Didn't know it represented the four seasons but Wikipedia informed us.

If you are any where in the old town of Palermo you will pass by this ornate crossroad. The buildings at the intersection of Via Marqueda and Corso Vittorio Emanuele ( often closed most of the day and evening for pedestrian walking, still watch out for bicycles and a few motor
No matter which corner you stand on or which way you look you are surrounded by historical building and beautiful architecture. a must see location.
Standing in the square surrounded by these awesome buildings is a must do in Palermo. It is close to other must visit places.

You can't just take a quick glance, your gaze wanders from the bottom of one corner to the top then across to the next bldg. and so on
When I went there, there was a scholl work, and the young students could explain to turists, in italian or english,, the master piece Works, statues, etc.

I visited a few years ago and the architecture still takes over my mind. I am traveling back in a few months to visit again. Quattro Canti is a gorgeously historic piazza with matching 4 corners of the most intricate work. A must see!
All Baroque with compliments from the Spanish. Any direction you walk from this site is a treat. Just be sure and you stop for a gelato or a cannoli!

The 4 corners are a must see and are easy to fit into your schedule, as they are a very short walk from the cathedral. The crossroads are busy with traffic and even horses, its exactly how you wold picture an Italian city. They are stunning to look at stoping many in there

These buildings have statues of the 4 seasons. Also there are the four Spanish Kings. Finally the 4 patrons of Palermo.

A lovely intersection with four facades that have curved walls and fountains. I had to try not to get run over while I was taking some photos here, and there were also many men with horses and carts to transport tourists, so we had to watch out for touts, too.

Here I fell in love with Sicily and decided that I have to live on this island sooner or later. Back in 2005 it was still dirty, chaotic etc. But with the years the city got better organized, cleaned out, pedestrian zones ecc. The "4 Corners" are kind of the vortex of Palermo.
Here you can admire, that even such a practical thing as a busy crossroad can be historical monument :)
Stunning architecture definately worth a closer look. Take care when visiting as part of a busy road junction in the middle of Palermo.
This is an interesting but busy corner in the city centre but is certainly worth a look, in particular the details of the carvings.
While it is a busy plaza, this is still a beautiful area to see. It reminded me of the Four Fountains in Rome, but not as beautiful or interesting. Still, worth your time.
Enjoyed a few days in Palermo and walked through Quattro Canti several times, and found it always busy.

Technically speaking this is a crossroad, but there are four delicious buildings with great decorations at each corner.
Four beautiful matching buildings around this junction, quite a sight, and in the neighbourhood of quite a few places of interest in central Palermo
ID HEARD A BIT ABOUT THIS PLACE.. probably NEEDS A GOOD CLEAN, but its didn't inspire me greatly.. A lot of Palermo looked like it needed a good steam clean
While it looks like a busy traffic intersection, it has been there for quite some time and the corner buildings are most interesting to view and understand. Interesting architecture and exterior art.

A very impressive intersection near some very cool and slightly rougher neighborhoods. By rougher I mean a little poorer and working class. And very interesting and enjoyable.

An interesting 4 corner intersection with beautiful architecture and fountains on each corner, very much worth the visit and a great insight into a different way of life.

Since I like to walk around a city or twon I always like to memorize monuments, churches, shops, etc. to find my bearings.This Quattro Canti with its four corners lovely carved statues mounted on each corner of thisstrreet is one of them. I don't know how many times I would have
This is the center of the old city in Polermo. While we were in Polermo we walked the old city extensively and there were few other structures as beautiful as these four statues.

This street intersection reflects thoughtful aesthetic planning to make maximum impact in a relatively small vista. The baroque exteriors are not only beautiful; the architecture creates a great early-urban experience
You have to go there if in Palermo. Not that amazing, but it is a quick visit and probably worth stopping there just to check it off the travel list.

The four corners show the four seasons on one tier..the four kings on another tier and the top tier the four women saints who were protectors of Palermo ,until they failed to save them and were replaced by new Saint

After a morning tour of Palermo with a fantastic guide and our ear pieces in it was great to have free time to explore and this was on our "to see list". The only reason I did not give this an excellent was it was a bit grubby and could use a clean up.
I saw these while touring on a bus and then took a walk to get closer. This is a must see if you are in Palermo.

Happened on this by chance. Not a long walk from the port but it is a busy intersection. One could spend much time looking at the detail and taking photos. In its' prime it was probably quite striking. Unfortunately, like much of Palermo, it could do with a good clean.

This Four Corners is the heart of Palermo with spectacular architecture and lots of buildings and fountains for photo shoot. This is the most unique intersection in the whole of Europe. The place is very well maintained to benefit future generations. From this intersection,
Each corner has it's own feel. Horse and cart rentals on one, fountain on another. Make the trip around to each corner to see and appreciate all the magnificent architecture
Beautiful intersection with four matching buildings on all four corners. Stand and imagine what this square was like when first built - it must have been stunning!
Literally a crossroads with four decorated buildings with fountains on the corners. Lots to see here and nearby.

We passed by this cross section while walking through Palermo. Didn't spend more than 10 minutes (mainly taking pictures) but the place was very interesting where the 4 corners of the road had buildings that look exactly the same. The section is adjacent to the Pretoria Fountain
Visit here and you will understand why people tell you that the old city was divided into 4 quarters. We video'd it which was easier than taking photos. Grand, detailed carvings adorn it.

Amazing architecture. Unusual and fascinating One of many amazing sights in Palermo, but don't get run over w while viewing

The Quattro Canti in the heart of Storico Centrale (historic district) in central Palermo features Baroque architecture. From this Four Corners/buildings you can easily walk to other worthwhile sites (such as the Cathedral), as well as stopping for gelato and souvenir shopping.

We came across this amazing intersection by chance and we were very pleased that we did. The architectural structures, on each of the four corners of the intersection were amazing with their style and sculptures with each complimenting the others. It is easy to overlook the fact

Contains 4 concave facades of the 4 seasons with statues of patron saints of each quarter of the city and of the Spanish kings. Nearby is the "Fountain of Shame" (Fontana Pretoria) with mythological creatures and statues, all nude, hence "shame".
This was a lovely part of the city. Each building on the 4 corners was beautiful. Must see this intersection.

Stunning corners marking the intersection of Corso Vittorio Emanuele and Via Maqueda which is seen as the traditional centre of Palermo.
Like everything else in this area of Palermo Quatro Canti is an example of architecture over the years. Nearby is the fountain in the Piazza Pretoria and at least four churches worth seeing.
A treat for the eye! A must when you are in Palermo. It is located among the rest of Palermos treasures.
This is the centre of town. What a wonderful corner. If you visit Palermo, you have to and I mean you have to visit Quattro Canti.... a real treat.
Amazing.. not every day you see such beautiful four corners of buildings with sculptures.. very nice corner in the old city of Palermo.. recommended

Nice atmospheric crossroads, four fountains to look at, only let down by the place being a hub for spivs with horse carriages and tat for sale.

One of our favourite spots in Palermo, for the second time in this area and we couldnt miss passing by Quattro Canti again. Leaves you speachless, trully beautiful attraction, elegant and respectful. This year a "just married" couple took photo shots in the centre of the quattro

It is too bad this is such a fast moving intersection that so many cars are whizzing by it if difficult to see the details of each corner. What you could see had interesting details.

text.wiki:
The following is a timeline of the history of the city of Palermo, Sicily, Italy.


== Prior to 19th century ==
415 BC – Carthaginians in power, but continue using Greek name Panormos on the city's coins.
276 BC – Conquered by Pyrrhus of Epirus.
275 BC – Carthaginian reconquest.
254 BC – Romans take Palermo under the Latin name Panormus.
251 BC – Attempted Carthaginian reconquest fails in the Battle of Panormus.
1st century AD – Catholic Diocese of Palermo established.
440 – Vandal siege and conquest of Panormus.
535 – Byzantine siege and conquest of Panormus.
830 – August: Arabs begin siege of Palermo.
831 – August: Saracens in power.
1072 – Normans take Palermo.
1130 – Palermo becomes capital of the Kingdom of Sicily.
1136 – San Giovanni degli Eremiti church built.
1140 – Cappella Palatina consecrated.
1143 – Martorana church founded.
1160 – Chiesa di San Cataldo (church) built.
1185 – Palermo Cathedral construction begins.
1191 – Basilica della Santissima Trinità del Cancelliere active.
1282
30 March: Sicilian Vespers uprising against Anjou rule.
4 September: Peter I crowned as king of Sicily in Palermo Cathedral.
1330 – Palazzo Sclafani built.
1394 – University established.
1460 – Porta Nuova (Palermo) (gate) built.
1477 – Printing press in operation (approximate date).
1557 – September: Flood.(it)
1584 – Fontana Pretoria (fountain) installed in the Piazza Pretoria.
1620 – Quattro Canti laid out.
1676 – 2 June: Naval Battle of Palermo occurs offshore.
1693 – 1693 Sicily earthquake.
1726 – Earthquake.
1734 – 2 September: Spanish conquest.
1735 – 3 July: Charles V crowned as king of Sicily in Palermo Cathedral.
1740 – Earthquake.
1760 – Allegorical Apotheosis of Palermo artwork painted in the Palazzo Isnello.
1790 – Palermo Astronomical Observatory founded.
1795 – Botanical Garden of Palermo opens.


== 19th century ==
1801 – Astronomer Piazzi discovers Ceres (dwarf planet).
1806 – University of Palermo established.
1837 – Cholera epidemic.
1848 – 12 January: Sicilian revolution of 1848 begins.
1849 – 13 May: "Neapolitans capture Palermo."
1860
6 June: Forces of Garibaldi take Palermo.
Giornale di Sicilia newspaper begins publication.
1861
Teatro Garibaldi (Palermo) opens.
Population: 199,911.
1866 – Anti-government unrest; crackdown.
1871 – Population: 219,938.
1873 – Società Siciliana per la Storia Patria (history society) founded.
1886 – Palermo Centrale railway station opens.
1891 – 15 November: Esposizione Nazionale di Palermo (exhibit) opens.
1897
Teatro Massimo opens.
Population: 287,972.
1900 – L'Ora newspaper begins publication.(it)US Città di Palermo was founded by Ignazio Majo Pagano


== 20th century ==
1901 – Population: 309,566.
1906 - First edition of Targa Florio.
1919 - Gonzaga Institute, Palermo founded by Jesuits.
1930 – Cinema Orfeo opens.
1931
February: Palermo flood of 1931.
Palermo–Boccadifalco Airport opens.
1932 – Stadio Littorio (stadium) opens.
1936 – Population: 411,879.
1940-1945 - Palermo is bombed during the Second War World.
1943 – 22 July: Allied forces arrive in Palermo.
1947 – Sicilian Regional Assembly headquartered in city.
1950s/1980s - Sack of Palermo.
1953 – Cinema Astoria opens.
1957 – October: Grand Hotel des Palmes Mafia meeting 1957.
1960 – Palermo Airport opens.
1961 – Population: 587,985.
1970 - Mauro De Mauro disappeared.
1971 – Population: 642,814.
1974 – Palermo Notarbartolo railway station opens.
1979 - Mario Francese and Boris Giuliano killed.
1980 - Piersanti Mattarella and Gaetano Costa killed.
1981 – Population: 701,782.
1982 - Pio La Torre, Carlo Alberto Dalla Chiesa and his wife Emanuela Setti Carraro killed.
1983 - Rocco Chinnici and Mario D’Aleo killed.
1985 – Antonino Cassarà killed.
March: Sicilian local election, 1985 held.
1986 – Maxi Trial begins.
1988 – Internazionali Femminili di Palermo tennis tournament begins.
1990 – Palermo metropolitan railway service begins operating.
Palermo hosts some matches of 1990 World Cup.
1991 – Population: 698,556.
1992 – Anti-Mafia judges Giovanni Falcone and Paolo Borsellino killed.
1993 – Pino Puglisi killed.
Leoluca Orlando becomes mayor.


== 21st century ==
2001 – Diego Cammarata becomes mayor.
2006 – Paolo Romeo becomes archbishop.
2007 – March: Sicilian local election, 2007 held.
2010 – UCI Palermo cinema opens.
2012 – Leoluca Orlando becomes mayor again.
2013 – Population: 654,987 city; 1,243,638 province.
2015 - Palermo’s Itinerario Arabo-Normanno proclaimed World Heritage Site by Unesco.
The Palermitan Sergio Mattarella becomes President of Italian Republic.
2018 - Palermo is “Capitale Italiana della cultura” and hosts the 12th edition of Manifesta.
Pope Francis visits the city.


== See also ==
History of Palermo
List of mayors of Palermo
List of landmarks in Palermo
Archivio di Stato di Palermo (state archives)
History of Sicily
Timelines of other cities in the macroregion of Insular Italy:(it)Sardinia: Timeline of Cagliari
Sicily: Timeline of Catania, Messina, Syracuse, Trapani


== References ==


=== Citations ===

This article incorporates information from the Italian Wikipedia, French Wikipedia, and German Wikipedia.


=== Bibliography ===


== External links ==

text.quote: This lavish auditorium was built in 1897 & remains Italy's largest with a seated capacity of 1,387.
trip:
Overview One of the biggest opera houses in Europe, Teatro Massimo is renowned for its excellent acoustiscs and holds over 1,300 seats.The venue hosts more than 130 music, opera and dance events every year.The exteriors are in neo-classical style with...more Address:
Piazza Giuseppe Verdi, 90138, Palermo, Sicily ItalyMap
Amazing place to see and a tour is well worth doing. These are available in different languages. If you have time you can have a coffee and meal at the restaurant.

Fascinating to know that while Teatro Massimo is not as well known, it is the largest theatre in Italy. We didn’t manage to catch a show here as the year-end performances were hugely popular. But we managed to watch the performances broadcast live on a big screen right outside
I went and had a tour around the Teatro with my teen brother. And he enjoyed it too. It’s like a little time travel. The experience was nice. It’s the 3rd largest theatre after Paris and Vienna.

There are guided tours of the theatre. We were seeing a show so we did not take the tour. The theatre is a very impressive venue and well worth a look even if you bare not there for a show. There is a bar and a Tourist information kiosk on site as well.

We thought we would have an enhanced experience of this magnificent theatre by attending an Opera but found that our seats which cost 60 euros each offered no vision of the stage or the theatre. I would suggest that the guided tour which is 8 euros may be more worthwhile unless

We enjoyed the services of a very helpful guide who spoke perfect English. Some you win and this was a fine example of that saying. We were lucky to be there on a day that a performance was to take place in the evening. We thought that this might cramp the occasion but no, the

I'm going to keep this brief, there's so many GREAT reviews here on TA already, but I will add a few photo's... a picture is worth a thousand words. Do you have any idea what it's like to be the only one standing in an Opera House, I do and it's an incredible feeling. One of my

Sadly, we were not able to go inside the building,. due the lat of hours. But we could see, from the outside, and also, from the hop on hop off tour that we took, that it was magnificent. One should go to Palermo and see this through! I am most definitly going back to Sicily -
To be honest wasn't really bothered about going here but was really impressed with the whole tour which was about 30minutes for 8 euros well worth it

A beautiful theatre in Palermo - 3rd largest Opera house in Italy. It’s being gradually renovated but is still in remarkable condition. There is a 30 min tour worth doing - 4 Euro pp. The guide was knowledgable and informative.
It’s a beautiful theater! I was impressed, delighted! I had never seen an old theater from the inside and it’s realy beautiful. If you have a half hour to spare, go for an inside tour.
Interesting to get behind the scenes and into the auditorium of this beautiful interior. Well worth a visit
Here we are in Palermo, the beautiful capital of Sicily Island. There are many monuments, one of my favorite is the Teatro Massimo.

The largest opera house of Italy, never restored so get the original glimpse before it starts. Large auditorium, nice spaces, retracting ceiling petals, elevating stage. Hard to fi tickets during our visit window so just toured the place. End with a cappuccino on the terrace.

Teatro Massimo is reputedly the largest theater in Italy. However, it has wonderful acoustics and doesn’t feel large when you’re inside. My wife and I visited in December and saw an excellent performance of “The Nutcracker” which will long remember. Also memorable were the

This building is so grand and beautiful! Apparently the third biggest historic theatre in Europe. I loved the fact that it looks quite different from every other theatre I saw around Europe. The size and the Magnificence of the building makes you realise this city had a glorious

I went on the tour for the opera house, and it was terrible. For 8 Euros, they show you the main entrance, and then let you see the main opera house from both the main audience area, and where royalty sits. We also got to see a room where the men used to go and talk politics

We visited Teatro Massimo to see My Fair Lady on Sunday 1 December. We had seats in the side tier on the 5th floor. The stage was to our right. Fortunately, our seats were two of three in the front row. Leaning forward & craning our necks we could just about see two-thirds of
We saw My Fair Lady which was performed wonderfully. We sat in box seat on the side and had a hard time seeing our side of the stage. Try to get seats as near the middle as you can.

As the largest opera house in Italy, Teatro Massimo is a wonderful venue to attend a Symphony. Purchasing tickets on line well in advance was also very easy. The acoustics are outstanding and there is not a bad seat in the house. Before visiting Palermo, check the calendar

This is such a magnificent building! The largest opera house in Italy and the second largest in Europe. The acoustics are sublime. Plush red velvet seating with ample personal space for total comfort. The ornate boxes lining each side are highlighted with beautiful lighting
Head to the opera in the evening. I had my own opera box and felt like royalty. The performance was stunning and the theatre - simply breathtaking.

Al Pacino-Michael's daughter was shot down on the steps of this theater in the last installment of the Godfather, which brings a lot of tourists to the site. Other than that, not much: built in the late 19th Century by father and son architects, it's now gathering place for
Excellent theatre with ancient and historical body and great sound atmosphere. If you have the chance psy some time to watch a show in the theater. Beautiful architecture..

Visiting Teatro Massimo for the second time was the best gift from Sicilia. This beautiful theater with gorgeous exterior and interior and great history will charm you even from outside. We were lucky to visit the opera by Ludovico Einlaudi - "Winter journey" which was dedicated
One of these remarkable baroque buildings of Palermo, huge. At one side there are some nice terraces on the square.

A bit like the cathedral the Massimo is probably a bit more impressive from the outside. Interior pretty plain. Had a really good night as seats were a good price even though we went on opening night and the acoustics up in the gods were great. Had never heard of this oratorio

I love opera, and this one was long on my list. Having booked tickets online (easy enough), I picked them up at the shop on the day of the performance, put on the little black dress and went to my seat. Everyone is dressed up, which is nice, and the auditorium (which is huge!)
As the title suggest, the Theater (their opera and balet) is massive. It is just the beautiful to look at. Around, there are many shops and bars. I recommend going on a tour of the inside.

I missed the chance to see a performance at this beautiful theatre but the basic tours is well run and informative. Good price and they have a lot of extra tours available such as the back stage and terrace tour so you can really have a a thorough day trip.

We were strolling through the neighborhood near our hotel and came upon this building without knowing what it was. On the north side there is a large area with steps where folks were resting. It's a great place for a photo op. The building was closed so we did not go inside.

Great building. Sadly, they were no performances on during our stay but take the tour and find out all about this lovely building ... and make sure you visit the roof top for the most impressive panorama of the entire city! Not to be missed!

It was new information for me that Palermo is located in the third largest opera house in Europe. The building is impressive, and about a 40-minute tour of the building took us through box-seats to the parrante floor. Tour is inclusive and we got lucky to watch the ballet

A short but informative tour, friendly, funny guide in English. You have to do it once. Don't forget you can sit in the Royal box, where a scene from the Godfather part3 was filmed and test your voice with the amazing acoustic sounds in the echo room.

Very interesting tour by charming Italian/English speaking tour guide - definitely worth the money. Would also highly recommend lunch in the alfresco theatre restaurant - excellent value for money. You don't actually have to take the tour to eat in the restaurant which can be

Our family took the English guided tour and really enjoyed seeing the inside of this beautiful theatre. No performances in the Summer, but they host opera and ballet from September to June. Other languages offered and the cost was €8 per adult, €5 for children. Very popular

Teatro Massimo is an imposing big structure right in the center of Palermo. It is the biggest theater in Italy and the third in Europe. It has a very beautiful neoclassical facade, with two lions and a staircase on the main entrance facing a nice piazza which is full of people

It is the biggest opera house in Italy, and 2nd biggest in Europe. Built in a beautiful neoclassical style. You can join a 30 minutes guided tour inside. Tourists like to visit here as it was filmed in the "The Godfather" movie.
This theater is one of the most impressive in Palermo and looks beautiful from the outside. The lion statues outside the entrance are impressive.

Beautiful from the outside and imposing, this building is at the center of Palermo and not to be missed. The guided tour only lasts 30 minutes and will explain the history and architecture of the place which is relatively new for Palermo built in 1861.
This is a magnificent theatre full of history and a pleasure to visit. They have guided tours, which last for only 30 minutes, but they are well worth it!

Closed to performances while I was there ( early August). Re - opening in Sep for opera performances. Spectacular, opulent, feel the history, some sections needing renovation but no less appealing. Your Guide was both succinct and informative. I would recommend booking a

The tour took about 30-35 minutes and ticked all the boxes. The theatre is beautiful and the tour takes you through the various foyers, interval areas, the main theatre and also into the Royal Box. The tour continues through other interesting areas like the domed echo room.
Probably the most pretty building in palermo, the only one with decent maintenance on the outside. on the piazza guisepe verdi , nice place with small terrace and iceshops.

Do the guided tour for about 8 euros each. The theatre is beautiful to look around, we saw the orchestra rehearsing and ballet dancers warming up. You also get to go in the Royal Box where the top price ticket is only 100 euros, making London's West End ludicrously expensive.
As we learned, this is third biggest active Teatro in Europe, unfortunately been able to admire it only from exterior, haven't had a chance for going inside.
Beautiful historic building, you cannot miss it, located in the city centre. We didnt go inside, but we went for a drink in a theatre caffe, and it was really pleasant.
Beautiful theatre in the heart of the old section of Palermo. Take the tour of the inside as it is just as impressive as the exterior.

I wanted to go in/see a show, but time prohibited it - loved the outside of the building and I look forward to going inside the next time I'm back in Palermo. The square outside/surrounding streets appeared to be the main social hub of the city...

We visited the theatre with combined English and Italian tour. Was supposed to be English only, but not disturbing. Beautiful place. Just one point. Wanted to go to toilet at the end. They do not allow for that unless you drink something. Came across very unfriendly.

The third largest theatre in Europe and very definitely grand, the only downside of the visit was that your eight euros only buys you about half an hour of strictly guided tour - no loiter time allowed.
Went to see an Opera by Philip Glass and was not disappointed. we went for pre show drinks in the bar downstairs and the service was excellent. waiting staff were very attentive.

This place is Palermo central --- from morning to dusk shops , day markets and restaurants/bars are nearby... The structure itself is amazing. Concerts are scheduled as well should you want to experience Sicilian Opera.

Great experience as there were practice ballet and orchestra playing American Jazz sessions and our group had a grid Teatro guide.

The tour is paid . Eight euros per person. Worth every cent. Out tour lady was informative, friendly and extremely accommodating. The theater is beautiful, old and it needs s lot of investment , but it remains a sight to see.

Attended a ballet (the last performance of the season). It was fantastic. Comfortable seating! The event was part of a "soirée Rolland Petit" with full orchestra and an opera singer. After the show we had a drink at the outside bar. Fabulous !

Built in late 1800's and originally held 3200 spectators. Beautiful inside and out in the typical Italian style theatre.
Beautiful building. I didn't go inside. There is a free WiFi in that square. You can walk easy to all different shopping areas! Also close to the teatro Politeama.
