The theatre is a beautiful work of architecture, a jewel in the center of the square. I really liked to go there for a performance and to admire the inside. Too bad I could't because I visited Palermo during the day.

One of the main attraction in Palermo. There is a large square in front. The hop on hop off bus is stopping just in front.

Exquisite. The patio dining before a performance was excellent. The atmosphere with a full moon over the architectural entrance mesmerizing and romantic. The service was outstanding; professional and friendly. Even with the chilly weather that moment was sterling.

The third biggest theater in Europe. Great building. Guided tours inside available in various languages. The tour is a standard rush though, lacking of spirit and compassion. What a pity, expected more because the place is amazingly beautiful.

The Teatro Massimo sits in mid town very near to the famous four corners of Palermo. It has served the city for many years with the greatest talents of Europe. Beautiful architecture, spacious seating and fantastic tapestries. Open most days for tours.
Lovely theatre seen as part of our cruise on Norwegian Epic. Lovely stone work largest theatre I have ever seen well worth the effort of seeing.

This stunning theatre dominates the square and is a real focal point for the locals as well as visitors. It fills an entire block and is worth walking right around enjoying the building from every angle.

We took guided tour of this theater and the interior is beautiful! The guide also tells us the last scene of Godfather 3 and other related scenes. Unfortunately, there was no performance at the day we visit (January 25th) otherwise we would like to enjoy the performance here.

Outside and inside - stunning theatre. So nicely decorated for the holidays. Seigfried version developed just for Massimo was an insult to the gradeur of this theatre!
Unfortunately I just saw the outside because I was in a cruise and I was running out of time It was the month of December and the Poincetas flowers were beautiful.
I visited Palermo during the 1 day of the new year and as you can see by the attached photo it was a fantastic sight. I hope to have the opportunity of visiting it one day...

We cought the rehearsal of The Magic Flute, which was a really special experience. Even my four years old son enjoyed it very much.

Feels like you are in another time watching amazing performers. From the orchestra to the stars on stage and the entire cast. I’d advise to watch a show. Incredible! You can feel the excitement from every entertainer. It must be the Massimo Theatre

Stunning Theater! As the hole city of Palermo. Walk on the square to take a look around it, go inside if you have the opportunity to do so. Great cafes outside if you want to grab a coffee with a view.

text.quote: Grand 9th century palace with a neo-classical facade, historic chapel & ornate royal apartments.
trip: The Palazzo dei Normanni, situated in Piazza Indipendenza, just near the Porta Nuova, is an architectural symbol of Sicily itself. The building you see before you goes back to the Arab conquest but the foundations go back to the Phoenicians of the 8th to 5th centuries BC and
This place is where you truly want the walls to talk. Amazing mixture of Moorish and Norman styles living happily together. A must see. As most things in Palermo.

On a warm Feb afternoon we visited this lovely Palace and museum. The staff were helpful, spoke good English and were unobtrusive throughout. It is ideally located minutes off of the main market and Square, up a street with museums, gardens and restaurants. The exhibits were

The chapel, covered in beautiful mosaics, is the main attraction. That is worth the two stars. Almost everything else is not worth walking through. On the main floor are some exhibits about the history of the Normans in Sicily and Southern Italy which is mildly interesting.

The Norman Palace was long the centre of power in Sicily and, as the name indicates, is closely associated with the Normans who ruled Sicily for about 100 years from the late 11th century. It is somewhat austere and fortress-like outside but it is massive and inside has much

Stunning doesn't even begin to describe how beautiful this massive Palace is! I took so so many photos, there are tours and I recommend you take one. Best to go early so the cue isn't too long, I walked right in, but the velvet ropes lead you to believe this is one busy place.
Great castle to walk round. We went as part of the hop of hop off tour. Admission is fairly reasonable.
I thought it would be just another palace/castle... And then I entered the Palatine Chapel... I was speechless... So beautiful!
Generally this is good, but the Chapel is absolutely superb. Not far out of the centre and easily walkable - call in at the Cathedral on the way up

Don’t miss it. Never seen such a magnificent, well preserved Byzantine mosaics. To say the atmosphere in the Chapel is magical is just an understatement!!! Unfortunately the magic was interrupted because we had to change the audio guide in the middle of the visit due to low

It’s an avoidable destination. The amount of ticket does not justify the visit. Most of the palace rooms were closed. The garden is a joke except few old trees. See it from outside and that would be enough.

One of the worst organizers I have seen, buy the ticket not on site but somewhere else, no toilet, found a toilet but works only with 50 cent, paid full ticket but was told second floor is closed (for no reason without even mentioning anywhere), and no proper description in

Well worth the visit, the chapel was beautiful and the rooms were outstanding, very well preserved considering the age of the Palace. the staircase in marble you can just imagine the people who have walked down them in there beautiful cloths. The horse drawn carriage has been

We walk a lot to get here and it is worth it. the mosaics are fabulous. We did not spend a lot of time here because it was near closing.
This is a miniature of Monreale which is close by. If you can go to Monreale Cathedral. You will be awed.

Once the bunch of garrulous Italian women in front of the ticket office had dispersed I bought our tickets (€15 each) for the Cappella Palatina, Castrum Superius Royal Apartments and the Royal Gardens (an extra €4 that we didn't find out until later and had to go out and buy

We went to see the palace on a day when we could not see the royal apartments - if you cant see those, it probably isnt worth the visit. The garden is truly disappointing and I can see from other people's pictures that the apartments are really the best part.

Individual rooms are aesthetically or historically interesting, The courtyard is especially nice. The parliament that meets here is one of the oldest in Europe. Other public rooms reflect a succession of periods. In fact, the most interesting thing about the Palace is its age

Awesome museum, many in one in actual fact, take a ticket that allows you to visit everything, the royal rooms, the norman part, the sala dei leoni, it is all beautiful.

Place was interesting, highlight was the cappella palatina, simply stunning, fabulous. Didn't buy the right ticket so couldnt go in some rooms which was very annoying. Not sure why you would need separate tickets for different rooms!

Byzantine at its best. We had no idea how special this chapel was. It is virtually impossible to describe. This amazing blend of east meets west is at its finest.

While unassuming from the outside, the Normal Palace, especially the Palatine chappel, is truly an artistic and historic wonder, not something to be missed.

1. Yes, it is a marvel. It’s UNESCO world heritage site status is very well deserved, for its combination of styles. 2. Ticket buying is a challenge! Ticket titles (what is printed in the ticket) do not correspond to what you actually can visit. The “integrated” ticket states

Royal apartments were closed so disappointed. I prefer to wander through such places instead of shuffling through exhibitions about them, regardless of the background they provide. In a crowded situation it’s hard to absorb much.

In this times that you´re paying a big amount of money for any small thing that you want to visit, in this place you enjoy any cent,. Garden not so interesting.

The city was working on renovations to the Norman Palace which was disappointing, but the chapel was definitely a must-see in Palermo. The mosaic work was amazing. The intricacy of each panel was a true work of art.
Do not miss this Palace. Great example of Architecture, well conserved. Breathtaking views. Mosaics alone are deserved a trip.

We had visited the Norman Palace several years ago while n a cruise and wanted to return to spend more time there. we were not disappointed. The chapel with its gold mosaics is truly amazing. we had a chance to visit the gardens on this trip and they are worth your time.

16euros for a visit staff are very officious few thank yous lots of dismissive gestures. Palatine Chapel is beautiful, Royal Appartments we’re closed I didn’t think this palace respected its visitors or was good value

The palace has many aspects and we were there on a Monday which meant that all areas were open. I particularly enjoyed the Royal Apartments as the decor and and frescoes were so inline with the time. Even the curtains were awe inspiring.

Very interesting. Enjoyed a couple of hours walking around this Palace. A tad expensive I thought at €10.50 for entrance fee in comparison to other places I have visited in Italy. Having said that though, I would recommend it.

If only to visit the Cappella Palatina, you must visit the Norman Palace. It's magnificent. The rest of the palace is also lovely and worth visiting, but honestly it pales by comparison. In fact, see the chapel last, leaving the best for last.
Quite interesting. The chapel was lovely but far too many people to make the experience memorable. The adjoining gardens were a big let down.

We bought a Euro 14 ticket which allows you entry into the Palace plus the gardens. The main attraction within the Palace is of course The Palatine Chapel but there are other things to see within a building that also operates as government offices - including the local

There is not much to see. Just one chappel and the rest of other rooms was closed and they didnt let anybody to see. It eas strange since even the ticket says you have access also to other floors and rooms.
This is really a gem of a building and well worth a visit it is fascinating to see what is still a working government building and also was a Norman built Palace

From outside the building does not look so spectacular but the inside is definitely worth a visit. As this is a governent building not all areas can be visited all the time. You will see at the ticket office what can be visited and therefore the ticket price varies. The famous

You pay 14 euros to see the royal 1 (a few rooms with paintings on the walls, nothing royal about it), the royal gardens (quite small and kind a dirty), the chapel (really beautiful, amazing) and an exibition with a few paitings that all look the same). You also get to see the

This building traces the history of Sicily since the twelfth century and the presence of Norman. The atabo-normand style of the older parts is remarkable. Not to be missed for a two day stay in Palermo.
In the historical side of Palermo, there are a lot of attraction, but the Masterpiece Is the Cathedral.

In terms of seeing the Islamic, Christian and Judaic architecture coming together and demonstrating how they can work in peace then a visit to the Chapel is truly amazing. Given when this was constructed and the craftmanship required this is an absolute highlight of Palermo
Amazing place to visit. I spent 2 hours walking around this palace. I will definitely visit again in the future. Italy is the best place in the world to go holiday.

Amazing site, really worth a visit for his beauty, but poor administration. If you can't stand on your feet for a long time is going to be tough as there is no place to seat and rest for a bit even at the café on the top floor. You can only eat and/or have a coffee while

We came to visit the Palatine Chapel and the Royal Apartments, which were both open and absolutely stunning -- if you are interested in the Normans in Sicily, you can't miss these. However, we were disappointed with the quality of the administration of visitors -- in particular

The number one place to visit in Palermo undoubtedly. The Capella Palatina, particularly, is going to leave you speechless. The mosaics are incredible, it's hard to believe they are so old! The only drawback, of course, is that you want be alone in admiring the place -it's
We loved our visit here. There was a nice display of art about Rosalina the patron saint of Palermo. The government chambers were especially grand and worth visiting.

Cappella Palatina is the gem hidden inside this ancient palace which also serves as the seat of the Sisilian Parlament. Notice that the entrance to the chapel and to the state rooms is from the southern side of the palace, not from the Piazza Independenza as it used to be.

It was ok but not worth the tickets, esspecially the gardens which are 2 e but more beautiful park could be seen for free in front of the palace. It was stated on the brochure that it has archeological part but it was just a hole in the floor, sad to watch...

Apartments were closed and ended up paying 12 euros to see the palace and the gardens . Palace was ok but not worth the money . Gardens were non existent. Had to be done to tick off a list but wouldn’t rush back

The royal apartments were closed when we visited, and the cost of the entrance ticket was rather confusing and overpriced. But the Palatine Chapel was beautiful and if you are in Palermo, the Norman Palace is something you must see. It's an easy walk from the center of Palermo.

Half the exhibit was closed and we were charged full price. Wouldn’t bother coming here. Wasn’t very interesting, not for the cost. After paying entry fee you’ll also need to pay extra just for using the restroom...
This spectacular venue is not to be missed. Golden mosaics, high vaulted ceilings, a very special place that should not be missed.
The chapel was jaw-droppingly spectacular. Utterly entralling. Well worth the cost of entry alone. The rest of the palace is so-so.
Well, worth a visit, if not the most beautiful architecture in the world. Interesting to see the Norman influence on Sicily.
One of the most beautiful sites of the whole country. Enjoy it in the early morning to avoid the crowd peak time!
The Norman chapel is a must on any bisit to sicily the gardens and terraces are wonderful. Good limited time exhibition on the art of Santa Rosalie when we went.
The palace is nice but the most beautiful place to visit is the chapel, just gorgeous. Good exhibition as well when we visited.

The tickets should be sold as Palatine Chapel as there is nothing else available. It is a great work of art, however is filled with chairs on which you cannot seat and the transept is inaccessible.The room is badly illuminated and some details are difficult to see from the path
15 euros to get in, the archicture is marvelous, as well as the gardens, don't miss the palatine chapel, beautiful !!

The palace and chapel must be visited if you are staying in Palermo. Thankfully we managed to visit as it was closing early on the Saturday we were there due to a wedding taking place so do check the closing times rather than relying on online times so you don’t miss out. Do
The small, beautiful Palatine Chapel is a must visit when in Palermo. The Cappella Palatina (Basilica) was founded by Roger II and it is a jewel of Arab-Norman art with its splendid mosaics.
The palace as building is wonderful, but the 12 euro entrance fee just to see just a few rooms, it was too much. Most of the rooms are closed to public

Other than the fact that there was a large tour group in front of us, we enjoyed the Palace and Chapel. Like most places, admission is charged which was a bit much, but worth the visit.

We attended Sunday mass in the Chapel. It was a Latin mass with Gregorian chant. While modest in size the Chapel is stunning with a magnificent painting of Jesus in a huge cupola above the altar. The Chapel is a must to visit. The Palace includes the Sicilian Government

There is not a huge amount to see if the state apartments are closed (as they were when we visited) and you only get a 2 euro reduction on the ticket price. The garden is a nice space: they pipe music into it and there are seats around. The leaflet is a bit confusing as it
Aside from a few steps you can easily tour the rooms they have open in an hour or two. The gardens are beautiful also.

The Palatine Chapel was on our list of must see places in Palermo. The place has limited hours so we arrived right at opening. For off season it was still very busy. We had no time limits on the length of our stay so could wait for that perfect spot for photography. The small
Interesting historical palace with incredible Palatine chapel a must visit in Palermo, the chapel truly a wonder to behold
We toured and learned the history at first had, the architecture and details are perfect. Note the details on the external pillars.
The Palatine chapel is a MUST see when visiting Palermo. Amazing mozaics from the early mediëval period 12th century. The Royal Palace is worth seeing but less impressing than the chapel

Capela Palatina is the most amazing place and all the exhibits are state of art. It is the top of the list of attractions in Palermo. It is a must see and absolutely superb. The palace exhibits are attractive. It is interesting that they have a newer wing and an older wing

Capela Palatina is the most spectacular place on Earth we've ever visited! There are no any words on any of all of the known languages to describe the preciousness of the Chapel, it is truly stunning and breathtaking! Whenever in Palermo, we'll go there again, and again...
We had a good tour of the Palace at a reasonable rate. They moved the entrance from the front to the back but no signs were posted until you get to the front.

Palace exhibits are quite nice as wall as the star attraction chapel. The gardens are well worth it. Interesting plants although green houses were largely empty (November). Overall this site is rightly a must see on a short break in Palermo

I wish we had more time to see it and I wish the gardens were open (it was raining) but definitely worth the €10 entry. There’s many discounts available so look before you buy!

So firstly I would recommend that you buy tickets in advance unless you want to queue for an hour to get in. The state apartments are only open on certain days so if you want to see them make sure you check the days first (it's a reduced price on the days when they aren't open).

Of course, the Palatine chapel is the highlight, but the apartments were also very interesting. Be prepared for queues to the chapel, and perhaps it is best to see them first, get it over with, as everything else has far fewer queues. If it all gets a bit much, the gardens
Well worth a visit. So well preserved, stunning. Can get a little cramped at busy times. Choose your visiting time wisely, gardens and rooms closed on our visit.
Highly recommend visiting this palace and the Palatine Chapel. The chapel is the highlight of the tour but the private apartments, only available from Friday to Monday, are well worth a visit.
Stunning to see, the mosaics were unbelievable. Details were spectacular to see, I would highly recommend.

The visit worths the trip!! Audio phone to be recomended €6. entrance €12. We started with Palatine Chapel, continuous to Sicilian Regional Assembly and finish at the Royal Gardens. Opens at 8.15h. Better go early in order to avoid long queu of tourists.

We've been to Palermo several times but first time here. Stunning! The issue We had was the audio guide droned on for way too long and nothing was numbered in the rooms so you couldn't follow the guide easily. No staff anywhere to ask for help. Having been to Madrid palace

We only had a morning to hit the highlights in Palermo- this was the highlight. As everyone says the chapel is an incredible sight to see with the amazing mosaics- just astonishing. Get there early- lines can take awhile, but well worth it.

Really fabulous chapel and amazing building. It is a “must see” if you are visiting Palermo. Really quite beautiful and the upper floors of the building are in active use by the Government parliamentarians.
I loved wandering around here. We got the audii guide, which helped. We let the crowds go in front and lingered at the back. Lovely cafes nearby.

The chapel is absolutely awesome. Its a shame some tours occupy the space leaving individual visitors to fight through the crowd and that some visitors think it is ok to take mobile phone calls in the chapel but it is still worth a visit. The gardens are not that special but the
fascinating historic building blending \\\\\\\\\\byzantine, Norman and Arabic sytles. The Palatine Chapel is an exquisitie masterpiece of 12th century art

We spent a couple of hours exploring here and really enjoyed it. Great architecture and stunning Chaple. We paid to enter the Gardens but felt these were nothing special, still didn't take anything away from our visit and we thouroughly enjoyed visiting.

This really is a gem of a building. Not just the chapel that is outstanding and decorated with beautiful mosaics, but the palace with it's variety of rooms all decorated with a variety of great art.

I was on an organised tour with Andante Tours , we had an evening visit to the Cappella Palatina . To see this magnificent & stunning chapel was the highlight of the tour , glittering gold mosaics , inlaid marble floors and a magnificent Arabic style ceiling , absolutely
This is a must . So much history and amazing art. The mosaics are unbelievable. The best we have ever seen . So much history and art .

Go when the crowds are at their smallest otherwise you will have to wait in line for the x-ray machines and the Palatine chapel. We visited on a very wet day at lunchtime midday -14:00 and could stop and look at all the rooms and the chapel. Pick up a leaflet in one of 4
Really impressive building with wonderful square in front. Commands the area! Take the time to circle the entire building. It’s as impressive from the other sides

A spectacular visit of private chapel. The palace is beautiful as well. The chapel has a mixture of different types of architecture. It varies with Greek, Arab and Italian. It is a must see experience.
This chapel was absolutely incredible with the mosaics, gold and more gold everywhere. A sight not to miss. We were disappointed that the apartments were not open to viewing.
Well worth the visit. The chapel was the standout. We went early and beat the crowds which were lining up as we finished.

One of the most wonderful experiences of my life. The Palace itself is tremendously imposing and worth a long visit in its own right; but the Capella Palatina is an experience that no visitor to Palermo should miss. Built for the great Norman king, Roger II, who turned Sicily
You have to visit the chapel with the golden mosaics. The art is unique in the world! The palace had a lot of interesting places to visit (gardens, exhibition etc)

The highlight of the visit was the Capella Palatina which I preferred to Monreale as you are much closer to the mosaics. We got there early to avoid queues and coach parties. Handing back the audio guides was a nightmare! It took a long time to collect them as there was only 1
The rest was a disappointment really. But not the chapel. That was awesome. Spectacular. That alone was worth the money I'd say a definite do.
The grounds, palantine chapel and architecture are impressive examples of Norman design. Certain rooms are only open when the politicians are not in session.

The beautiful chapel covered with mosaics and other decorations on every surface will be a memory of a lifetime. The Royal apartments are also interesting particularly Rogers mosaic room complete with mosaic peacocks and leopards.

Spent an afternoon here as plenty to see. Stunning buildings, with fascinating history and detail. Over a few floors there are stunning buildings, rooms with paintings, furniture, vases all with historical interest. The most stunning Cathedral is also there at the centre of the

Tried to get into this place twice. First time we were late getting there and were told to "come back tomorrow". We did after checking on Trip Advisor to confirm it was open. You can imagine our surprise to find that it was not open due to some sort of unspecified holiday.

Be warned, this place is probably THE highlight of Palermo so expect to queue and don't expect to be alone while you ogle (not the right word but ordinary 'looking' is just not what you will do) the sumptuous sights on display. Every piece of the Chapel is covered in sumptuous

Glorious, beautiful... Breathtaking... Be sure to make time for this stop, including the royal residence and the Chapel. Highly recommend anyone to go there, it's definitely on the list of things you have to see. The Palatine chapel and the palace are high points of our visit in

The Palatine Chapel is one of Palermo's must see sights, breathtaking mosaics you can look at for hours as there is much much detail. We visited on a day when the Royal Apartments were open. I'm glad to have visited the apartments but they are not as memorable as the Chapel.

While the Palace is a fascinating hybrid of styles from the outside, noting prepares you for the concentrated glory that awaits you in the Palatine Chapel. Simply dazzling right up there with Monreale and Ravenna for mosaic lovers.

The Cappella Palatina is a necessary stop for anyone going to Palermo. The Chapel was built under the reign of Ruggero, emperor of the Sicilian Norman Empire. It is one of the most beautiful churches I’ve ever seen in Italy. Tickets 10€ each. The visit will take about an hour if

Very old (if not oldest) royal palace but looks quite comparable to much younger royal palaces in other countries. It is very richly decorated with indeed unique mixture of Byzantine, Norman, and other styles. The garden access is optionally sold and not included in regular

One of the most spectacular places to visit in Palermo. The chapel is beautiful, reach, full of gold but the most important is to realize how much of professional work it required to decorate it. Also wooden ceiling is impressive. Palermo is not full of outstanding places to see

The chapel is the most stunning part of this attraction. Keep your ticket if you are entering the gardens before leaving as you will be approached by a guard and asked to show it. If you are into Dutch art then the gallery is also worthwhile
Only had 24 hours in Palermo - this is a must. The Palatine Chapel is a wonder ! The best we have ever visited. Really a wow factor.
Having read the reviews we wanted to see this but on the day we went the state rooms were shut. No mention of it when we bought our ticket. Disappointed

A guided tour is what you need to appreciate the wonderful church inside the palace. Extraordinaryarchitecture, beautiful decorations, interesting historical background. A jewel you cannot miss. The royal apartments deserve a visit as well.
The most important thing to see in Palermo, together with the Cathedral. Interesting building, many nice rooms inside and a nice garden next.

You know when your wife really wants to see something and you get beaten into submission to tag along, well this is it. The most amusing part was at the entrance where they have Airport style “Security” the lady that was supposed to be watching the screen for the X-ray machine

You pay to visit the royal chambers and chapel, there was also an exhibition of paintings while we were there. Worth the entrance of 12 euros. The palatine chapel is stunning and the exhibition was really interesting

If you want to see a chapel and a garden with trees (no special trees only trees) and it worth 12eur per person don’t skip it, otherwise find yourself a bar at the main road and drink something instead.

We waited in a line for 20 minutes, we bought the full tickets and we saw 2 rooms and a small picture gallery. I expected much more.

It is a beautiful palace and beautiful Chapel Its worth the visit. Nice mosaics. The staff did not seem too friendly though.
The Royal Palace rooms had lots of nice furnishings and the chapel was lovely. The mosaics shine gold in the sun.

Beautiful objects are gathered all around in the norman palace with the apex being the visit of the palatine chapel, which is as beautiful as the Sixtine chapel in Roma or the Sainte-Chapelle in Paris with of course, every one of them being different

The exterior of this place is amazing! However, the interior is quite boring unless you are particularly interested in the Norman rulers and there history in Sicily. However, the chapel is fantastic and worth the price of admission. It is very similar to the Monreale cathedrale
If you like ancient building well your in the "Rome" of Sciliy here in Palermo. This is one of the must see buildings
Worth the trek to see the inside of this well preserved palace. The chapel is of particular note and is a beautiful example of Byzantine Christian art.

Heard about this by chance from another tourist at dinner. Rivals the Cistine chapel , a must see! Doesn't seem like much from outside but the palatine chapel is amazing. Get the audio guide to truly appreciate it!

Truly a lovely place to visit - very popular but not to be missed. The Mosaics were so impressive and the building itself is magnificant being 1000+ years old and steeped in history. Inside the palace we were shown the parliamentary chamber - again very impressive.

I was concerned about the 19 euro for the entrance and audio guide, but it was well worth it. The Palatine Chapel is so much better appreciated with the information provided in the guide...there was an exceptional amount that one would miss without it. Even so, I doubt I

At the moment only the Palatine chapel and art gallery are accessible. The chapel is outstanding and well worth taking your time to look around - incredible mosaics! The art gallery is not particularly well stocked, with a small number of mother and baby pieces.
The state of the Palentine chapel is excellent. The evidence of tolerance with islamic, jewish and christian symbols displayed in the mosaics is impressive.

I’m not one to get too excited by churches, but I was impressed by the palatine chapel in Palermo. Amazing to think how long ago the works were carried out at this site. The tilling is incredible. Not much else to see there, but impressive none the less.

A popular venue for visitors to Palermo. Impressive architecture and gardens if you are interested in Church history.

Another breath taking place to visit, avoid the queues by booking in advance. Be prepared to security check.

The Capella Palatina is one of those special places in the world that must be visited! It is spectacular and cannot be captured in photographs. It is a “must see”.

from the congested piazza, with its mad sounds, its fumes, its people, the street vendors, all of which may make you feel it's just one of those days from your fabulous Indian travel (as so many other places in Sicilia do), you enter the palm-fringed peaceful oasis of the inside

Amazing mosaics, even better than the photos you see in guide books ;-) Worth the wait in line. Remember to keep your ticket for the exit scan!

Not much to see, but a big queue. If you like interiors, this palace has plenty of them and very well kept. Some nice flamming paintings gallery. A light attraction, but you can’t expect more from this town, anyway.

On Piazza Indipendenza we saw a magnifique palazzo, but onl outside, around a rich garden; it was the oldest royal palace of Norman kings in Palermo;

Absolutely spectacular and unique. If it were not for this and Monreale there would be no reason to go to Palermo.

Can be seen relatively closely. Fascinating mixture of styles: Islamic Byzantine western Christian. Good to have a guide to point out special details such as belly dancers in one panel in the ceiling.

The Cappella Palatina and the 2017-2018 exhibit on Sicily were well worth the long lines (50 minute wait) on a Tuesday morning in late October! The gold mosaics are a tourist's dream! Definitely call before you go and ask for someone who speaks English.. A local person told

The Cappella Palatina is an unforgettable wonder room but it is so busy that you can not get to grips with the details of the decoration. It is so overwhelming that you can only glance at a few things and get impressed. The way up to the entrance is long and steep and there is a
Sicily has rich histories since different nations have been here the biggest island in MED. Norman palace is a combination ! There are kinds of ages , and you may know a lot here. Recommended
The place is very big?, and everything is very impressive in terms of work and time spending of doing everything.

The Palace of the Normans is a building that was added to over the centuries starting with the Emir of Palermo in the 800’s. The building is the oldest royal residence in Europe, the home of the rulers of the Kingdom of Sicily and imperial seat of Frederick II and Conrad IV.

The Capella is not large but it is a perfect gem. Norman Byzantine mosaics at their best cover all the walls . It is worth taking a guide book with you which explains some of the images so you get the most out of the visit. The candelabrum is easily overlooked - a wonderful
We paid full price only to find after entry that the whole second floor was closed. Chapel was amazing and art exhibition was great too. Shame about the reduced access.

The chapel is small but beautiful. The mosaics are absolutely stunning with Bible stories depicted around the walls, all made up from tiny pieces of mosaic. The colours are fantastic, especially if you visit on a day when the sun shines on the gold .

This arab-bysantin and naormand architecture is really the top of tis art. I never imagine the quality of the work in Sicilia.

A bit tricky to find the entrance but it was worth the effort. The room with the mosaics was beautiful incredible given the age of the art work. We weren't so taken with the Royal Apartments having seen better over palaces but despite this the mosaics made the visit wothwhile.

I visited this during a week day. There was about 30 minute wait to get in. The church is worth seeing and we also visited the council rooms where the ministerial meetings take place. Please note these are not open to the public on a couple of days during the week so check
If you have only an hour to spend in Palermo, this is the place to go and to be Wow.... Paintings are incredible and details are just amazing It would be a miss not to go there

Best place to pay 7 euros for a chapel consisting of one room. Because of all the fancy security was expecting a lot more and we arrived in a room full of people and nice art. Not saying that it wasn't interesting, only that in our opinion, not worth that much money.
Amazing building with a fabulous chapel covered in mosaics. Very interesting architecture of the Norman Arab type. Also the hall of Herculean where the regional assembly meets.
The chapel is totally breathtaking with mosaics and art. This is a must see when visiting Palermo. The courtyard is very peaceful too .

The Cappella is within the Palazzo, so one ticket covers both. The Capella is a masterpiece of decoration, and the apartments in the Palazzo are as opulent as anything the Romanovs could have imagined. Very Beautiful.

I have travelled a lot, I have seen many churches and chapels but the Cappella Palatina, the idea of the type of ruler Roger II must have been, a visionary who understood the need for ‘union’, left me emotional and close to tears. This is a marvel, beautiful mosaics blending the

The chapel is amazing and not to be missed. The Arabic Muslim influences and artistry are extraordinary. The free bus stopped right at the entrance and returned me to the Theatre Massimo. Hated having to show or stamp my ticket 4 times in the one hour I was there (why?).

It is city centre for tourists. Around here there are many churchs and piazze. It is the start point to explore the city.

The Whole City is a treasure ..don’t miss going there..great markets food and people in sicily are wonderful
This church had a very beautiful and unique usage of small construction pieces making up golden mosaics and decorations, something we did not see elsewhere in europe. Very pretty to walk through.

This is one of the Absolute Must Things to Do in Palermo, probably # 1 ? The Palatina is one of the Worlds most Beautiful Churches of all, you have to see it in person to believe its splendidness. See It !!!

Once we saw Monreal, no other sacred space in Palermo was that special. There is much written about the Capella. Wirth r sting about it to learn how to best appreciate it. Better to see it before you see Monreal.

Absolutely breathtaking to see. Beautiful architecture. Easy to get to via walking if you stay in the middle of Palermo.

It looked really interesting but it had limited areas to explore. I probably wouldn't have gone or paid for the little I got to see.
This is such an amazing place to visit, visiting Palermo and seeing the culture and what it has to offer especially its history!
The palace is a wonderful example of the architecture of the Normans. Embedded in a wonderful garden it is a place to visit and relax.

The main attraction of Palazzo dei Normanni is the chapel but the other rooms if open is also very interesting to see. But the chapel takes your breath away when you step into it. The gold mosaics in the chapel is so over the top that you must just take it in and take your time
The mosaics and frescoes in the Capitoline Chapel are gorgeous. Absolutely sumptuous. We had fun reading the stories from the depictions. It is beautiful.

The combined ticket at 8.50 euros is good value for a visit to this building, but the Byzantine Cappella Palatina is worth 80% of that price. I've never seen so much gold & intricate mosaic in one place.

...then let us see it all. This place was under construction and you only got to see about 25% of place. Seriously, everything was roped off. I understand that updating is needed but don’t charge full price! Also, when construction is happening with loud power drills going

The Capella Palatina is a stunning mixture of Byzantine art, mosaics and gold. beautiful in a building that looks pretty plain on the exterior which is normal in Palermo! recommend you go early and miss the crowds of school kids/tourists to make for a better experience
Mostly closed, its a collection of closed doors, some paintings and very little else. More guards than visitors. Not worth the effort

the only way to see the Cappella is to visit the whole of the palace which is not particularly interesting. However, the Cappella is a real highlight (photos not allowed) and worth the cost of the entrance. Having a guide is worthwhile to get an explanation of all the mosaics.

The royal rooms are only open from Fri to Monday as far as we can tell. We wanted to see the mosaics in La sala di Ruggero. They were worth the entry but the other royal apartments weren't very interesting. La capella Palatina is just wonderful _ the mosaics are truly stunning.

We had to queue for 10 minutes but it was well worth the wait. It is a wonderful example of the Arab-Norman architecture. The mosaics are beautiful.

The Palazzo dei Normanni is a good place to visit. The outside architecture is very impressive and the internal rooms are nice to see. The most spectacular place within the Palace however is the chapel! The mosaics on the walls and altar alone is worth the price of admission.

It was okay, if only the apartment rooms are open. :) But its still a good stop and worth visiting. The chapel mosaic is intricate and amazingly done.
This is the Royal Palace of Palermo. Today it is the seat of the Sicilian Regional Assembly. The building is the oldest royal residence in Europe.

The courtyard is built on three levels with Mediterranean-style colonnades of pillars at each level. Inside there are paintings of the various monarchs, mosaics and extensive Norman architecture. Attached is the Palatine Chapel which has ornate mosaics dominated by the mosaic

The Palatine Chapel is stunning - well worth the admission price on it's own! The programme is the same as that at Monreale but on a smaller scale, therefore it feels more intimate and the lighting and detail are clearer. The ceiling, a rare example of purely Islamic wood

We visited the palace on a Sunday morning and were lucky that we could attend a mass in the Palatian Chapel (thanks to a recommendation from our hotel). One of the most beautiful churches we have ever seen...
The Palatine chapel has some of the most spectacular mosaics in Palermo, a city that seems to specialise in beautiful mosaics.
Really nice visits, it lasts about 1.5 hours. Rooms that you will see are perfect also a small church inside.

We were extremely excited about this site. However, due to some ongoing works, we were told that some of the royal rooms were closed. With more than 80% of the palazzo still to see, we paid full price tickets and entered. However, ONLY the capella palatina (which is sublimely
Surprised no one spoke English or Spanish here. Hardly any books in English either in the bookshop. The mosaics in the chapel are breathtaking. Very busy Saturday a.m.
We got here on a day when you can visit only the chapel. It was like one small very nice church but if you have the time you can see the same thing bigger and for free on Monreale cathedral.

Very impressive from the outside - stunning from within. The dimensions! Mainsight of course the Cappella Palatina - unbelievable. Thanks for allowing only a certain number of people at a time - this way one can move and admire the fabulous mosaics!
By all means visit this spot. It is well worth seeing. The entrance is all the top, away from the square and took us a while to find.

When we first went to visit around 1w noon there was a reasonably long queue so we decided to head up to Monreale first. When we returned at around 4.15 there was no queue at all and still about 1 and a half hours until closing do in we went. Decided to head to the Royal
Don't miss the Palatine Chapel. Having a guide explain the various elements of the Chapel was invaluable to get a sense of the old and New Testament mosaics and the Arab wood carvings on the ceiling.
This was our main reason to visit Palermo and we were not disappointed This is a must see for anyone. Buildings making up Norman Arabic itinerary Exceptional architecture and unique

I recommend going early since there is a wait to get into the Palantine Chapel even after you have purchased your ticket. I recommend paying extra for the audio guide. We spent 45 minutes inside the Chapel gazing upward and around. It truly is a feast for your eyes. What a
Spectacular. The individual artistry is of top quality and the overall design for solemn occasion is perfect I spent about 2 hrs on it Unfortunately the royal apartments were closed

We went on a day the royal apartments were not open. There was basically one room to visit. It was crowded and there was a line to get in. We got the audioguide which was informative but kind of useless at the same time. While I'd have liked to learn more about the history and
a mixture of democracy (Sicilian parlement) and religion with beautiful wall paintings, breath taking!
Worth your time more than the Duomo. Beautiful Norman palace with interesting art and rooms but not overwhelming.

What an absolutely fantastic church- we were there on a day with few tours- (or between bus loads). We enjoyed the mosaics quietly- in relative calm, without a huge crush of people. It is really important to see, and words and photos can't do it justice!
The palazzo opens at 8.15am, go for opening time to avoid the tour groups. We had an amazing 15mins in the chapel where it was just us and no noise. Sublime!
We have seen a lot of the world! The Cappella is outstanding!!! What a beauty!!! Words mean nothing! Go there and decide yourself!! It is worth it!

We went part of a Cosmos Tour. This building structure is stunning and in tip top condition, particularly considering the Normans built this centuries ago. Inside the building is picturesque . This place is a must visit.

The Palatine Chapel has to be seen to be believed and is a testament to how different faiths can co-exist. You really should take a guided tour to fully appreciate it. I can't comment on the Palace as it was temporarily closed.

We went early Sunday which was a good idea as someone had privately reserved the chapel for a wedding and it was closed until later. This gave us ample time to see the State rooms and other areas. Well worth any waiting.
Visited on a guided tour. Amazing. We were also able to visit the second floor and see the parliamentary room and the family rooms.

Not enough of words to express the amazing beauty. Beyond my expectations. Palermo is a definite walking city. I would highly recommend a visit Palazzo dei Normanni. There this great little Gelato stand right outside the from gates. A must try.

With 2500 photos on this site it seemed pointless to me to add more. Only the throng of people in the chapel prevents even better movies & photos being taken. I particularly liked the ceiling, the Islamic inspired lower nave walls and the floor tiles. Of course, the wall mosaics

The Arab Norman churches collectively are indescribable. You have to see the glittering mosaics to understand. To take this trip back in time to the multicultural sophisticated world of King Roger II and his dynasty is something every traveller should experience.
Stunning views of marble mozaics, rich decorations in the capella make it a must-see attraction during your visit of Palermo.

The palace of course was packed with history, amazing mosaics and some great artwork. The queue to get in was quite long and there's no shelter from the hot August sun. Take a hat. But in that delightful Italian way, even at a major attraction like this you can buy an ice cold

Try to go on weekends so you can visit the state rooms as well. The capella Palatina was an amazing site, take your time to admire the artistry and the messages of the makers. Very well stocked bookshop on site as well

Brought a joint ticket for the Palace and the Cappella Palatina. Both were completely stunning. Cappella Palatina was overwhelming, with the mosaics of outstanding quality. Lots of stairs to climb. Couldn't access the courtyard as work restoring this was going on.

Gorgeous palace, wished we could have seen more of it, limit your access to just a few rooms. Took about 45 minutes to view.
Had a lovely morning strolling around the palace. Great place to get interior design ideas. The chandeliers are beautiful

The Cappela Palatina is so phenomenally beautiful and resonant with history that I nearly wept spontaneously upon entering...and I'm Jewish! Palazzo was ok, interesting but secondary. The Capella is not to be missed.
With one ticket we were able to see the Palatine chapel and the Royal palace. Get there early enough and you will not have to wait on line. The chapel is absolutely breathtaking, a must see!
If there's only one thing you can visit in Palermo, don't miss the Palace and the Capella. There is queing for the Capella entry, hence plan at least 2 hours for a rather quick tour.

Cappella Palatina is something you do not want to miss in Palermo, even it is the only thing you'll see, it's well worth the visit. Probably one of the most beautiful church in the world. Do expect some queue in touristic season. 12€ well spent to visit the entire complex
If you are in Palermo that's a must see! Go and visit both, the Palace and the Capella. The tour will take you around 2 hours. We had to queue at the Capella for around 25 minutes.

The palace is first of all chilli in the crazy heat of July which is perfect. Well structured. The chapel is one of the nicest I've seen. Not stroller friendly but we managed to carry it up the stairs. Interesting history.

This was top of my bucket list for Palermo and whilst I enjoyed, it was a little below expectation. The "chapel" is beautiful and remarkable in its design and opulence - although occupies a fairly small space. When we visited the royal apartments were closed and the only other

Relatively interesting Sicilian palace. The Capella is beautiful and worth a visit. The palazzo and royal apartments are good, however I did not feel this was worth the €12 entrance fee. Took around 1 hour to visit, when compared to other Sicilian sights such as Segesta temple
Not too expensive to get in and does cater for English speaking visitors. There can be a bit of a wait to get in but worth it.

The church/ chaple is a must see in Palermo amazing building and beautiful decorations. I had read up about the place and seen programme about it and it lived up to expectations. I did not go in the Royal appartments.
A place to visit during your stay in Palermo. Easy to reach but check the working hours. In Italy everything is very complicated.
Breathtaking work of art. Where the Arabic world meets the Norman version of Byzantine mosaics. Absolutely spectacular. To be visited in conjunction with Monreale cathedral.

I had been told the Capella was on par with the Sistine Chapel, so I was disappointed. Michelangelo did not work here! Having said that, it was nevertheless a beautiful (smallish) chapel with a fascinating history. Dense gold mosaics decorate everything, so the feel is a bit
if you have time for one thing only, go here. the Palace and its Palatina Chapel are a world treasure and a UNESCO word heritage site. blown aay by the beauty of the chapel's mosaics

Price is 12e for person, 8.5e for castle and 3.5 for dungeons. In dungeons don't have noting to see. Time to visit all 1:30h
It's fascinating to see the styles of architecture that the various regions have brought to Palermo. This is a fine example.
Impressive and interesting building. The surrounding garden is well maintained. One of the touristic points in Palermo
Move over Saint Marks... Cistine Chapel chapel pah! World class and the waits and crowding on a Monday were fine

Must see for historical and cultural lovers. Advise to visit Capella-magnificent and breathtaking peace of art.

The building has been maintained very well but the garden needs a lot of care as the grass has died and is overgrown

Obly chappel and an average piazza is possible to village. You don't get to see anything of the inside of the palace. Besides the chapel, which is quite nice, their is a little uninteresting art exhibition. I have no idea why thia place has such a such rating. This was totally

We went went the palace rooms were closed but the chapel was great (one of the several Norman/Arabic chapels/duomos in or near Palermo). Not as overwhelming as Minreale and you get closer to the mosaics. Ignore the complaints about being overpriced - you and we have spent time
A nice surprise: the vucciria of Guttuso was there. Great piece of art. The palace is nice, the "cappella" is great, but not satisfied my expectations.
This is an amazing cathedral, it's free to enter but you can pay to go to the roof tops, it's a must if you visit the area

Entry to Capella 10 Euro. Photography allowed - no flash. What can I say ... Firstly, the day I went only the Cappella was open so I missed out on a visit to the Palace. Next - the entry fee is 10Euro - in my view a tad expensive to view a church. And thirdly - even though I was
This Cappella is well worth a visit. The detail on the walls and ceiling is exquisite. Palermo really doesn't have many "must sees", but this is one of them.
Gorgeous interiors. Mosaics tell a story. Also a great modern Italian art exhibition. Worth the walk up.

Nothing can prepare you for the opulence and sheer beauty of the Palatine Chapel as you enter the building. Just incredible and quite possibly the only thing worth seeing in Palermo - other than the Oratorio di San Lorenzo.

The Norman palace complex is one of the top attractions in Palermo. Actually the palace itself is not so impressive but the small church "Capella Paltina" is really amazing. A rare jewel of medieval mosaic art!
The interior of the chapel is absolutely incredible. The mosaic work is breathtaking. Such craftsmanship. The palazzo is also worth seeing, but is eclipsed in my memory by the chapel.
Having trudged through hundreds of churches and cathedrals, one gets bored. But this one is in the top five in Europe.
The Capella is gorgeous, but rather small compared to the Cathedral of Monreale. The palazzo is nothing special, you can skip it to save on time and money
Great place to visit when in Palermo. When we went, police and military were having some kind of a parade. Close to the main cathedral.

This sumptuous Byzantine chapel was a real treat. The royal apartments were interesting as well so I would advise going on a day when both are open. You may want to go later in the afternoon because it can be busy with tour groups who hold up the line for tickets.
A visit here is a must. The decorations in both the Chapel and the Apartments are jaw dropping to say the least. Take your camera you won't believe your eyes.
Must see place in Palermo. Stunning mosaics from XII century along with those in Ravenna and Constantinople, are the finest in Europe.

We went on a Sunday and, regrettably, we were not able to visit the rooms of the Palace since at 12:30 p.m. they closed the entrance, while we were still waiting (for approximately 30 minutes) in a long queue. Nevertheless, the Palatine Chapel was opened for visitors and we

Apart from the justifiably famous (but quite small) chapel with mosaics, this palace contains a suite of large but not very interesting palace rooms. For some reason security is airport style, and we felt that our 12 Euro entrance fee could have been better spent elsewhere.
The chapel is truly a marvel. The mosaics shimmer amidst light and shadows, and there is beauty everywhere you look.

Il Palazzo dei Normanni (The Norman Palace), lies in the oldest part of the city on the site of a Punic Settlement. Arriving at the palace, the stunning mix-styled architecture of the old cloister will catch you up as you gaze upon it. But the best it yet to come. Hidden within
if it were the only experience (it is not), I would travel to Sicily. Incredible! mosaic, architecture everything is fine.

We went here based on its high Tripadvisor ranking but I don't get it. Ok, it's a nice little church but not as good, in my opinion, as Santa Maria dell'Ammiraglio yet it costs €10 to visit. Sorry but I don't wouldn't recommend visiting at all. Maybe we missed something?
The inner Chappel is absolutely breathtaking and incredibly unique, which makes it worth the hordes of tourists, queues and waiting times. Rich history to the building worth exploring.
We visited in the morning and were dazzled by the mosaics on the walls, floors and ceilings and impressive wooden ceiling carvings as well.

The queue may be a bit long but it's worth it. We didn't visit the royal chambers but the chapel is beautiful. The old mosaic is simply awesome, so do try visit this chapel. If you're on tight budget you can just visit Monreale, also beautiful mosaic and that is free.
Enjoyed our visit to Palazzo dei Normanni. The chapel was quite out of this world. Well worth a visit.

Called in on Sunday morning. Just happened to be a First Holy Communion mass in progress. Couldn't believe the noise the tourists we making. Lots of locals on their mobile phones and texting. Incredulous!
Well worth visiting for the stunning interior of the chapel, but do not go on a Sunday. There are only limited time slots between services and the queues are horrendous!

The Cappella Palatina should be rated one of the 7 wonders of the world. You cannot believe it could have been built/finished sound 1143! Mosaics and wooden ceilings look so fresh and undamaged by age or fire or invasion etc, you cannot get your head around it. Normally any
I loved the Palazzo, but I went on a Sunday, the queues to the Capella were horrendous, but worth every minute I waited

text.wiki:
Saint Olivia of Palermo (Italian: S. Oliva dì Palermo, Sicilian: Uliva di Palermu), Palermo, 448 – Tunis, 10 June 463, is a Christian virgin-martyr who was venerated as a local patron saint of Palermo, Sicily in the Middle Ages, as well as in the Sicilian towns of Monte San Giuliano, Termini Imerese, Alcamo, Pettineo and Cefalù.
Her feast day is on June 10, and she is represented as a young woman with olive branches surrounding her, holding a cross in her right hand.


== Hagiographic sources ==
Saint Olivia seems to have been sanctified
 by popular tradition alone as a pious local saint, since her name was not recorded historically in any mainstream Latin or Greek martyrology or Hagiology of the Church.The oldest textual sources of her Life include a Gallo-siculo Breviary of the twelfth century, which records her memory and is still preserved in Palermo, as well as a document in vulgar Sicilian of the fourteenth century found in Termini Imerese, and a Life contained in a lectionary of the fifteenth century.

A venerable icon of Olivia also exists, perhaps of the twelfth century, which depicts Saint Olivia with saints Elias, Venera and Rosalia.There are also references to a church being dedicated to her in Palermo since AD 1310 on the supposed site of her burial. Today this is the Chiesa di San Francesco di Paola (Church of Saint Francis of Paola).
In addition, numerous Lives of this Saint were published in Sicily, both in prose and in verse, and also in the form of sacred representation until the end of the eighteenth century, reflecting the fair vitality of her cult. She is recorded in the Sicilian martyrology of father Ottavio Gaetani (SJ), as well as in the Palmerian martyrology of father Antonio Mongitore in 1742. A Breviary from Cefalù also contains a detailed entry on her Life (Breviary Cefaludes).The Bollandists published in 1885 the Acts of Saint Olivia, which they took from the lectionary of the Church in Palermo.Moreover, Sicily's most illustrious writer of the 17th century, the poet Petru Fudduni (born Pietro Fullone) wrote a poem in 114 octaves about her, while a dramatic opera of Gioacchino Bona Fardella, a tragedy in three acts, was also famous in its day.


== Hagiographic life ==

According to the hagiographic legend, Olivia was the beautiful daughter of a noble Sicilian family, born around 448 AD. Local hagiographers state that she was born in the Loggia district of Palermo. From her early years she devoted herself to the Lord while declining honors and riches, and loved to give charity to the poor. In 454 AD Genseric, king of the Vandals, conquered Sicily and occupied Palermo, martyring many Christians. When she was thirteen Olivia began to comfort the prisoners and urged the Christians to remain steadfast in their faith. The Vandals were impressed by the strength of her spirit, seeing that nothing could prevail against her faith, and so in deference to her noble house, they sent her to Tunis where the governor would attempt to overcome her constancy.
In Tunis Olivia worked miracles and began to convert the pagans. The governor therefore ordered that she be relegated to a lonely place as a hermitess, where there were wild animals, hoping that the beasts would devour her or that she would die of hunger. However the wild animals lived peacefully around her. One day some men from Tunis who were hunting found her, and impressed by her beauty tried to abuse her; but Olivia converted them too with the word of the Lord and they were baptized. After miraculously curing many of the sick and suffering in the region, Olivia converted many pagans to the Christian faith. When the governor heard about these things he had her arrested and imprisoned in the city in an attempt to make her apostatize. She was scourged and she was stripped and submerged into a cauldron of boiling oil, but these tortures did not cause her any harm, nor did they make her renounce her faith. Finally she was beheaded on June 10 of the year 463, and her soul "flew to the sky in the form of a dove" (Italian: "sotto forma di colomba volò al cielo").


== Veneration ==


=== Patron saint of Palermo ===
At the end of 1500 her cult was spread by the Franciscans, who sought her body.On June 5, 1606 the people and Senate of Palermo elected Saint Olivia as Patroness of the city, together with Saint Agatha, Saint Christina and Saint Nympha. These four patronesses were chosen for each of the four major parts of the city. Their commemoration was entered in the Palermian Calendar by Cardinal Giannettino Doria in 1611.Their veneration waned following the discovery in 1624 of the (alleged) relics of Saint Rosalia, who had appeared to rescue the city from the plague. Thereafter Saint Rosalia began to be venerated as a patroness of the city as well.In 1940 a parish was dedicated to Saint Olivia in the city.Her commemoration as patron saint continued to be celebrated by the Church in Palermo until 1980 as a mandatory commemoration. However, in 1981 it was officially removed from the local Liturgical Calendar.In Tunis, the Roman Catholic Cathedral of St. Vincent de Paul and Saint Olivia is also dedicated to her. It was begun in 1893, replacing the oldest Christian monument in the city (a chapel built Father Jean Le Vacher in 1650), and was opened on Christmas of 1897.


=== Saint Olivia and Islam in Tunisia ===

The Great Mosque of Al-Zaytuna ("Mosque of Olive") is the oldest in the Capital of Tunisia and covers an area of 5,000 square metres (1.2 acres) with nine entrances. Its exact building date varies according to the sources. Ibn Khaldun and Al-Bakri wrote that it was built in 116 Hijri (731 AD) by Obeid-Allah Ibn Al-Habhab. However, Ahmed in Abu Diyaf and Ibn Abi Dinar attributed its foundation to Hasan ibn al-Nu'man, who led the conquest of Tunis and Carthage. Most scholars agree that the closest date is 84 Hijri (703 AD), and what Al-Habhab did was in fact enlarge the mosque and improve its architecture.One legend states that it was called "Mosque of Olive" because it was built on an ancient place of worship where there was an olive. However the most accepted explanation is that transmitted by the 17th century Tunisian historian Ibn Abi Dinar, who spoke about the presence of the tomb of Santa Olivia at that location. Recent research has shown that indeed this mosque was built on a Christian basilica. With the advent of Islam, the church was converted into a mosque, retaining the dedication, but translating the name into Arabic.
The saint is particularly venerated in Tunisia because it is superstitiously thought that if the site and its memory are profaned then a misfortune will happen; this includes a belief that when her relics are recovered Islam will end. This ancillary legend related to the discovery of the saint's relics is widespread in Sicily, however it is connected to other Saints as well.In 1402 king Martin I of Sicily requested the return of Saint Olivia's relics from the Berber Caliph of Ifriqiya Abu Faris Abd al-Aziz II, who refused him. Even today the Tunisians, who still venerate her, believe that the dominion of their religion will fade when the body of the Virgin Olivia will disappear.


== Historicity ==
The main criticism of the life of Saint Olivia is that the elements of her legend do not have a personal nature in and of themselves, but they all derive, with slight modifications, from old themes or archetypes that were dear to the medieval imagination, such as that of the  'sacred heroine'  or the  'persecuted maiden' . The Italian teacher and writer Giuseppe Agnello carefully undertook to sift the hagiographic tradition from the literary one, and did not see anything more than a random homonymous saint of Palermo conflated with the heroine of the mystery play dedicated to her, which was studied extensively by Alessandro d'Ancona and Alexander Veselovsky (who in turn cited Ferdinand Wolf).Nevertheless, Msgr. Paul Collura defends Saint Olivia's historicity writing that "the core of our ancient legends has a substrate that should not be underestimated, and since the Arab domination in Sicily (827–1092) made a clean sweep of all the written documents, sacred and profane, the memory of several Saints has been handed down only on the thread of memory."Furthermore, it has been accurately pointed out that the Roman Catholic church has remained somewhat aloof from Southern Italian saint cults.


== Notes ==


== References ==


== Sources ==
(in Italian) Sant' Oliva di Palermo Vergine e martire. SANTI, BEATI E TESTIMONI. 10 giugno. Retrieved: February 2, 2015.
(in Italian) Daniele Ronco (2001). Il Maggio di Santa Oliva: Origine Della Forma, Sviluppo Della Tradizione. ETS, Pisa University, IT. 325 pp.
(in Latin) "ACTA SANCTAE OLIVAE." In: ANALECTA BOLLANDIANA. Tomus IV. Edidreunt: Carolus de Smedt, Gulielmus Van Hooff et Josephus de Backer (S.J.). Geneve: Societe Generale de Librairie Catholique, 1885. pp. 5–9.


== Further reading ==
(in Italian) Giuseppe Agnello. La S. Oliva di Palermo nella leggenda popolare e nella tradizione letteraria. In: Archivio storico siciliano, n.s., VII (1955), p. 109.
(in Italian) Giuseppe Agnello. La S. Oliva di Palermo nella storia e nelle vicende del culto. In: Archivio storico siciliano, n.s., VIII (1956), pp. 151–193.
(in Italian) Giuseppe Agnello. "Tradizioni agiografiche e alterazioni leggendarie." In: Saggi Li Gotti [37], I, 24–35.
(in Italian) Igor Gelarda. Persecuzioni religiose dei Vandali in Sicilia.  In: Historia: Zeitschrift für Alte Geschichte, Bd. 59, H. 2 (2010), pp. 239–251.
(in French) Halkin, François. "La passion grecque des saintes Libye, Eutropie et Léonis martyres à Nisibe". In: Analecta Bollandiana. Paris [u.a.]: Soc. des Bollandistes, Bd. 76 (1958), S. 293–316.
Matthew Bunson and Margaret Bunson. Our Sunday Visitor's Encyclopedia of Saints. Second Edition. Our Sunday Visitor, 2014. p. 626. ISBN 978-1612787169
