Stunningly beautiful ,the view from the roof is breathtaking although there are a lot of stairs to climb
You have to pay to go to the upper area to walk around the outside. Great interior. Not many signs to read to describe what you are looking at. No guide book that we could find.

Compared to the many other ecclesiastical treasures in Palermo, the interior of the Cattedrale is unremarkable but at least it is entirely free and if you are observant, you will discover a nice set of servizi in one of the side chapels. However, unless you are fixated on 2nd
You can tour the cathedral on your own for free and the extras to the treasury and the roof are worth the few Euros. Read up on the cathedral before hand so that what you’re seeing makes sense.
One of the most beautiful cathedrals I’ve ever seen. Amazing architecture. A must if you are in Palermo.

Really beautiful building & grounds, a must see when in Palermo. You must visit the little juice stand opposite the building too- ask for a Sicilian spritz...you won’t be disappointed! Sit there and enjoy the view!

Much more impressive on outside than inside, but inside quite nice. Be sure to see side altar on right for silver altar honoring patron saint of Palermo. On left side info on priest murdered by mafia and on his way to sainthood.

This was a bit of let down after some of the stunning churches we had been to and way more pricey. We paid for the full package and got to go to the top to view the city which was nice, see the treasures and the crypt.
Worth a visit, beautiful building. There are regular mass so to have a walk around best to go out side those times

If you visit one Cathedral then I would suggest this one. It was close to our hotel and we were able to walk here. Lots of history surrounding this Cathedral. You should expect to spend 30 minutes here.
Well worth the visit!!!!! Visited the treasures of the palace and they were fantastic, Totally loved the city and all surrounding area. I reccomened you go if in Palermo!!!!!

It is a very beautiful cathedral where you can find a lot of history : tombs of royalty and not only. When you get inside if you are not dressed properly you can get an one use cover for 1€. Tour busses arrive constantly and it’s always very crowded, you can enjoy the greatness
This is a large and impressive cathedral. Though the art is not the most impressive in Palermo, it is still a beautiful church and well worth the time to visit.

This is a classic example of a cathedral style church because of its impressive outside beauty and the simplicity inside. The church is not really the best and it’s pretty basic for the standards of Palermo’s churches.

Visited from the outside, i wore shorts so was not allowed in. The prettiest building in Palermo. Huge historic significance as an example of multicultural architecture, showing Muslim and Christian influences.
Built in different styles over many eras, the cathedral is a very interesting place to visit. Does not leave the same impact as the Cappella Palatina, but still not to be missed if in Palermo.
This is a must see when visiting Palermo. The Cathedral is amazing and its surrounding piazza is as well.
Approach this via a monumental archway for best effect. Usual grandiosity but surrounded by pleasant cafes.

We only looked from the outside. After many comments, we passed on paying for the interior view. Instead, we walked around and enjoyed the magnificent architecture and style. The area around this landmark have many places to get food or drinks or snacks to relax and take in
The cthedral is very big and impressive with ornaments and statues. Before you enter it the yard is also large and fantastic. recommended
Good place to spend a hour or so. Church is free but you can visit other parts by buying a ticket. Lovely altar paintings.

Please note that shoulders must be covered to enter. They sell covers for €1 I believe. We purchased a package to go to the tower and see the crypt for €10 per person. They took credit cards. There was much more to see than we expected. It was amazing. We first went a room on

This cathedral has an interesting mix of styles, both inside and out. Definitely worth a look round the exterior. A guide is useful to get the most from the side chapels and the history. Free to enter but one euro if you are not dressed modestly for a papery overdress for the

I visited here when they had a service on, and it was packed, but fantastic. Also I went another time when I could walk around and it is huge inside. You can also pay a little and walk around the roof top of the Cathedrale, with great views of Palermo.

Free entry into this beautiful church. Stunning architecture reflecting the different powers that ruled in Palermo throughout its history. Persian Roman Norman influences. Dress codes apply make sure you bring a scarf to cover your shoulders if you are wearing a sleeveless top.
This is a must visit. It is a impressive building that is worth the visit. Going with children is easy.
One of the most beautiful buildings and courtyards in Europe. Well worth the visit even if you're not all the regious
What an amazing building. Walked all round it and admired it from all sides as well as the beautiful garden.. Wonderful, wonderful, wonderful. Do take time to go in, I am sure it is beautiful.
Like most cathedrals, this one is beautiful and free. We made sure to bring a guide that day because it really made a difference.

Magnifecent Byzantin Church. Is a must if you are in Palermo. Incredible well kept. GREAT!! I was there almost 3 hours. . The Dinasty of the Roggero's were very advanced. The amazing thing for the of 1100. AC. were so advanced that had 4 laguages that were accepted. Greek, Arab,

If you want to climb up to the roof top and enjoy the views, they charge up to 10 euros. Otherwise it’s free to visit the church and well worth your time. Be mindful, no short shorts or bare shoulders. Cover up or you won’t get in. Worse, they may you buy and where a god-awful

We visited last week. It wasn't great. The main cathedral itself is big and not much else and is free to enter, but it has the option to buy tickets together or separately to the royal tombs, crypt, treasury and roof. We did the lot for 10 Euros. When we bought the ticket it

We found Palermo Cathedral during a one day stopover in Palermo as our ship was docked in the port here. We had opted to explore the city on foot and had prepared our own agenda with points of interest to visit. Passing along the Via Vittorio Emanuele we picked up a map with a

The church is free to enter but there is a ticket to access the royal tombs, treasury, crypt and the roof. We didn't purchase a ticket an only visited the main cathedral itself which was so full of history and interesting to visit. There is also the tomb of a priest who was a
I love old town that is why I love Palermo a lot. Don’t miss to visit Cathedral Di Paletmo. I am not a Budhist ,but I love this sacred place a lot.
The interior of the cathedral isn't something interested.The view from the roof is the best.The crypt has many jewels of the Palermo's history.

We saw the main interior and the roof walkway. Amazing views from the roof. I m not amazing with heights but I was ok because the walkway was not near a ledge, more so in the centre of the roof with handrails, was worth it.

A super nice cathedral in the historic centre of Palermo. The cathedral sits inside spacious grounds with plenty of places to sit and enjoy a break from walking around. This was my favourite spot in Palermo. It's near other sights and the adjacent street has a lot of touristy
Cattedrale di Palermo is beautiful. Definitely a place to visit in Palermo. The view from the top is spectacular.

Outstanding Cathedral with layers of different culture influence. The chapels inside are “ store in store” type for a church and loaded with beautiful art of all types. The facades are a masterpiece and you don’t get tired of admiring. We visited only the free admission portion

We went with our group and our time was limited-it would have been nice to spend more time especially on the roof with the stunning panoramic views. There is an extra charge to see the artifacts and the crypts. If you have the time, spend the time to see this.
This is a huge and beautiful cathedral, especially the exterior. There is so much detail and so much to look at. We went back at night and it looked very pretty lit up.
Touring this cathedral is a must. The size and buaty alone is worth the trip and the history is a bonus.
Worth time to stop for a short visit. It opens at 8.30am and not many tourists are up yet, at least in June.

A must see when in Palermo, the exterior of this cathedral is one of a kind, all the different architectural styles that have created this gem have been harmoniously combined together during the centuries and left something that you cannot see anywhere else thanks to the many

What a beautiful building, both externally and internally. We were on a street food and historical tour and we arrived just in time to see the sun dial cross the meridian line. Make certain that you see this on your visit.

Lovely building and interior. We didn’t pay to visit the rooftop but worth going to see the inside. There was a lack of information boards in English to educate visitors about each area but there was one about a priest Giuseppe Puglisi who was murdered by the Mafia.
Right in the centre. Loved the statues around it and the roof and crypt. Loved the Norman influence and not just Italian Renaissance architecture
It’s a MUST in Palermo! Well located and close to the Capo district with its amazing street market and delicious street food! It’s a journey into the authenticity of this unique Sicilian capital!
Go see this! A must for your Palermo trip.. And go up and out on the roof.. stunning vistas .. take a walk through the pedestrian area and sample the street food..

Lucky to arrive as a service was starting on Pentecostal. We stayed to experience the service which was lovely, beautiful singing in an amazing building. Recommend a visit and paying to see the priceless artefacts and cript.

A must of course, but the ewhole church was unfortunately ruined in Baroque times, so little remains of the grand Cathedral of Walter of the Mill. The only reason to go it to see the fantastic tombs of thre Norman Kings and the German Emperors.

I’m running out of expletives to describe all of these churches and castles and the artwork we’re seeing through Italy. The cathedral is just another fine example of the importance of the church in early Italian times. See it when you’re there.
A beautiful Cathedral to visit, the views from the top are amazing, as are the underground Crypts. The interior is amazing with the different altars and enclaves to see!
One of my favorite attractions in Palermo, this cathedral is a masterpiece because of the architectural stiles. I recommend you to book a tour and visit the top because the city view is breathtaking.
Palermo's cathedral is amazing...no words to describe it. No matter the weather, in the sun or on a rainy day it is simply amazing! You can't stop staring at it!

You can spend a small fortune paying for the entry fees to Palermo’s churches which seems to be the (irritating) norm here. But the cathedral is majestic even from a distance, especially around dusk. We walked around the premises (which you can enter for free), but most of our
This cathedral blends many styles, and the result is pretty over the top. The inside is immense and gorgeous. On the outside it looks a bit like sandcastles we all made on the beach as kids.
Great example of Ancient Architecture. Beautifull cathedral, well kept. People like to climb the stairs and get the best city views.
We visited the cathedral and were so impressed buy it. Truly worth the visit. It's really spectacular

This building is awesome. We went up to the roof (100 ish spiral steps) but well worth the effort for the view which is stunning. The architecture is fantastic and the inside is breathtaking. Even if you are not religious you cannot help but be overwhelmed with the atmosphere.

Wow. Not only is it one of the most beautiful cathedrals that I’ve ever seen, but the €8 ticket to see everything is totally worth it. The roof alone provides unmatched views for the city and its surroundings, and also makes for some lovely photos. The crypt is breathtaking,
Nice exterior. Dull interior. Like much of the city it could do with a good clean and made attractive.
Lovely decorative stonework. Roof visit quite good for views over Palermo. Interior had some interesting features too.

I’ve seen a lot of churches and cathedral so this one is OK on the list of what I’ve seen in my travels nothing spectacular however it is very large. You’re in the location you might as well walk through it and visit can’t hurt.
#1 place to visit whilst in Palermo! Architecture from a bygone age!! Norman style that is definitely worth research! Side chapels rival the Vatican! An oasis in a busy city!!

The cathedral is really worth visiting, its square/garden is also beautiful so it is great to have there a short break, too. I highly recommend to go on the roof for only a couple of Euros and enjoy Palermo from above.

A visit to this Cathedral is important when you pair it with the other Norman gem, Monreale to compare. The two Cathedrals were very much in competition with each other. There is no admission cost to enter the church, but a fee is charged to visit the crypts below and to climb
Spectacular. What can I say, the architecture is fantastic. Lovely clean grounds and surroundings. Well worth a visit

This is a beautiful cathedral to visit, stunning to photograph and free to enter. Inside doesn't disappoint and is as sumptuous as any in Italy. There is access to the roof for the brave at heart with the expected stunning views of the city. Set in it's own gardens in the centre

The cathedral of Palermo is a famous landmark. It is free of charge to visit the interior and only a few Euros to go on the rooftop for some nice views. Must see and it takes approx 1h to enjoy it all. Don’t pay to see the crypt and treasury, not worth the money.
The cathedral is an impressiv building. Inside is not so exiting but the view from the roof is worth the 5 EUR. Also lighted in the evening it looks really good.
From outside and inside one of the most impressive monument. You can also walk on the roof for 5 Euro per Person.
Probably the most interesting landmark in Palermo. You should spend some time at the outside too, maybe even more impressive than from the inside.

Like many regions of the south-western Mediterranean, Palermo and Sicily have been on the receiving end of frequent invasions and take-overs. The Cathedral is a classic example of a site with a varied history, as it was originally an early Christian basilica, and then under

Impressive church in the center of town. What makes the architecture so interesting is that it was started in 1185 and after various additions, finished in the eighteenth century. Entrance fee can be up to €10, but on Sunday’s one can only walk on the roof for €5. Impressive
Amazing structure - huge, delicate and beautiful. Impressive to look at and see all the structural changes made over centuries. The outside is much more beautiful than the inside of the cathedral.

The cattedrale is definetly the top site in Palermo. The exterior when viewed for the first time is breathtaking but comparing to Rome, Florence, Venice or Milan it is nothing much to mention. It is large and dramatic but not beautiful nor noteworthy on any count. it is just

The Cathedral of Palermo is one of the few monuments to visit during a short stay in Palermo. In the purest Arab-Norman style, the building dates from the twelfth century, as a whole, while the nave was later reworked during the Baroque period.
We are always delighted by these grand cathedrals. A real testament to the faith of the people who contributed to building these wonderful structures.

I believe this is one of the most important sites not to miss in Palermo! The cathedral is immense and well preserved. You can pay a couple of euros for an extended tour and the possibility to go on the dome of the cathedral. Recommended
A unique example of Norman-Arab architecture, a world heritage sight with every reason. The outside is far more interesting than the inside. Don't miss it!
Loved walking around inside and out. Nicely maintained building , unfortunately missed the tour as we arrived too late - would have liked to do this!
Amazing place BUT nothing compared to the Monreale's one. Trust me: visit this cathedral than run to Monreale. Also Cefalù's one is nothing compared to Monreale's one. Go to Monreale! Clear enough?
Nice Cattedrale and is definitely worth to visit. When we were there a big group of tourists just entered, so we stayed just for ten minutes. They also provide some walking tours on the roof.
Beautiful Cathedral. The outside when you first see it is a wow. Inside is impressive but not the most in this town.
Interesting and beautiful. Looks a lot bigger from the outside than when you get inside. Some great ceilings and altars.

Beautiful Cathedral that you have to visit.. Standing also from the outside. Beautiful view from the roof but you have to pay 5€ to go and if you want to visit the tresury and tomps 3€ more euros needed!
Beautiful cathedral, very interesting. Contains the grave of the priest assassinated by the mafia. Over the road enjoyed a freshly squeezed pomegranate juice.

Palermo is home to many very beautiful churches. This Roman Catholic cathedral-church, Palermo Cathedral, is the largest and most magnificent. The exterior is very ornate and the interior even more magnificent. Parts of the present day cathedral were built in the 12th, 14th,

The Cathedral is free to enter and it is surrounded by lovely grounds. There are several architectural styles and the exterior was perhaps even more beautiful than the interior (not as spectacular as the Cappella Palatina or the Duomo in Monreale). We did not pay to walk up to

The Palermo Cathedral is a mixture of several architectural styles, and so was fascinating to visit, I'm sorry we didn't have time to go up to the roof. The tomb of a priest executed by the Mafia in 1993 is also located in the cathedral - a reminder of the Mafia violence that

This cathedral looks amazing from outside, amazing architecture and a beautiful entrance. The inside of the cathedral didn’t blow me away(we visited so many cathedrals along our journeys that we became a bit picky) but impressive as all the mighty cathedrals. But the rooftop is

Maybe it is the most important and biggest historical structure in thr city. The building was built by differebt emperors so each added some new parts. Thats why the cathedral has different architectural contexts in one. Worth to visit and you can go top of cathedral to watch
It is a top 3 on the list of places to see here. The beauty and history is beyond anything I’ve ever seen. It’s truly not to be missed. Go during a service but please be respectful. Gorgeous!
Lovely cathedral set in lovely gardens, roof top walks are available, very historic and crypts inside too. Very reasonably priced too .

Eondercul Spanish inspired cathederal built on and out of former mosque there is an inscription from.the Koran on one of pillars. The ornate silver on show makes you think of the exploitation of South America by the Spanish Newer tombs are to those who stood up against the
Beautiful cathedral especially on the outside. You can go up and walk on the roof where you get a lovely view.

This is one of the top 50 cathedrals of Europe. If you haven't seen your fill, or enjoy church and history, certainly visit. The price is essentially free to view the building with a very reasonable 3 euros for a inside look at rarely seen extensive underground crypts and church

The cattedrale di Palermo is one the historic sites in Palermo that can not be missed. It is a nice building that offers different options in the form of tours. Particularly I think it is a bit overpriced and, despite being nice inside it is nothing special when compared to
The cathedral is huge and a landmark. Do not forget to buy tickets (think Euro 5 per person) which grant access to the rooftop. Amazing view. The insides are ok.
The cathedrale itself is a must see but for 5euros go on the top to get an overview of Palerme and the mountains around !!

The Norman cathedral was built on the site of a Muslim mosque in the 12th century to rival the cathedral at Monreale. The external architecture is stunning and it is worth walking all the way round rather than just viewing it from the gardens in front. Having visited some of the

I loved the outside of the cathedral. The big square in front of the side entrance gives you a wonderful view. The inside however is rather plain, and you can easily drop entering (and paying) without messing much.
It's a beautiful cathedral, although not as interesting inside as some others. We went in the evening, and the exterior was breathtaking with the lighting from the sunset.

In this Monumental Cathedral where several kings were crowned, it has in its interior the Chapel with the relics of Santa Rosalia and the beautiful lapizlazuli chapel of the Santisimo Sacramento and on the floor of the central nave are the signs of the zodiac. Do not miss seeing

The place is very nice. You can take a tour on the roof, wich is great. Thats about 5 euro per adult. You can also try a tour in the crypt. I don't really know how much that costs. I think they have a website with their prices. Still, the roof view is restricted. You can't walk

We have been to a few different cathedrals in Europe so we wanted to visit this one also. Very beautiful inside. You can take the roof tour for 5 euros, but since we are on the top floor of a condo with a very large veiw of the city, we opted out. However, there we tons of

This is such a beautiful Cattedrale. Beautiful design on the walls and a wonderful nativity. We did the roof tour and you walk up many steps to the top of the roof and the views are amazing! It’s a must see.
Full of different architectural styles Norman, Arab, great history and a little atmosphere including tomb of Frederick II a must visit in Palermo
This cathedrale is really impressive! From outside looks more like a palace, but inside has the peace of a temple.
Even if you have had a lot of visits to cathedrals do not miss this one. It is hige, impressive and full of history

A must see when visiting Palermo. The inside of the cathedral but for sure the walk up the roof to see the panoramic view over the city. The cathedral is the outcome of a mixture of different roman, Norman, gothic, arabic and baroc architecture.

The cathedral is one of the first things to do when you visit Palermo! The exterior is very impressive and it is influenced by Arabs,Spanish and Byzantines who consequently has occupied Palermo in the past. Inside it looks like a typical renaissance architecture and it has

The architecture of the place is outstanding and the garden beautiful. However, the price to visit this place is too high related to what it offers. There isn't even a caffe where you can sit and relax.
Amazing mix of cultures in only one place , too much history and the inside of the church we’ll conserved
Free and easy to tour on your own. Very little in English descriptions. There are parts that there is an additional fee but we did not participate in that area
The Cattedrale di Palermo is a must when visiting Sicily. the square is perfect for meditation and a short break from walking.
We bought the 8 euro tour which included the rooftop, the treasures, the crypt snd the catacombs. An amazing cathederal, but my favourity part was the rooftop and the view. Never found the catacombs.
Very unusual and stunning silver altar, domed ceilings with extravagant frescoes. One side chapel holds a series of ancient crypts. Very worthwhile stop.

Beautiful exterior, but don’t expect the same feeling of amazement when you enter because the interior has a neo-classical design. If you want to see breath-taking interior art, go to Monreale Cathedral, which is the opposite of Palermo Cathedral.
Visited today. It is very beautiful inside with a lot of treasures. To enter the cathedral is free but they charge for everything, the treasury, going to the roof.

Nice from outside despite critical carping about the dome (which doesn't truly fit but what in Palermo is of one era ?). Tombs + crypt interesting. Cathedral interior less so. An hour without roof. Maybe one to 2 with. Treasury artefacts interesting but limited. A few star
A must when you visit Palermo. Try to circle the area and see from different ankles and views, there are several hints of this spot.

I fell in love with the exterior of the Palermo cathedral. Could have stared at it for hours. The interior is also nice. We climbed up to the roof and the dome. Keep in mind that the steps are rather high and somehow difficult to climb up and you might also feel pressure to
What a building! Not to be missed while on a visit to palermo. Truly magnificent. We visited in October, so there weren’t too many tourists.
A must see in Palermo. The pillars, mosaics, paintings, the building's magnificence by it self......
I found the exterior very interesting but the interior bizarrely soulless I guess fair when you consider it's been rebuilt so many times. A great place to shelter from the rain

We visited this ornate cathedral only for the short time that our Globus tour allowed. So much history here that it was hard to take it all in! The tomb of Blessed Giuseppe Puglisi is located in one of the side chapels. This priest was martyred by the Mafia 20 years ago for

Not the best cathedral I've ever been to but not the worst by any means. We went to the roof up narrow stone stairs. Don't go up if you are claustrophobic. It's either all the way up in one go or not at all. No escape. The view is ok but I've seen better roof views. The

Unsurprisingly given the look of this building outside, this cathedral started out as a mosque. Some of the towers are original from the 11th century, and it always fascinates me when buildings are that old. Inside, the cathedral is quite tame in terms of decoration. You can buy
What a view. The facade and the gardens of this baroque, Norman cathedral is breathtaking. The interiors are less impressing, but once in Palermo you cannot miss it
This cathedral is beautiful inside and out. It is in a great part of the town and very popular with shops and restaurants nearby.
I loved the beautiful Cattedrale. I wish had more time to complete the tower and roof tour. Simply stunning.
Really enjoyed the cathedral, part of the major attraction in Palermo. Take time and have a good look around. The roof tour is amazing.

We visited the cathedral yesterday and found it to be well worth the effort and price. The main cathedral is beautiful and free of charge. The is an 8€ charge for access to the rooftop, treasury, tombs and crypt. However, on the day of our visit only the tombs and rooftop were
What an amazing place! Don't forget to take the roof tour, very steep winding steps, but well worth the effort! Fabulous views inside and of course from the roof!
Beautiful architecture but not much inside ! Worth a visit and good views from top of the cathedral.

Interesting cathedral - got up to roof - saw the tombs and treasury etc. Enjoyed the visit but visitor info is very patchy, no guide pamphlets appeared available - occasional signs in English but hit or miss. Not cheap Go because you should but don’t necessarily pay for the

This was a nice cathedral but there was so many beautiful churches in this city. Crypt was interesting but had to pay extra for this. Roof visit has 120 steep steps and is only about 13 meters long so is full of visitors.this is open only every 30 min. Pay just left of entrance.

The best thing about this cathedral is the walk around the outside. Views are wonderful, architecture is superb. Inside - well, it’s OK but compared with the building is relatively modern. Look out for the toilets! The door is hidden in a chapel behind a monumental marble altar!
Very nice cathedral in the middle of a pedestrian area. Nice front garden. You can go upstairs and have a wonderful view of Palermo roofs. More spectacular is inside rather than outside.

While it has a very pretty exterior the interior and alter are nothing spectacular. Since it is free to visit it was worth entering simply to check it out. It was a great way to get out of the rain for 30 minutes.

As I said in the title the Cathedral is amazing in the outside but is nothing special in the inside. So I suggeste the visitors to come visit because it is a very important place for Palermo but don't aspect anything special in the inside. No parking places anywhere close.

Visited the Cathedral which is free to enter and walk around. If you want to climb to the roof of the Cathedral there is a small charge €6 there are quite a few stairs in a winding turret with a hand rail...we chose to go at the back of the group so we could go up at our own
I have been to many Cathedrals over the years. They are all pretty much the same. We read the information from our guide book and didn't bother with the audio. Good view from the roof.

We met our guide here for a half day walking tour. It was a great place to start as there was space for us to sit while she went over the basics of a very complicated history. There were lots of places around the cathedral where she could illustrate a point she was making. And
A wonderful place great architecture with some stunning statues on a bright sunny day in sat outside here admiring the view and the busy town centre behind you
Do not waste time waiting in coffee shop to be served. Waitress was ignorant unfriendly and dismissive. Left after 15 minutes 😞

This large cathedral has had many additions over the centuries which explains the different styles of architecture. Because of Sunday Mass, we could only tour part of the church but what we saw was beautiful. Would love to go back and complete the tour.

The outside of the cathedral is amazing - and worth looking at it from all sides as the end view (from the right-hand end as you look at the front - is also magnificent. Inside, the cathedral is surprisingly simple, but still fantastic.
The building is a real mish mash of styles built up over the centuries but inside you could be in any 17th or 18th century church. We did not stay long
I just agree with all that everything that’s been said already. Very narrow staircase but well worth the climb.
As it was closed on the date of our visit, we could not go inside. However, even seeing the cathedral from outside is wonderful.

We visited the Cathedral a day after the Pope left Palermo so there was a lot of excitement around the area. A visit to the roof is a must just for the view, also the architecture. Also visit the Tombs and Treasury.

Loved it. Beautiful cathedral, crypts downstairs are interesting, the view from the roof is fantastic! Pay the €8 and you won’t regret it. It’s a narrow staircase up, but it is so lovely. You are given a time to go up, so no mad rush or long wait (we only had to wait 20mins
much plainer than expected (with the exception of the silver alter) but go up on the roof and look at the views - they are stunning - you can also do this at night with the Gregorian chants

The cathedral is far more impressive from the outside than from the inside but it is still worth going inside if only to find the most original place for a lavatory in any church I have encountered...namely behind one of the smaller altars/chapels. Very good if one has to go and
A grand beautiful Cathedral but nothing to separate it from many of the others.I found the Baroque churches in the town center more unusual and interesting.
Fabulous and impressive building that dominates the area and provides a great photographic opportunity.

A must when visiting Palermo this historic city has a lot to see. The Cattedrale de Palermo is one of them.. Expected to spend many hours here and take many pictures. The building is so photogenic and full of statues inside one out.. If feeling adventurous for a few euro’s a

The Cathedral opened its doors at night during the summer. Good view from the roof area but the security fight give you much standing time to really savour the views - everyone just really marched up had a quick look and had to keep the queue moving. Plus the information

We only purchased the ticket for the view from the roof of the cathedral. The interior of the cathedral and the catacombs are also supposed to be lovely but we did not have enough time. Think realistically about the 110 spiral steps climb. Each step is 12 to 14 inches tall. They
This was the first important historical building we saw in Palermo, so a good encounter. We did not take the tour, but admired the architecture and the courtyard.
We walked by here and absolutely loved it. It dates back to the 18th century. Worth the walk to come see it.
Fantastic architecture and consider the age of the building. Powerful modern sculpture in the front puts the bishops in their place
Wonderful cathedral Delighted to have been there Incrediblely hot day Bring water Lovely place really worth seeing

Review only for the roof. You have to pay a few euros (3-5€) to visit the roof of the cathedral for 30-45 minutes. You get a nice view over the rooftops of Palermo and the surrounding landscape. Maybe you have to wait if there is another group on the roof.

I happened to walk past this and found the exterior to be very nice for a stop and photos. You do have to contend with the poor street dogs and teens sitting around playing music. I didn’t go in so no comment there.
This is a large and decorated cathedral which are all over Italy and Europe for that matter. Worth the time to see it but it does get crowded and the roof tour and crypt cost extra.
The dominating building of the wonderful city of Palermo, an extraordinary fusion of Moorish, Norman and Christian architecture. If you visit the city, you can’t and shouldn’t miss it. Unforgettable.
Just like most Sicily towns the main Cathedral are a site to see. This applies here. Surrounding building are worth the visit to see. And on main shopping tourist street.
Really nice building, as we are lovers of history, we have visit this place. My hubby even paid the fee to go on the roof.
Well worth the entrance fee. The roof view is stunning. Be prepared to walk up several flights of a winding staircase. The crypt and the treasure room are also well worth seeing.
Fantastic energy feeling place .Do not miss the chance to take a tour on the roof . this is spectacular !
The silverworks in the front of the church are magnificent. The exterior facade is very detailed and beautiful.
A must visit site in Palermo full of amazing and historical relics. Full of tourists too, so visit early or later in the day.

We simply did the roof top tour of the cathedral which was one of various charges tours you can do of the cathedral. You can for instance do a tour of the crypts but you see a video of it whilst you are waiting and it didn’t seem worth it! The views from the top are really

The cathedral is an impressive and very old building in central Palermo. Make sure you do a tour to the roof, which gives panoramic views over the city, and also go down to the crypt to view the very old coffins (dated 1100's to 1500's). Definitely worth a visit if you have time

As we approached the Cathedral it was stunning Norman building, but less interesting on the interior. Free admission but worth paying the extra to climb the steps to the roof and walk the length of it.
Wonderful cathedral, impressive architecture inside and outside,full of history , not to be missed. One of the most visited sites in Palermo.

This lovely Catherdral is a hive of activity as the community attends services and conducts weddings here. Pay the extra fee and visit the tidy and historic crypt. We were the only visitors in the crypt and climbing to the top and across the buttress for a great view of the

Palermo doesn't disappoint the architecture is stunning and so was the Cathedral. We had passed by a few times and not stopped due to queues. Need to make sure shoulders and knees are covered to be respectful Visited on a quieter day and found the Cathedral was beautiful with

Catholic Cathedral of Palermo, dedicated to the blessed Virgin Mary. Made of a number of different styles due to extensions through the ages. Dating back to the 12th century it was founded by Pope Gregory. It contains sacred vestments, jewellery and artefacts from the past
Begun by the Normans and built over several hundred years, this cathedral is impressive inside and out. There are layers of design, including Arab elements, but it somehow all works together.

Sicily's heritage is reflected across the outside of this great cathedral, from the Norman architecture to remaining Arab writings on several columns in the main entrance, and to the Spanish Baroque dome. The interior is comparatively unadorned vs. other churches in Palermo

Beautiful cathedral with many features. We bought the 8 euro ticket to climb to the roof, see the crypt and view the treasury artifacts which were all worth seeing. The climb to the roof is up a narrow winding staircase so if you're not fit, suffer from vertigo or claustrophobia

Having maybe visited the Norman Palatine Chapel in Palermo and the Norman Cathedral at Monreale, you probably expect to walk into the Norman Cathedral and see the same amazing covering of every square inch of surface with decoration in a mainly Byzantine style. Well, this
A really amazing place of worship, the building is large and well maintained. You pay extra for a tour of the roof and the crypts.

The Cathedral of Palermo mixes Arab and Norman architecture and it really works. The exterior is beautiful and the inside is awesome. The silver chapel to the patron saint of Palermo is drop dead gorgeous. This is a MUST see. Free admission.

There are so many churches and cathedral but this one is very beautiful even from the outside. Very picturesque. The cathedral itself is free to enter and sit there looking onto its altar. The walk round had various little niches with all sorts of picture's there is also a

Well worth a visit if you are in Palermo (we walked there from our cruise ship). The outside is very impressive and you can go into the main part for free. Out of respect you need to cover your shoulders. I took a little cardigan with me in my hand bag – but I noticed that
The exterior of the cathedral is spectacular and not to be missed. The interior is rather disappointing especially after the splendor of Monreale and Palatine Chapel

The exterior of the cathedral is well worth exploring -- it is a romanesque mastepiece. The later interior is to my taste disappointing, but the tombs of the Norman kings are a remarkable sight not to be missed

Thy have a dress code in the summer. The man in charge of the door only applies it to non Italians. Try any type of reasoning and he’ll just be rude and mean to you. The option they give you to go inside if he decides you can’t is buying a 1€ piece of cloth...

A very impressive sight, large open area in front of cathedral always plenty of photo opportunities. Gets very busy on Sundays, watched a wedding. Nice bars at the side entrance for beer and ice-cream.
There is lots to gawk at - both from the exterior and interior. But do not miss the terrace upstairs, from which you will get fantastic views of the city.
Amazing stories to this church, tour guide of Palermo would be good Wonderful little piazza outside Worth visiting very near shopping precinct, wear comfortable shoes and take plenty of photos
The cathedral is rated now as a place number 20 to visit in Palermo, which is probably underestimation since it has unique architecture, history, easy parking nearby, tour to the roof, etc.
One of must sees in Palermo. Looks great from the outside. Interior though is not spectacular. Taking roof tour makes sense.
Stunning building absolutely worth going see and the little roads surrounding are great to walk down and see the small shops

Exterior of the cathedral is very fascinating. It has a big garden and square in front of it. It is extremely long but not that furnished interiors. Its brick walls are like art pieces. I liked it very much. And strongly recommend anyone who visits Palermo.

The roofs of this beautiful building are occasionally opened to the public , I recommend a visit if you are in town when they are opened. Stairs up are a little tight obviously but not too bad , I am not comfortable with small spaces and heights but i could handle it fine. The
Nothing special, the roof is very narrow and the views are not spectacular as you can only see the centre
We were completely in awe of this amazing Cathedral in the centre of Palermo. This is a place that visitors must see when in the city to appreciate the rich history of Palermo.

The outside of the Cathedral is beautiful, the layout of the area and the fact that it is so well maintained make it all the more special. We visited the Cathedral around mid-day and it was obvious that they were preparing for a wedding. This enhanced the excitement of our
Wow well worth the walk. Breath taking views. Great building filled with history and venerable facts. A spectacle on Palermo. Just an amazing place to visit.
In the historical center of Palermo: this Norman cathedral is a must see attraction. Nice garden around and some stone bench to rest.

Buy the ticket for the roof only as the royal tombs are not worth it. The view from the rooftop is great though. There are many steps to climb and only small groups are allowed to go up at a time. The outside is beautiful though the inside somewhat disappointing.
Interesting cathedral - a shame we did not get to see the Norman tombs but the rest was fascinating. A good hour to spend.

Unusual inside - a mix of different architecture! 8 euros allows you onto the roof, into the crypt and morselium. Not that big, but well worth the money. The main church is free to visit - need to dress appropriately, if not cover ups are sold for a euro.
If you do have the displeasure of coming to Palermo, then the only nice thing you can visit is this. It's beautiful.

Me and my partner visited the beautiful Cathedral. We took the open roof tour. Sadly, I agreed my shorts were too short for the dress code and purchased a 1 euro cover up. However, it soon became clear that others had not followed this rule - in fact over 75 percent of people.
Visited in May..our air bnb apartment was directly opposite this magnificent cathedral. Very beautiful inside..worth paying for the visit to the royal tombs, and the rooftop walk.

Not much to see on the inside, but a stunning building....make sure you walk all the way round to spot the Byzantine influences...and perhaps pay your 5 euros to climb to the top for some great views!
Free tickes to visit the church. It looks amazing outside and inside. One of the most beautiful churches in the world.

There are thousands of churches in Palermo - and they can't all be fascinating, but the architecture of this one is interesting. However the interior is disappointing. Leaving aside the Royal tombs, and the silver altar to Sante Rosaria, there is little else to see. It's
Really worth a visit! Superb architecture and most unusual. We loved it and highly recommended it to all.
The architecture outside is so nice but when you visit inside the cathedral it’s not very very beautiful as outside. Worth a visit!

This stunning cathedral is free to go into, unless you want to climb up the dome to see the view of the city. It is a beautiful cathedral, containing many treasures of enamels, jewellery, sculptures and engravings. When walking by, you just have to pop in. As with most places

The most beautiful cathedral ever seen. You really can feel Sicilian people’s faith (at least what remained) Bring a long trouser or a skirt. No visible knees and shoulders allowed at the cathedral but at least it’s free to visit.

We did not go to the roof but still thought both the building and the interior were above average and should be a mandatory visit if in Palermo. Its close to all the markets, the Palentine chappel and the Quattro Canti

Free entry, though if you’re wearing short shorts or a vest top, you may well be charged a euro for a wrap. Cathedral is fairly large, and definitely worth a visit. The catacombs & roof are charged for. We didn’t do these, it think it was about €7 per person.

This huge cathedral was erected in 1185 and after many restorations and additions has many different architectural styles: Norman, Moorish, Gothic, Baroque and Neoclassical. Many kings and nobles were buried here. Entry is free of charge.
This place embodies the history of Palemro and Sicily in general. Best part is the view from the dome.
We went into the cathedral not knowing what to expect. It is beautiful and well worth a visit if you decide to pay for a trip up on the roof. The view over Palermo from the roof is spectacular.

Nice place to take a break towards the top of the tourist route. Seating was available to rest your feet and take the sights in, before you go on the roof walk! The only place we had beggars in Palermo - actually inside.

The cathedral is a top attraction in Palermo, but mainly for it's spectacular medieval exterior in the unique Arab-Norman style of this part of Sicily. The interior has been remade to look like most of the grand papal basilicas in Rome and have lost all of its medieval feeling.
The place really worth seeing. Don't forget to go to the top of it to the dome. The view over Palermo is absolutely gorgeous and unforgettable. Beata
Well worth a visit...an excellent building with impressive sculptures and other works of art. It is on a local bus route so easily accessed. You can also explore the high roof areas.
Visited for the first time. What a gem. A true and absolute MUST to see place while in Sicily. Beautiful altars towers and scenery that you would expect from a high tier church.

A beautiful cathedral full of history. The architecture is stunning and the inside reminded me of Baroque churches in England. It's definitely worth spending the 7€ to visit the roof to get panoramic views of the city, as well as the crypt and treasury.

Impressive 12th century church. Free entry to the main building but it will cost you quite abit if you want to access the more interesting areas including the roof. Worth a look if you aren't yet totally over churches.
This is one of the places you have to visit during your stay in Palermo. Check the working hours before you go there
Beautiful, impressive- one of the few places which city of Palermo is taking care of. To see the inside you need to cover your knees and shoulders!

The piazza around this cathedral gives you great views of the architecture. The high spot (excuse the pun) is the rooftop walk which gives you spectacular views of Palermo and the surrounding countryside.
A wonderful exterior and square, a great place to admire, the interior is quite plain compared to Dome Monreale but then again many places would be.

Not much to see on the inside of this cathedral, especially if you have already been to Palatine Chapel and Monreale. The outside is very impressive however. The cathedral is free to enter but you can pay extra to climb the exterior roof and see some of the people buried here

The visit of the cathedral in Palermo was the highlight of our visit. The architecture is breathtaking and one can spend a lot of time there, just absorbing the atmosphere. It is possible to go up to the roof, which we slipped, because it was simply too hot.

We payed 7 Euro to visit the roof (which has set times during the day approx. Every 30 mins or so) has a great view of the city and you could see the cool coloured tiles on the roof... it was hot up there so take a hat. The 7 Euro also included the treasure room and the crypt

Amazing history and architecture. Make sure that you visit the museum after you have seen the Cathedral. Plan on at least 3 hours there. Stay away from the restaurants surrounding the Cathedral as they are all tourist ripoff places with dubious food. If you walk just 5-10

The Cathedral is a must see sight I Palermo. The splendour of the age when it was built is in full view here for all to witness. On entering to your left is the ticket office, Once you have your ticket you move into the waiting area for the roof tour. Here while waiting you will
Brilliant external architecture and stunning internal details but the busiest spot in Palermo. There are quiet areas for contemplation as well as an amazing organ. Worth braving the crowds.
The walk on the roof is the best thing here. Inside the cathedral is good for sheltering from the heat. The exterior is impressive.
Beautiful palace well worth seeing, glorious gardens also, quite a relaxed atmosphere, Would certainly recommend a visit.
The exterior is more impressive than the interior. The exterior is also lit beautifully at night. We had no issues or concerns in walking the streets in the vicinity of the cathedral at night.

The interior was nice but nothing to write home about. The exterior, however, was a site to behold. The various architectural influences apparent were truly fascinating to look at. You can also get tickets to go up tot he roof.

One cannot visit Palermo without visiting this beautiful cathedral, its huge! The grounds and interior are well kept and worth a tour around. Yhey have lovely rosaries you can have blessed and keepsakes. I bought one with lovely small roses which she prays to every day. Enjoy
Incredible Cathedral with amazing architecture!! Great felling while inside. Located at an area with some good cafes

The architecture on the outside is amazing. The best way to take all in, is to walk around the cathedral. The inside is totally different to that of the Vatican. It is all white and completely clinical inside. If you love cathedrals, it is well worth a visit.
Amazing view from the outside, wouldnt recommend going inside, there is not much to see inside......

This is best seen by walking the whole way round outside and appreciating the Normal architecture. Inside nothing is left, just lifeless later makeovers. You can enter for free but the "specials" are not worth it. The treasury is a sorry affair - the Constanza crown is poorly

A true gem .. such a mixture of architecture is a delight to see under one roof . A visit at night is recommended where you have the choice to have a walk round the roof tops amist bell towers and coupolas..
This is a beautiful cathedral externally and you get fantastic views from the roof (beware spiral steps with not always a handrail) but internally it is rather austere. Didn't go to the tombs.
This is a must to visit, fantastic example of construction. You can visit right up to the top, on the roof, and from there you can see all the city of Palermo and take some stunning photos!
From the main hall to the crypt and the roof, this was a personal favourite of mine on our trip and well worth the time and money invested into seeing it all!
Go with stairs aside, up on the roof - what a magnificent view to the whole city! Visiting it on Saturday may enable you to witness wedding too.
It is worth to visit. I always love big old churches. I recommend everybody to go inside for at least 15 minutes.

Beautiful cathedral and plaza with an atmospheric crypt full or tombs we (sadly!) found so interesting we spent a quarter hour reading the inscriptions. Upstairs it was perfect, after hearing about Roger everywhere, to see his tomb, only €2 for this and the crypt/treasures.
Go early to avoid bus loads of tourists - interesting to compare with other Cathedrals in Sicily - went to 3 and this one rates as number 2.
If you love history and looking at beautiful churches it's a place to go. It was a wonderful time. Worth the time to visit.
Very majestic and I was in awe. The walk there is through some questionable areas and when you turn a corner and come upon the Cathedral it is an amazing site.

We just came back from a 10 day vacation in Sicily. While in Palermo we visit the beautiful cathedral twice. It is a great work of art that requires several hours to see properly. You can take a tour or you can visit on your own. You can climb the tower whic gives you a

Cattedrale di Palermo is a huge and stunning building. You should not miss this place during your stay in Palermo. It is beautiful from outside. Inside is not as amazing as outside, but still fine. You can pay to climb the dome, but the scene is not so impressive. You can visit

This is a very impressive looking building on the outside and large inside. It is not as elaborate inside as the one at Montreale just up the mountain outside Palermo. It is worth a visit as it is one of the grand buildings in Palermo.

We approached the cathedral from the back and found it quite stunning with a very moorish appearance. Inside the building is less remarkable but does have a couple of lovely chapels. From the front the exterior is even better.
After travelling for a while, cathedrals start to get a little boring. Palermo’s cathedrals are typical examples of that era and worth a visit while your walking the city.

Here's why you go to Palermo..This amazing cathedral is almost overwhelming in its size and unique Arab-Norman architecture. The current church began construction in 1185, but it was really built on ruins of an earlier church which was turned into a mosque by the Saracens in the
Grand exterior, with a lovely plaza in front. Nothing special inside. Very popular with tourists visiting Palermo.
Very serene setting stunning stained glass one of the most beautiful cathedrals I’ve seen my 17 year old granddaughter who does not do churches was very impressed
We had an ok view from the rooftop. Nothing special but not to bad really. Wasn't overly impressed inside as religion isn't my thing. But the architecture of the structure is amazing to see.
Simply amazing! The architecture detail of the building is just amazing. We didn’t go to the top of the roof but I am sure the View must be incredible.

The paintings on the dome ceiling draw a deeper look. The right-hand alcove has two marble relief sculptures and an ornate altar all in silver. This is the cathedral’s gem. No fee to simply walk through. The treasures and the catacombs are extra, but we did not stay for these.
View from the rooftop is amazing and it was worth climbing. Besides that, it's nice example of combination of different architecture styles. Worth of visiting.
What's interesting here is the adaptation of the earlier architectural motifs..the EXTERIOR more interesting than inside!

Our first glimpse of the cathedral was from a small back street from Teatro Massimo which gives on to the incredible view of the back of the church (ie behind the nave). Not many people walk round there from the front square but it’s definitely worth it! The main entrance is
It very nice castle and church in best part if Palermo,very big building with so many great places around.
The catacombs were fascinating. The walk across the Cathedral roof provided incredible views of Palermo. The Cathedral itself is a nice place to sit and contemplate.

An absolute gem of a cathedral with some of the most beautiful artwork and intricate sculptures hidden inside. Worth a visit and worth going on the tour to see the great views of the city from the roof top.
A stunning church, but the best bit is the 100 steps climb to the roof. Well worth it, amazing panorama views over the whole of Palermo.
If you come from the outskirts of Palermo through the narrow alleys with 90% immigrants you suddenly see this absolute amazing building showing the contrast between now and then. A definite must see!
Among Italy's many churches, Palermo Cathedral isn't among the top ranking few, yet it is a very attractive building that taps into Norman, Arab, Gothic and various other styles

We found it disappointing, probably expected too much but we've visited a few over the years. Very little info in anything other than Italian, no option for audio devices offered so difficult to understand any of the significance of the items

Do whatever you like, but be sure to visit the Palermo cathedral. Too large, too rich to describe in few words, it must be one of the most beautiful churches in the world. You can also take a walk on its top, to enjoy breathtaking views of the city.

The cathedral is a rather unexpected building, different to what you have seen in other places and this is true for the inside and outside. Do not forget to have a look at the back facade which has very special decorations.

Another awesome cathedral but this one is unique in its architectural cultural values of a mix of norman, moorish, gothic, baroque, neoclassical influences. Outstanding and well worth “another church visit”. Don’t let this one pass.
The cathedral is beautiful. It needs some restoration to be done but it’s a piece of art and culture. Worth a visit.

Worthy places to see is the Cathedral Palermo which is a combination of the best of the Norman and Arab architectural styles and which houses the tombs of different Norman kings and Emperor Frederick II
The best 5 euros spent in Palermo! The access ticket on the rooftop. The stairs are rather challenging, but the view is just breathtaking!!! Loved it!
It's a huge cathedral combined with styles of architectures which shows the history of Sicily , like Norman , Arabic , gothic , baroque, classic and so on. It's the first place to go in Palermo.
This is one of the famous symbols of the city, a big and impressive building inside and outside, with lot of details.

Pretty impressive from the outside but, in my view, slightly less so inside. Biased, possibly, I cannot help but feel that the cathedrals and churches of southern Europe, devoted as they are to their purely spiritual role with their fabulous decoration, lack the historical
The appearance of the cattedrale looks amazing. It’s appears huge from the outside and small from the inside.
Worth a visit, notice that the toilets are located behind one of the altars! Charming and interesting cathedral, although all the tourists obviously thought the same.. very crowded.

The Palermo Cathedral was begun in the 12th century but not finished until the 18th! That makes the architecture kind of a mishmash. You enter through the stunning 16th century portico. It is free. The interior is decorated in the Baroque style. One of the most interesting

Extraordinarily . Well done . Many points of interest. Beautiful. We spent nearly an hour in the cathedral. Rich history . Recommended it to others on the trip. I would say ..a must see when in Palermo.
Free to enter and do the basics awesome architecture and scenery , they need to find a way to let people’s self tours , she they don’t
Built near 900 years ago, in perfect condition it 's one of the best cathedral in Europe I think. Discover how three cultures can co-habited pacifically
This Cathedral glows in the sun, it's just beautiful and unique, a must see in the city, the gardens and the atmosphere outside are fabulous

We were lucky enough that this building, when light up at night, was the view from our bedroom window. The building is enormous and a fitting size for a town like Palermo. It is monumental size and design. Interesting history and structual differences to other Italian Churches.
Massive cathedral beautiful artwork we walked in in the middle of mass Music was beautiful do not know what else to add it’s a cathedral
A place to visit and enjoy the beauty Must spend 30mn on this area and try to figure out how long it took to do this marvel

This cathedral is spectacular inside and out and well worth a visit. It is beautifully maintained- I am not knowleagable about architecture but am able to appreciate the amazingness of how such places were designed and built so long ago,
The cathedral is beautiful and the place is crowded by relaxed people sitting around talking, listening to music etc.
A huge building with a plainer interior than most of the baroque churches in Palermo. It also has an amazing silver altar to santa Rosalia. The external architecture is a wonderful time behold.
Look the timetable! If you want to go on the roof of the cathedral , you have to be there before 13:00h
Definitely worth seeing both outside as inside. Great architecture and atmosphere. Unique combination of european and arabic architecture.
Historical and beautiful cathedral. This is a must see when visiting Palermo. Wonderful outside gardens.
Honestly, dissapointed. Looks much better from the outside, and the history is interesting but that is really it. There are other much nicer churches in Palermo.

It's easy to get a bit blasé with all the superb religious art and architecture in Sicily. I was particularly impressed by the cathedral's crypt, which contained a number of stone caskets (sarcophagi?). These objects were of various ages, and with various degrees of

Having visited the Palatine Chapel and Chiesa Della Martorana I was disappointed with the Cathedral. It is a lovely building but nothing special compared to the two mentioned above. Unfortunately the day we visited it was 'raining' according to the surly ticket attendant so no

We visited on a Sunday afternoon but it was closed so check opening times before you visit. There are lots of tours available, bookable inside. We chose the roof tour 5 euros, and when you eventually climb to the top (quite arduous if your not very fit) you are rewarded with

Amazing from the outside. Incredible representation of architecture from 1170 AD. It is a wonder, the pride and workmanship never ceases to impress me here. Inside, the standout is the exquisite use of silver and artwork throughout the cathedral. The blend of Arabic and Norman

Another truly remarkable landmark in Palermo. The interior is massive and amazing . The area on your left has beautiful sanctuary of the Virgin Mary all in Siver . Unforgettable . We spent almost an hour here , Free admittance.

On a excursion from our ship we visited Palermo cathedral which is in the centre of Palermo. It is a majestic imposing building. The outside is very decorative and is rich in history . The interior is entirely Neoclassical in style and has a splendid high altar. Well worth a
Lovely place with a great history. You can feel the atmosphere when you go inside the building. Advice to plan a visit here if you have got the chance
Palermo Cathedral is the cathedral church of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Palermo, located in Palermo, Sicily, southern Italy. It is dedicated to the Assumption of the Virgin Mary.
We paid 5 euros to climb up to the roof. Yes the views are lovely but there's only a small area to walk around and your view is obscured by other people quite a lot. You only get 30 minutes up there.
It is the most famous historical monumental of Palermo. You must to walk around of the building, inside of the building and on the topof the building. It is wonderfu l.

The ticket costs 11 euros and the tour is great! The king's church is beautiful and show the arabic-roman influences in Sicily. The rooms are also beautiful and you can see the Sicily Parlament debate room. Worth the time and money.
You can see it from far away. The outlook is great and huge. Inside is simple than I expected. But the museum have a lot of things to see.

The cathedral is a chimera of architecture, shown off beautifully against the backdrop blue sky with the sun shining on it throughout the day. It is worth studying the norman towers, catalan porch, cupolas and turrets. Yet the whole structure works. Less interesting inside

The cathedral is beautiful! The alters are gorgeous. The silver one is the most beautiful I have ever seen. Pictures don't do it justice. The climb to the top was well worth it to see the view of the city.
Beautiful architecture and had a very nice miniature replica in the church. The silver statue was impressive.
Unbelieveably beautiful. Both the architecture and artwork on the inside and outside were fantastic. Like everything in Palermo, just gorgeous.
Make sure you spend time outside looking at the design. That is really the highlight of this church.
This is a great spot in the Capital. Rich in historical and archeological characters, a mix of Norman’-Bizantin style. Don’t miss the walk on the roof and the great panoramic view on the city
Stayed at an air bnb that overlook this amazing building. Could have done without the bells from 6am but hey that’s what a church does.
The exterior of the cathedral is vast, it is worthwhile sitting peacefully outside and looking at the various statues. It is only 5 Euros to walk along the roof top and take in views of the city.
Wonderfully decorated cathedral with a mixture of architectural styles - extra fee to visit side chapel, but worth it. Combine with a visit to the Diocesan Museum next door.

This cathedral has a myriad of different styles and is a truly fascinating building. Originally constructed in 1185 on the instruction of Pope Gregory I, the church has seen many uses including a mosque and a crypt. Inside, a prominent feature is the treasure chamber that
You can spend so much time here, just enjoying the scenery and what it has to offer, have a caffe across the road with a cannolo, there is so much history in Palermo a just to enjoy!
I always the UNESCO sites, and found this cathedral an interesting mix of different architecture. Visit the bathroom behind one of the side alters!!!

The Palermo Cathedral was built in 1185. It is dedicated to the Assumption of the Blessed Virgin Mary. It is an amazing architectural structure because of the different styles used when additions, alterations and restorations occurred in the 18th century. A must see when you
This is an interesting building with beautiful mosaics.it is worth going up on the roof but the steps are quite steep and there are 85 of them. Worth the climb, though.
A wonderful monument of ancient Sicily. A must see is a treasury with a medieval crown and a crypt from the VII century. Free to enter.

Cattedrale di Palermo is a beautiful cathedral in Palermo that rivals any church in mainland Italy, beautiful exterior with an interior to match. You must see it in the day time and then come back after sunset to realize it beauty. Take your time exploring the interior of the
It is beautiful and worth visiting if you go to Palermo. It is part of the old city that is closed for the traffic.
The building was really nice and huge, but was quite nothing inside. There are several more beautiful churches in the city, e.g. Santa Caterina d'Alessandria.
What to say... whenever you are, morning or evening, it looks amazing! We were there there during a wedding ceremony.. another great experience! A must see!
I was quite unimpressed with the ancient monuments of Italy and Sicily. The Cathedrals, which remain in use, were miracles unto themselves. And this one is one of the best.

This is a massive structure, and it has been fully restored on the outside. A combination of the architecture from the many ruling cultures, it is a marvel. Climbing the long spiral staircase to the roof was a treat. We could see the many structures sitting on the top of the
A very beautiful building both inside and out with a lovely garden. The cathedral is well worth a visit.

This is a very nice cathedral well located in the centre of Palermo. Typical catholic decoration to ceilings and walls. The service we went too lacked any real singing and was more readings. Not used to catholic services so maybe this is the norm. We paid extra for the tour, but

This is a beautiful cathedral dating to the time of the Normans in their typical style although many renovations were done later making it a mish match of architectural styles especially in the interior. Access to the main cathedral is FREE though if you want to ascend to the

If you're a history lover it's the right place for you. Arab norman Palermo is full of attractions like this one. Great and fascinating from the outside, with a beautiful square, a little disappointing inside. Been there twice. Don't miss a chance to see it while in Palermo.

You can tell the influences of the various inhabitants of Sicily just by examining the architecture of the cathedral. From the Norman towers to the Catalan porch and the muslim influence on the mosaics. An impressive structure. Worth a short visit

The modern interior contrasts sharply with the astonishing facade. There are some stunning Arab-Norman tombs, a wonderful treasury and beautiful shrines. A particular favourite of mine was the modern pulpit.

The size of the cathedral hits you first as it’s it large hight and width also because it’s eclectic it comprises of differing architectural styles as it was renovated and completed in different centuries. The cathedral also put in me in mind of the cathedral in Seville. It’s
Its a cathedral, you seen one you've seem em all. This one is pretty good as they go, so I suggest it is a must see
So worth a visit to experience its medieval to the 18th century exterior. You can purchase one of the best cannoli over the road then sit in the garden and mesmerise over this beautiful Cathedral
Fabulous and impressive, on a grand scale. Much to see here. Compare this with the Royale Palatine Chapel for 2 different realizations of the importance of these religious monuments.

I wandered past this building while walking around Palermo. I have to say I didn't go inside, I was happy just to look at the facade. The location is lovely and easy to find. The building is well worth seeing. I also spent my lunch break sitting next to it, very peaceful and

The plazza in front of the cathedral is quite pleasant and relaxing, the cathedral façade as well, since it is an aggregate of many styles. But the interior is cold and uninteresting compared to other churches in Palermo
The cattedrale is a must see. The ornate interior displays a sense of pride in workmanship. The columns tell a story
Interesting architecture and mosaics. Tombs of various priests inside, along with one that was killed by the mafia in 1993.

The cathedral is very big, and architectural styles is different. This is point of attraction. You could find bizantin style, moors or baroque. Very nice portico in front of entrance. Inside for me the best was the wooden roof, nice sculptured. You cant miss the Palermo

Beautiful cathedral highlights the variety of cultural influences over the years. A must see in Palermo.

Amazing architecture and very beautiful inside. We happened to visit during mass and it was a very lovely experience.
Huge structure with two distinct parts. Was rebuilt inside in typical late XVIII century style, not interesting .
Beautiful and ornate cathedral, definitely worth a visit! We didn’t buy tickets to see other parts but enjoyed the main cathedral and square outside very much.

The Cathedral in Palermo is definitely worth a visit. The architecture is amazing. The steeples and facade are breathtaking and the interior very impressive. You can take a tour to the crypts below as well as the rooftops for spectacular views of the city.

You have to see this Cathedral if you’re in Palermo, no questions asked. Yes, it’s beautiful, but when you go up to the roof (100 steps) it’s a spectacular view of the city. The 7 euros cost per person includes the tresurary and the crypt . This is one of the reasons you came to

Great to see the toombs in the Crypt and the Church. But remember: in Italy women have to wear a long skirt / pants and shoulders covered to go in churches! The rooftopwalk offers a great view over the city.
Worth it. The view is amazing, cheaper than climbing Teatro Massimo (20Euro). You can have the view 360 degrees of Palermo Town, crossing the mountains and the sea.

Confession: I am not a church or cathedral kind of guy, but go there to see the culture at the time it was built. You should go to this one. If you are a cathedral person, like old tombs, mosaics, etc. no doubt you'll appreciate it more than I.
One not to be missed! Great piazza and garden to browse before entering. Free entry to main Cathedral but small charges to visit Dome, roof and vault. Numerous street cafes nearby.

Very beautiful gardens, lovely sorroundings, many people, pretty architecture. It was in the heart of Palermo, easy to reach.

Buy the ticket to the roof and you can see the Palermo. A recommended first day activity. Steep stairs though, so not recommended for the elder or people with weak knees.
Monreale and Cattedrale is a must see. if you are in Palermo, do not miss this. just steps from quatro canti.
The church, complete with its lapis lazuli altar and one in solid silver, is the most stunning and visually beautiful church you can imagine. A must see.

This was a beautiful place to see. Music played outside the cathedale. There are zoomed coffee shops in the area also. Great athmosphere in this part of palermo. The cathedral is spectactular.

After spending 5 days in Rome, we were surprised to find such stunning churches in Palermo. Such ignorance on our part. This is a world heritage site, for very good reason. Wonderful architecture; a blend of several styles and cultures. You must see!

I find it difficult to 'rate' and review any church or cathedral, because they're really not there for anything other than their raison d'être - to be a place of worship. In that respect, this cathedral fulfils its role perfectly. The external appearance has a strong influence

Perfect, must see while you are in Palermo. Also treasure room and combs, we didn't go to roof because it was close due to rain.

Due to a long history of additions this beautiful Cathedral has a complex architecture; its huge and fascinating at first glance, from a distance. It made me feel tiny and insignificant when I stepped inside; its height and dimension was really exciting for my eyes and mind!
Interesting place. The roof walk gives a good view over the city. Very impressive art works adorning the interior.
This is a remarkable site in Palermo. Unique and extremely elegant. The cathedral is large and has pretty grounds in front of the main arcaded entrance.

text.wiki:
The Praetorian Fountain (Italian: Fontana Pretoria) is a monumental fountain of Palermo. It is located in the heart of the historic centre and represents the most important landmark of Piazza Pretoria. The fountain was built by Francesco Camilliani in the city of Florence in 1554, but was transferred in Palermo in 1574.


== History ==


=== Florentine origin ===
The fountain was created for the garden of don Luigi de Toledo in Florence. Previously the land of the garden had belonged to the nuns of San Domenico al Maglio and was obtained, after a lot of pressure, in 1551. Subsequently, in 1584, the Palazzo di San Clemente was built on this site. The creation of this unusual garden (devoid of palaces) and of the fountain was commissioned to the Florentine sculptor Francesco Camilliani, student of Baccio Bandinelli.The work was started in 1554. The fountain included 48 statues and was surrounded by a long arbor formed by 90 columns of wood designed by Bartolomeo Ammannati. Giorgio Vasari called the fountain: «fonte stupendissima che non ha pari in Fiorenza nè forse in Italia» («wonderful-est fountain, that is unparalleled in Florence and maybe in all Italy»).


=== Relocation to Palermo ===

In 1573 the indebted Luigi de Toledo (brother of the former Viceroy of Sicily García de Toledo), on the verge of moving to Naples, sold the fountain to the city of Palermo. In fact, the Senate of Palermo decided to buy the building e to place it in the square in front of the Palazzo Pretorio.
On 26 May 1574 the fountain arrived in Palermo. In order to transport it, the fountain was disassembled in 644 pieces. Then, in order to make room for the fountain, several buildings were demolished. However, the fountain arrived incompleted in Palermo. Some sculptures were damaged during the transport, others were maybe kept by Luigi de Toledo (probably the statues of two Divinities preserved in the Bargello Museum of Florence and other statues placed in Naples and then in the garden of Abadia, in the Spanish city of Cáceres).
Therefore, in Palermo some adjustment were necessary. The work of assembling was made by Camillo Camilliani, son of Francesco Camilliani. In 1581 he completed the work with the help of Michelangelo Naccherino.
Between 18th century and 19th century, the fountain was considered a sort of depiction of the corrupt municipality of Palermo.  For this reason and because of the nudity of the statues, the square became known as "Piazza della Vergogna" (Square of Shame).
In 1998 the restoration of the fountain started. It was completed in 2003.


== Description ==
The fountain represents the Twelve Olympians, other mythological figures, animals and the rivers of Palermo. 


== Curiosity ==
In 1973, Italian National Postal Service dedicated a postage stamp to the Fontana Pretoria.


== Gallery ==
