Our hotel resource said this place was known as the Square of Shame! The buildings around it seemed to be in decay but it took just a few minutes to walk around this fountain located close to the Quattro Canti. Beggars and homeless drifting around too. I might have appreciated
It is a beautiful plaza in the center of Palermo, near to other monuments. Try to take a look from the roof of the St. Caterina (if you can pay an expensive ticket of 20 € per person).

We found the Piazza Pretoria and its fountain during a one day stopover in Palermo as our ship was docked in the port here. We had opted to explore the city on foot and had prepared our own agenda with points of interest to visit. We discovered the Piazza quite by accident
In a small piazza with the City Hall behind the visitor finds a marble oasis and a picturesque scenery to immortalise happy moments in Palermo.

Simply beautiful. Lots of statues to look at, lots of detail, but I don’t know how or when some of the reviewers photos were taken as it was extremely busy when we were there on a Saturday morning. Wishing that tour groups were restricted to a maximum of 12 people or that the
Stunning fountain with lots of photo opportunities. A perfect place to come for a pit stop, sit down, enjoy the view.

A real gem in Palermo and a must see. Originally created by Florentine artists was donated to Palermo and placed in the Piazza Pretoria. The 12 Olympians and the animals and mythological creatures all around it make it a beautiful composition and stunning piece of art.

Beautiful fountain, sadly the state of the square seems to be of no concern to the local authorities, the buildings all around are in the need of renovation. Visit it after dark to get the most beautiful views.
It's another fountain in Italy :) It is interesting and has a great back story to it. We enjoyed viewing it, it is very large and beautiful.
The fountain and the many sculptures and statues surround it, make a very nice view. It takes a while if you want to observe each one. So take the time.
This beautiful waterfall was actually designed to be in Florence although was dismantled and sent to Palermo. It is absolutely breath taking and beautiful

Originally created in Florence, this was subsequently moved to Palermo and installed outside of a nunnery. As male nudity shocked the sisters, they emerged at night to chisel away the more offensive parts. The base is surrounded by wonderful animal sculpture. Each is unique,

This did not rock my boat - rather oversized statues and fountain in which would have been a lovely square without them as the surrounding buildings have character .But certain angles make for great photos - then move on.
Big and beautiful fountain visible behind buildings from main street. Some sculptures need renovation but you will take lot of nice photos.

It is a beautiful fountain and no admission fee is needed!You may spend 5 to 10 minutes to take some pictures there. From there , you can walk to church of san cataldo,Santa Maria dell'Ammiraglio,Quinto Canto and Chiesa del Gesù easily!Many beautiful churches within walking

The fountain with its beautiful allegorical statues is beautiful, but not stunning like those of Bernini in Rome. Because of its location (near the Martorana and Cathedral) you will probably walk nearby on your way to somewhere else. It’s worth a five minute deviation.
If you are in Palermo, please pay a visit. But definitely not a destination you wanted to plan. A place to stop by and take some pictures, I guess that's it.
Tucked away just off Vitoria Emanuelle, this fountain is worth the few minutes it takes to take it in.

A nice fountain in the center of Palermo. It is well preserved and worth to see. It is a bit sad to see that the building right next to this beautiful monument is in very bad shape.. During the day the area was crowded with tourists but at night there was no one around.
First saw this on Saturday morning. Not too busy. Sunday morning also not too busy. Beautiful statues. Fountain of shame. Nudes in front of two churches.

Located in Piazza Pretoria, also known as Piazza della Vergogna (The Square of Shame), the 16th-century circular fountain contains mostly nude statues of men, ladies (The term generally used is not gender correct/polite, so I changed it to “ladies.” Why do many people use an

The fountain is near the Quattro Canti on Via Maqueda and it's a must see attraction when in Palermo. There are Roman gods and goddesses, water spouting from the mouths of many types of animals, and various levels from which you can experience the art and the fountain. At
The fountain is like a diamond in the middle of the Pretoria square. You can see statues of mythological Roman gods and goddeses. Must see attraction.

A large and stunning fountain on Via Maqueda just a short walk from Quattro Canti, this is something that you must see. Set slightly above the road, the water from the fountain drops into two levels of basins which are surrounded by many naked statues (which is why it is also

Fontana della Vergogna is an incredible work of art, We were in Palermo for 4 days and I walked around it everyday. Every time I walked around it I found something different to admire about it. It is in Piazza Pretoria, in front of city hall.

This is a very nice and interesting Fontana with naked sculptures in Piazza Pretoria, in the historic town of Palermo. It is a must visit in the city and tends to be not too crowded, at least when we went. As a tip, it is worth mentioning that, from the next buildings' stairs, a
This 16th century fountain in situated in a piazza proximate to La Martorana, and the churches of San Cataldo and St. Catherine of Alexandria. A must see.
It is a very nice fountain with several statues too look at. It is not that busy so you can take your time looking at the statues.
Hard to miss if you visit historic Palermo and Quatto Canti. Out of season it wasn't mobbed and good atmosphere

The Fontana Pretoria is a must see and is in close proximity to other sites such as the La Martorana, Palazzo dei Normanni and the Cappella Palatina. This fountain was designed about 1552 for the garden of a Florentine Villa. It is also called "The Fountain of Shame" because

This is set in the beautiful old city of Palermo and is just one of the things you must see. Surrounded by many statues depicting men and women in all different poses (mostly naked be warned) - once called the fountain of shame because of all the nudity. This is a beautiful

Situated in the historic centre of Palermo, is this wonderful fountain and statues. Guards are vigilant all the time as there is a "no sitting" rule. Close by to several churches and the Ballaro Market.
It’s located in the old part of the city. It’s really nice to walk in this part of Palermo to enjoy the vibe and history.
This structure is a must see. It is truly remarkable and ornate. It is much.more interesting a larger than The Neptune. Well worth the visit.

This spot is attractive not only for the nude statues but I think because of the fountain itself and the very good lighting from above as long as it's sunny! The weather was very nice when we visited it and the sky was bright speckled with white clouds.
Nice and elaborate fountain near a couple churches. It’s worth stopping at for a few photos. One can get a great view of it from the tower of Saint Catherine’s church next door.
Nice to see and hear that the convent overlooked the fountain. It was deemed shameful with all the nude statues!

This Plaza is bordered by three buildings - Church of St Catherine, Praetorian palace now the city hall and two baronial Palazzo. The fourth side has stairs to another street. In the center is a large fountain sometimes referred to as the Fountain of Shame. The fountain is the
We came across fountain hidden away in this beautiful square, Always look up small alley ways you never know what you will miss.
With essential Palermitan buildings all around, this fountain fits in nicely and offers a good stop for a rest.
A famous fountain, too bad it's a bit hidden between so many attractive old historical buildings. Worth stopping by.

This fountain is totally over the top and featured animals and monsters and nudies 😊 I think the southern italians are a bit miffed and call it the fountain of shame. It’s a shame that heads have been taken off and it’s in a bit of a state.

This is a selfie users paradise for those who are desperate to get liked by their friends! Apart from that the statues are in need of some refurbishment but the atmosphere is good when the selfie users have gone
Delightful square with beautiful fountain and sculptures surrounded by many churches. We came early and there were not too many people around so we were able to get some good photos
I fell in love with this enormous fountain. It is full of beautifully carved animals (and a few monsters) that coexist with classical nudes. It is quite bizarre, but very enjoyable.
Beautiful piece of art and the story behind it was fascinating Take plenty of photos and bring you walking shoes as the peble stone roads are at time tough on your feet Worth the visit when in town
It's really quite pretty, with a number of animal head sculptures as part of the fountain- very unusual. And close to other sights as well, very convenient.

Despite weather conditions we visited that place Very interesting history The art and sculpture is magnificent . It is also near other places of interest when you go by small lane you get to the Arabian and Israeli places of interest
Possibly my favourite part of our visit to Palermo. An exquisite fountain in a beautiful location. Definitely worth a visit

A lot of things costs an entrance fee in Palermo. This fountain is free, it is beautiful and you can walk on it. There is a bit of interesting history connected with it that you should take the time to read up on.
Less much frequented as the Trevi fountain in Roma but as beautiful while completely different. Located in a beautiful square.
You’ve got to see this but really need an experienced guide or very good guidebook. Recommend Jackie Alio who painted a wonderful picture of the history.

Built in 1554 for Don Luigi di Toledo in Florence, later sold to the Senate of Palermo as a result of his debts, the fountain was erected in 1574 minus various statues of the original works. It is nevertheless the centerpiece of Piazza Pretoria with a fence surrounding three
Good destination. Should visit if you stay in Palermo and take pictures. That's all I guess. should go.

Just a short walk from the Quattro Canti, the centre of the old city, this fountain is gorgeous. It's better first thing in the morning - no people but the gates to let you inside are closed - but it's lovely at any time.

This iconic landmark of nude statuary situated in Palermo could have been lifted out of Florence. It is in the old part of town and is not to be missed.Because it was located in front of a nunnery , it was given the Square of Shame title.

An unexpected star in this corner of Palermo. The fountain is vast and has some amazing figures spouting water. It is a real suntrap and a great place to people watch. Spotlessly clean and well presented.

Fontana della Vergogna is located in the Piazza Pretoria. When we were there the fountain did not work due to people working around the fountain. I think it would've been an awesome sight to see if it was working. If you like fountains it will be worth your while to email the

Fontana della Vergogna (Fountain or Shame) located in Piazza Pretoria right in the historic centre of Palermo, opposite the beautiful church of San Giuseppe dei Teatini. It features naked statues of the Greek Gods, animals and mythological figures. It only takes a few minutes to
Profusion of sculptures and fountains from the C16 in a lovely piazza. The time to look at the expressions of the animals spouting water.
Nothing spectacular but it is located in the centre of town in a square surrounded by old buildings. Palermo is definitely worth visiting

The sculptures of gods, mythical creatures and animals around this fountain places it in my view above the famous fountain below the Spanish steps in Rome. I am surprised that this treasure is less known than many others in Italy. Happy to have seen it.
Fabulous fountain, with really interesting history and decor. Worth a visit but make sure you pause to sit down on it or expect a wrist slapping from the local security :)
Curiously named "fountain of shame", this is a powerful sample of Baroque art, with 16 nude figures and torsos of nymphs and satyrs with Roman profiles, all white and brawny, Very sensuous.
This is a lovely fountain where whomever designed it ensured that the smallest details of human anatomy were included.
The square is big and it’s worth taking your time to walk around it and take in all the different angles of the statues. No matter if it’s a sunny or overcast day, the fountains will make it justice!
This is very impressive and interesting work, in terms of time, dimensions and details. You can see it from the roof of one of the buildings there. Very close of 4 canti.
This fountain is located in the Plaza Pretoria. it has beautifully carved figurines, now barricaded so you can see them from a distance only

This was a shook - most sculptures at some stage have been badly damaged and then partially put back to-gether. Some appear to be masterpieces and others created as if a joke to fill in spaces. The design is interesting and parts of fountain BUT overall it was disappointing. It
Part of our horse carriage ride from the msc meraviglia. Stopped here for photos. Really beautiful to walk round.

What a beautiful fountain! On a fine day, one would wander around and take in all the Sicilian sun. The fountain boasts high Baroque heritage, with wonderful and enduring craftsmanship. The figures are vivid with smooth silhouette. The old, run-down buildings surrounding the
, As nice as it looks , but seems new and not a place of character, surrounded by gates so one can not appreciate it better
The fountain carvings and the square the fountain is situated in is very nice. You can visit some unesco churches nearby and the mayors house opposite for free.

During our stay in Palermo on a guided tour, our guide mentioned the history of this fountain that was built during a very conservative time in Sicily. Not only is this fountain breathtaking but equally beautiful with their nude male and female statues. I recommend that you
Just the thought of the history in this place and the stories, give me goose bumps! Do yourself a favor and visit this place enjoy!

We found this gorgeous fountain as we walked along the Via Maqueda. It is a very busy area filled with tourists most every day. There are horse drawn carriages that you can rent for a very nice ride to see area located right on the street.
Fontana della Vergogna not as beautiful as the Fontana di Trevi in Rome but as near as nice. Can't miss !

Situated in the center of the historic area of Palermo, it attracts a lot of tourists. With it's interesting history and a lot of statues that are part of this monumental peace one can spend an hour easily just observing, and taking pictures of it. Must see.
The amount of sculptures on this fountain are incredible. Just layer above layer. Rich content not seen on many fountains. Well worth the time to check it out.

With Florentine origins, the Praetorian Fountain is a colossal fountain sculpture complex located in the heart of the historic center. Constructed by Francesco Camilliani in Florence during 1554, it was transported to Palermo 20 years later. Hard economic times had fallen on the

Lots of figures in this plaza. The buildings housed a convent which was confiscated when the fountain was sold to the city. originally built in Florence it was sold and moved to Palermo. It is also called the Piazza della Vergogna" (Square of Shame).Based on the nude figures
Its a fountain, in a square. It has marble statues and various carvings. Its quite pretty, so worth seeking out

This was one of my favourite squares in Palermo as it just told so many centuries of story with the external palaces that surround the shameful fountain originally designed for Florence then dismantled and transferred to Palermo
After Rome and Florence, this fountain just doesn't stand the comparison...The statues are mediocre and the buildings around the plaza quite decrepit
Stay away from Catalonia. These are crazies that have no check on reality. Spain should let them fulfill their crazy dream, and they dont care ablut the lives lf refilar Eople.
Located in the Plaza Pretoria, this is one of those grand water fountains. It features well exposed human figures. Definitely worth a walk-by.
Rather unexpected between many churches. It badly need water to be a real fountain. The corner of Florence in Palermo
Close to a monastery for women who didn't accept to see naked female statues! In the historical center
Very loud and touristy, in the middle of the main street, had some concerts and events going on. Museums are with tickets, but overall a nice place to sit and relax.
Nice spot for taking pictures in Palermo city. Statues, buildings and fountain. Lots to see and interesting

This fountain is a very beautiful fountain at certain times of the day you can go on it and walk around. Lots of people like to sit on the steps and just listen to the water run. The fountain is made of all marble all I can say is it's beautiful.

Right near the Four Corners, the Fountain of Shame (named because it was built in Fiernze and moved to Sicily) has beautiful statues (which upset the nuns in the convent that once was across from it, hence the "shame") and is picture perfect spot.
This is gorgeous during the day, and even more at night when everything is illuminated. We were there several times, and we got to appreciate it even more.
The story of it is interesting and all the animals statues as well. Whatever you visit, it is on the way, so stop there for a few minutes 😊

The statues are IMHO crudely constructed. You will see this fountain if if take the sightseeing/free tourist bus or walk down Via Vittore Emmanuele near the 4 corners. History behind it is interesting.

This is an absolutely stunning little square in central Palermo, almost entirely consumed by this flamboyant fountain adorned with elaborate, idealistic statues of young, muscular men and curvey women, plus muses and gods. Not to be missed!
Beautiful fountain in heart of Palermo close to four corners and Saint Catherina church which is a great visit. Short walk to main street for restaurants and shops.

Wow, what a fountain, so much to take in so take your time to really appreciate it. A great gathering spot on a Sunday afternoon as all sorts of people sat or strolled around this fountain enjoying it.
Very interesting fountain. Many people were sitting on the steps in front, just enjoying the evening. The name made me go to 'google' to find out why it has the name 'Fountain of Shame'!
This is known as fountains of shame - every statue (other than one) are typical Roman nudes so difficult to take pictures if you are prudish:) - its a great visit and nothing unacceptable
Came across it by chance,well worth finding.Just off Quattro Canti on Via Macheda,great place to just sit and watch,then go on to the daily market
We found this fountain on our walk around Palermo. It has some unusual animal sculptures and is a good spot for a rest on a busy schedule
Very beautiful and looks clean and taking care of it. You cannot throw pennies in the fountain and you cannot sit near it to take photos
See during the night it's so beautiful. Near the "Quattro canti" one of the most famous places in Palermo.
I think the best thing about the fountain is to look above it. For me the skyline was a better treat than the fountains itself. Worth a passing visit but that's about it.
Just off via Vittorio Emanuele. Stop by for just a moment, or watch families and lovers escaping the traffic.
One of my favourite places in Palermo. Admire the architecture. It almost feels like being in the midst of people.
The Fontana Pretoria is Palermo’s most monumental fountain, which was built by Francesco Camilliani in Florence in 1554, and later transported to Palermo in 1574.
Stunning fountain set in a very picturesque square in the heart of Palermo. It has been refurbished lately and it's glorious, words can't describe it, a must see.
It is an astonishing site, perfect for amazing pictures: just crazy nuns could think about destroying the sexual parts of the statues
Knowing that Dolce and Gabbana had an Alta Moda fete months before our visit was the allure for me but it's a gorgeous spectacle and so nice to see it's a must visit location in Sicily. Bellissima!
Marvelos fountain with the great story behind it. Very detailed work of the statues and great quality of the materials. Definately worth visiting.

This fountain use to also be called the Fountain of Shame. . It was donated to the city by a wealthy family & built outside of the convent... it was called the fountain of Shame because of the feelings all the naked statues where said to awaken in the Nuns 😊
We came upon this when walking to the cathedral, lovely fountain and buildings around it, good place to take photos.
It is a spectecular place to visit. So much culture in one place. Shame that the buildings around aren't taking care of.

The Pretoria fountain is undeniably beautiful. I could just imagine if there was no fence. It would even be more grandious. From googling, I found out that this fountain was in fact bought by the Senate of Palermo from a rich man in Florence who needed money to pay his debts.

Set in a cute square in Palermo's old town center, it is a harmonious combination of elegant staircases and many large statues, some of which representing Palermo's rivers. The palaces around the square are also of great architectural value. Definitely worth a stop and a read of
A large fountain with a lot of nude people - or statues. I found it quite impressive, but then again I have a thing for fountains and waterfalls. The place surrounding it is also nice, by the way.

In the very center of Palermo opposite the town hall, is this big fountain. Called the fountain of shame, because of all naked sculptures. Well the men's testiles have been removed ancient time, because they were too offensive... Also the fountain was a synonyms for the
Beuatiful and well kept extensive fountain taking up most of a squate just off the Via Vittorio Emanuele in the central historic district.

This is the central-point set-piece fountain of Palermo. Unfortunately it has Nineteenth-Century railings around it and it is presently closed for restoration. When restored, it will be a fine sight. The statuary is of variable quality but there are some amusing faces. The

It's very beautiful fountain and what is more important it's in the heart of Palermo. A lot of nude statues which are beautiful, in front of the is a town hall where you can enter for free if there is no session.

Visited Palermo to see some of the sights. It is an exciting, if run down city and it has many attractions. The fountain should be one of them but, without water, it loses something. Sort of like the life is taken from it. The black fence around it detracts from it as well. It
this roman style fountain remindes classic simmilar items in rome or greece. go around. the vicinity is not impressive and it harms the overall impressin.

Fontana Pretoria is beautiful; it’s one of Palermo’s major attraction and it dominates over the Piazza Pretoria. The fountain's tiered basins ripple out in concentric circles, crowded with nude nymphs, tritons and leaping river gods. It was designed by the Florentine sculptor
A wonderfully exuberant baroque fountain with an explosion of marble figures. A lovely spot in the middle of busy Palermo.
The fountain is called of the 'Vergogna' shame, because of its nude statues which were placed between a church and a nun's cloister monastery!
A very nice fountain that got a bad reputation for the nude statues that surround it. Not sure why since there are a lot of nude statues throughout Italy.

Maybe we had bad luck, there was no water in the fountain, This gives this fountain a bit of a sad feeling. The story behind is nice and you probally will pass by this fountain anyway on your walk trhough Palermo.
The detail of this fountain is astounding! Take the time to view each portion, it is worth it! I found it by accident, but read up on it afterwards

It takes about 15 minutes walk to reach this fountain from Palermo Cruise Terminal. Very close is also Quattro Canti. The fountain is in a square which is also known as the Square of Shame because this fountain contains a good number of naked statues surrounded around its

The Fontana Pretoria (or as the locals call it Fontana della Vergogna) is a big fountain on the Plazza Pretoria in the heart of the city. The design is very interesting and the many statues, which represent Greek gods and goddesses, make a nice setting. The square can get very

Wonderful landmark worth checking out in Palermo! Too bad water wasn't running but this seemed to be the norm in the city. Lack of water or costs to maintain may be the reason but it would have been more impressive.

Large fountain crammed into a small piazza, but the result is still charming and photogenic. Come here either at the break of dawn or sunset, the light would be great. It's free to see and one of the places in Palermo one should visit.

There are many landmarks in Palermo that could be a real beauty . But like in many other landmarks - this Fontana on Piazza Pretoria needs dramatic cleaning and renovation . Even the buildings around the square ( The old city hall and Chiesa Maria and S. Giosseppe ) look

A very nice " fontana " just meters off via Emanuelle which was a rage in its time due the nude exposed it is a tourist stop today and rightly so as we ,the "modern " man are not offended anymore . Interesting and originally artful .
Squeezed into a very small square this fountain dominates. You can walk up onto it, and admoire the artistry.
The fountain is beautiful and you can walk all through the statues. It only takes a few minutes to visit as its just off the main road and it is really worth it.

When in Florence or Rome you are truly wowed but the fountains. This one looks like a poor copy. The updated parts look like they are made out of plastic and have little artistic merit. Go to it if you are walking past, don't make it a day out!
Fontana Della Vergogna is a Palermo landmark and a place to take pictures and walk around. The Square is located in front of City Hall and a 1/4 block from the Four Corners.

Has to be seen to be believed incredible collection of statues. Evidently the whole structure was transported from elsewhere with bits "lost" along the way. One fellow tourist said to me: "go see it it's mad totally crazy" - but beautiful too.
This fountain was brought to Sicily from Florence. It's really beautiful. Parts of the fountain were removed at night by nuns.

On our first evening in Palermo we went out for a wander without any itinerary. We rounded a corner and suddenly there was this amazing fountain! The size and grandeur of it makes this a worthwhile place to visit. It is surrounded by railings and gate is locked at night and the

A great square with an interesting history of having been donated to Palermo after the sculptures were considered too risky. Also a good base from which to go in to the Mayor's office on the square and look out at the view of the neighbouring churces.

This once great fountain is constrained in a tight space. It has an ugly black metal fence all the way around it. It looks run down and is dry many days. Worth seeing if you are in the area. Lots of interesting history. If this review is helpful then please indicate so
Enjoyed the architecture of the church more than the fountain. Located right near one of the main outdoor markets for the city which is really interesting to walk through and worth the time.
As so many beauties in Italy, as you are walking casually , you just " stumble " on this gorgeous fountain . They call it vergogna, the shame in italian , because the statues are all nudes .
Lovely fountain with statues on different levels just a few minutes walk from our hotel in Via Vittorio Emanuele
After walking around in the Aug. heat for hours, for some reason no one was really here. I found myself thinking what a prefect place, and of all the people who had enjoy it before me.

Apparently this fountain was designed and created for another location and in the end erected here just off the main crossroads in Old Palermo. It is large and interesting with many animals playing their roles in creating sprays of water. It is definately worth seeing but it's
Lots of statues around a large fountain in a square. Well worth the walk to have a look. Nothing else to say really.

Off the Via Maqueda, this piazza is beautiful and the centerpiece of an interesting area. Go at night too as it is gorgeous lit up. Nice coffee shop down the alley behind the pizza. Great spot to linger and people watch.

Piazza Pretoria got nicknamed Piazza della Vergogna (the square of shame) because of the nude sculptures that were put right in front of the church. A Belgian teacher told her pupils it was because the fountain turned out to be too expensive. Maybe, but it's not the main reason.

We were very lucky to be here immediately following a heavy rain shower. There was no one at the site and a great opportunity for photos. Loved all the details especially all the animal spouts. Have seen a lot of fountains in our travels but this is one of our favourites

This fountain is notorious...the nuns once cut off the noses of the nude statues in protest of their nudity. The fountain has since been restored and for the first time since i first saw this fountain 10 years ago you can now walk on the fountain instead of just seeing it on
Nicknamed the fountain of shame because of the nudity of the statues. In the very heart of Palermo with beautiful buildings all around.
The people of Palermo are very proud of their many fountains and stately squares and rightly so. A lovely square to relax in for a few moments while passing through.
Not a regular fountain. There are canals of water and you can walk around inside it. very beautiful, worth a visit, just nearby Via Vittorio Emanuele

Doesn't matter ow many time one can go around this fountain - every time it is different and charming and it is impossible to finish watching it and get familiar with all the images and scenes. The history of not only sculpture and fountain making can be seen but also a History
This is a beautiful fountain right off of the main shopping street. The statuary adorning it are lovely, as are the animal heads that circle the base.

I laughed on visiting this place after reading the blurb in my travel book referring to it as known as the fountain of shame...because of its nudity. Because of Italy's reputation for "la dolce vita" and it's fairly permissive societal norms, it is easy to forget there were

This fountain has a number of naked statues and hence the name of fountain of shame". It is situated close by to a convent of nuns and it is said that one night the nuns, who were horrified by the shameful sculptures, chopped all the 2private parts" of the statues :)
This is a pretty plaza, and the fountain is fun to visit. It is outside, so you can always see it (although the gates to walk up into it are closed at night).
The area is full of interesting monuments and the Fontana completely dominates the Piazza. It is well preserved and one can walk up to the higher levels of the fountain and take photos.

Completely free and very interesting. Each quadrant has 5 animals - some obvious, some not so obvious to our modern eyes. Lovely statues and the top held up by two scary looking mer-people. Loads of water gurgling and splashing everywhere. Well worth 10 minutes or so and
it is a very nice monument in a very nice square on one of the main streets of Palermo. Just behind the square there is the church of San Cataldo which is worth a visit too
It’s simply magnificent. It’s wonderful at any time of the day and of the night. Take your time to observe it and don’t go in a hurry.
The beautiful fountain of white stone, wonderfully blended into the small square. Easy access, when going to The Norman Pallace and Cathedral.

Situated near Quattro Canti it's right in the heart of historic Palermo, you can't possibly miss it. Unfortunately there are alot of tourists teeming around so it's quite difficult to take a picture of the statues without "intruders". It opens in the morning, around 9. Anyway on

This is a lovely fountain with carvings of animals real and mythical. It's just off the main drag. It seems to serve as a meeting point for locals. There was a wedding party being photographed there when we visited.

Few steps from Quattro Canti, on the piazza in front of the City Hall is this majestic fountain. It reminds on the famous Florence fountain which is on Piazza Signoria in Florence. This one was also built there, and later transported to Sicily. All figures are nude, and

The fountain was built in Florence and was sold to Sicily after a few decades. On its naval journey- from Florence to Sicily, some of the statues got "lost" and some were partly broken. It took about 7 years to fix and install the fountain in the City Hall square. The statues
A wonderful fountain surrounded by impressive architecture with impressive sculptures. Great for photo opportunities and certainly one of the most impressive fountains I have seen.

The renaissance fountain originally install in florence and moved to Palermo. The fountain included 48 statues and was surrounded by a long arbor formed by 90 columns of wood designed by Bartolomeo Ammannati. Rumor has is that the nuns in Palermo weren't so happy with the new
Love it! Love it! Typical Italian architecture and the beauty. Don't forgot to throw the coin inside the water and wish something.
Grandiose fountain in the heart of Palermo, delicate sculptures surround and intricate marble fountain, you cannot miss it.
This is a very well known fountain in Palermo and well worth a visit. The Roman statues are well preserved and beautifully made. A real work of art.

Everything you would imagine in an Italian fountain in a piazza is here, with unending sculptures and just eye-catching features. Unfortunately, access is limited as there is a fence around it, so can't get too close, but nonetheless can still appreciate it.
One of the most beautiful fountains i had the pleasure to see. It's a real jewel, a true work of art.

The fenced gate was open on our visit so we were able to get right to the centre. Beautiful statues adorn the fountain. Love the story that the Mass goers were so appalled by the nudity of the statues that they named it the fountain of shame.

This amazing fountain, surrounded from 3 sides by important buildings, is quite impressive, all white marble, with so many different statues beautifully blended together. Some parts do not work, would need bit better taking care for it

This is a beautiful piazza. A great place to take pictures during the day or at night. Take a break here and enjoy lunch looking at many naked human figures. It's also a very central place: you can go to the church around the corner and to the Quattro Canti. Also, you can hop on

Fontana Pretoria is absolutely stunning, pity there is nowhere for an aerial view, to get a true appreciation of the brilliant layout. The fountain was not intended for a public space but rather for a private villa in Florence. Built by Francesco Camilliani in 1554, it was
great craftsmanship and design, a fountain that dominates it surroundings. Looks fantastic day or night and worth taking a moment to study

Beautiful, beautiful beautiful. It is very difficult to describe in details Fontana Pretoria. If you think that the Trevi Fountain is beautiful, come down to Palermo and absorb the beauty of Fontana Pretoria. Highly recommended.
The fountain is very beautiful art work. It was the third stop on our itinerary of Palermo tour. The whole town is full of Baroque and Neoclasicism art pieces and the fountain is no exception.

You must take a good wake around each level of the Fountain. You can almost see the sculptor's devious grin as he is creating these interesting characters. I would recommend you read about it before you go to see it. Understanding the history makes it all the more interesting.

Very beautiful, but the local story is most interesting. The fountain was placed in the piazza between a church and a convent. The priest and nuns were not happy with what they saw everyday with the nude statues. They say one night the nuns removed parts that where offensive.

Very pretty fountain, but unlike Trevi in Rome, you look UP at this fountain and it appears to be surrounded by a steel fence at the front (go around to the side and you can enter and walk up to the top level. It's a pleasant space, just off the four corners area.

This was within 100 meters of our B&B and if you find yourself on Via Vittoria Emanuele near Via Roma take a quick detour to visit. It is a place where many come for pictures (a wedding shoot was ongoing when we were there).
Definitely worth a visit. No many other tourists were in the square when we were there. Very quiet considering its location.

The fountain is really big, maybe a bit too big for the square where it's located on. For a photo you should go up the stairs of a building nearby. You wouldn't expect such a big fountain on a square as peaceful as this one.
very interest fountain in front of the city hall. The larger than life statutes leave little to the imagination.

This is a great fountain. So much to see! Apparently it shocked the locals when it was built and it is easy to see why.

It is a really lovely fountain surrounded by interesting architecture as well. It's worth the walk. It is a pity that you cannot sit down on the fountains borders, but it's understandable.

Palermo is rather lacking in expansive urban piazzas; the Fontana della Vergogna anchors one of them, the Piazza Pretoria. One can walk around the fenced-in fountain and admire the facades of surrounding buildings, but no place really to sit.
Beautiful fountain and piazza. Really close to Quattro Cantti. I recommend a visit here if you go to Palermo.
If you are in the area , this is worth seeing if only for its size. The various themes depicted by the statues are interesting to view if you have some time to spare .

No matter where you go in Palermo, you will probably pass by this fountain and it is quite something as it takes over almost the entire square. Aren't the Palermitani lucky to have been able to acquire it?
You would never stop analysing the statues and decorations, once by one, of this Fountain which takes almost the whole square but the overall view is also beautiful and eye-catching

A hidden gem we stumbled across on a quiet sleepy Sunday afternoon. There was almost no one around and we had the place to ourselves. The craftsmanship is beautiful and the setting superb. Make sure you include this on your list.

What a gorgeous fountain -- Fontana Della Vergogna, or Fountain of Shame! Years ago, it was open to the public, allowing one to walk up the steps and enjoy the fountain from within. On our recent visit, the gates were locked but we were able to admire the statues from a close
Beautifull place, close to the others turistics points, e.g the 4 canti. It is surrounded by historics buildings.

You are walking on a street in a Palermo past some buildings and then, WOW. You turn a corner to see this. It's called the "fountain of shame" by the locals only because the statues are all naked. Gorgeous site!

This is one of the most gorgeous places one can find in this magic city. I had the bless of seeing it snow (very rare in Palermo) in the morning in this place. Wow, I will not forget the show of seeing the snow flakes fall while seeing this marvelous sculpture set. Beautiful

Yes this is the name the 16th century Sicilians gave this fountain. It's full of nudes though of course has been damaged over the years, plenty to spot at all levels including the beasts heads towards the centre. Nice place for a bit of a breather after walking round Palermo
When this fountain was unveiled the nakedness was shameful. The genitalas were not touch and so the noses were cut off??? Go figure.

Literally around the corner from the Quattro Canti. A large tiered fountain with many statues of naked men and women, from which the statue’s second came is derived – La Fontana della Vergogna (Fountain of Shame). Only a 10-15 minute visit is required.

For me this is Italy's most beautiful fountain: Monumental, impressive, beautiful and unique. Usually closed to public (it is fenced) in Feb 2016 in the early afternoon we found the gates open for visit - not sure if regular though. But even without open gates it is an
Great story of how the fountain got there.Surrounding buildings are worth a closer look and the Four Corners are nearby.

We visited this attraction and despite the comments about the fencing the fountain is still accessible and visible, you just have to walk around more to take it all in. Fabulous animal heads spouting into the pools.

This fountain was beautiful, but I feel the fencing hid a lot of the fountain. I know they're trying to keep people off the fountain, but I wish they would find another way. Standing behind a fence, trying to see the whole fountain, spoiled it for me a little, but it is still
Impressive fountain next to the Four Corners Square. Interesting details on different levels. When I visited it was open so I could walk around freely.
It is amazing how it is still standing after all these years. It show a lot of ware and tear, but still worth seeing. Mostly fenced in.

This ornate fountain, with its tiered basins and sculptures built in concentric circles, is at the centre of Piazza Pretoria .The nude nymphs proved too much for church-goers attending Mass next door, and it was dubbed the Fountain of Shame! It's just beautiful anyway.
The splendour and grandeur of this fountain is difficult to describe until you experience it, whether by day or, particularly, by night! Another unmissable Palermo sight!
Great art work. Interesting history. Good place to take rest. I was especially interested in imitation of different animal faces.
An incredible fountain in a lovely piazza. See it from all perspectives. Good thing they swiped it from the Florentines.
The reason for the nickname of the fountain is unclear but the whole square is a delicious example of the many cultures that inhabited Sicily during the centuries.
Theres just something about fountains that seem to relax you.. You can sit around and admire the view or catch up on your emails as this seemed to be a wifi hot spot
In one of ain own town streets. Interesting name! We avoided taking a custom guided horse drawn tour as the driver was too perdistent.

this is a nice piece of art in the historic city center which has an even more interesting story of how it got its name. ( Literally translated it is the Fountain of Shame - a name locals gave it because of its nude statutes ) Worth a visit.
Impossible to miss really. Slightly uglified by the railings around it but probably one of the finest outdoor collections to be seen.

Francesco Camilliani's most notable work is the Renaissance fountain of the Piazza Pretoria. The structure of the fountain has three concentric basins surrounded by statues of the gods of Olympus, graceful nymphs and mythological allegories - a harmonious and graceful ensemble

This large fountain stands on a square in the old section of Palermo. It is the work of 16th c Italian sculptor Francesco Camilliani. It displays a set of wonderful statues depicting scenes from the Roman mythology.

A lovely place to stop and wander around the fountain. The white marble is reflective on a hot day, so can feel very hot, but if you can find some shade, its lovely to sit & relax. The fountain itself is an odd mix of animals spouting water- a hippo, camel, dog, lion, wolf

We stumbled across this on a lovely evening and the light was fantastic. The statues are a bizarre mixture of the very life like with distorted figures and odd interpretations of animals (real and fantastic)

This is one of those places that you hear about but unless you actually go there you cannot appreciate it. The Fontana della Vergogna is an artistic delight and an architectural marvel. You have probably seen it in books and pictures, but you must see it in person.

Lots of history and interesting. The fountain is located in the middle of a square that must have been magnificent in it's day. sadly the surronding buildings need repair. Be sure to visit the church off to the side.

Located in the Piazza Pretoria, which is the Center of Palermo, is this fun, but rather nice piece of work. It was originally bought in the 15th century, and was modified to fit the square. The square is nicknamed the Square of Shame because of the nude statues. It is a very
Impressive fountain that's well worth a wander around when you are visiting the various other tourist highlights nearby.
The fountain was frowned upon by the puritanical nuns due to the amount of nude figures! A nice place to sit when it's hot as the water is so inviting .. .

Located near 2 must see churches, the fountain is in a semi shady square and a nice space to stop with a picnic lunch or at the café in the square. The perfect place to write a postcard home ( old school, but everyone loves a post card!), and you can even buy a stamp and post it

Located right next to the Quattro Conti this is one of the biggest and beautiful fountains. Lots of sculptures arranged in various scenes. Some of them are not in such a good condition and in need of restoration, but beautiful nevertheless.

This is a splendid fountain in the heart of town. Its very close to many other historic monuments. You can cover them all in one short walk. Excellent statues full of elegance adorn this lovely fountain.

We spent a day walking around Palermo, whist our cruise ship was berthed at the port. It was a Sunday and many of the shops in the city were closed. The bonus was that several of the main streets in the city were closed to traffic, making them pedestrian malls for the day.

Lovely fountain but unable to be fully appreciated from ground level. Good carvings but some are damaged and need to be repaired.
located in the city center of palermo, this interesting fountain is an amazing spot for your pictures from palermo
This fountain is a wonderful example of sculpture. From this piazza, you can see the domes and facades of four churches or note and are only a short walk from the Quatro Canti.
visually very attractive. The quality of the carved figures is truly outstanding and is far larger than the photograph suggests.

I just love Palermo, full stop. The Fontana is another 'hey, you are where the heart is' place. Deemed indecent by some when first unveiled, the statues appear to just quietly survey the passing parade of locals and tourists.

Right next to the center of the city, this fountain is hidden next to an equally impressive crossroads and a beautiful church. Even though it hasto be admired from afar it is well worth the visit!
You cannot miss this while being in Palermo, its a beautiful soot that takes your breath away. Just like in the movies it rises beside you and leaves a great impression!
Right in the center of the city in the old Palermo a square to see and a majestic fountain! And they also have the trip advisor panel inside! (That's funny)

Nice fountain in the middle of the city. While I found the Trevi Fountain in Rome to be the largest and most majestic i saw in Italy Fontana della Vergogna is up there as well and worth a visit. It is right in the heart of Palermo as well.
Not as nice as the fountain in Rome but still nice for pictures. Hardly any water but it was Sunday so perhaps its turned off on the day of rest.

Absolutely stunning! There are so many beautiful things to see around that area! It's a wonderful spot for kids to be able to run around and play.
The fountain is one of the most famous landmarks of Palermo. Very interesting statues and a lot of history that goes with them. The square itself is surrounded by some fine historical buildings.

Large square with a large fountain in ots center, surrounded by sculptures and dressed with fresh flowers just a few steps from four corners.

I haven't seen it all already, but from all I have already seen this is the most impressive place. All this statues mixed end up being a perfect view! I recommend to visit!

Set in amongst several churches this fountain depicts naked men and women. It was originally commissioned for a private collection but was at the last minute purchased by the town of Palermo and erected in the 14th century. It's chosen position and nudity caused some concern
Fontana della Vergogna is one of the places someone should not miss!! If you are an architect lover this is your place! the sculptures are so realistic and minimal

The sculptures simply don't hold up to many we've seen in Italy. Not particularly knowledgeable about Italian sculpture, so maybe we missed something, but they seemed so-so. Very centrally located near the Four Corners, so worth seeing, but nothing breathtaking.
Very nice fountaing with impressive statues. Great historic area and neighbourhood to spent time and waking distance from palermo cathedral c. 700 m.
Definitely worth a stop as you explore Palermo's hidden surprises. The fountain is set in a plaza off of the Main Street and makes a nice respite as you're walking the busy and noisy Palermo streets.

Loved the fountains and the architecture, although its cordoned off by a metal fence, a bit disappointing, but at a good tricky angle you can manage to take photographs without the fence being in view. Lovely though.

This is a nice fountain. Tons of detail in the architecture if you slowly walk around it. For a good photo, stand on the steps of the building behind the fountain (away from the street) - from there you can get a sort-of aerial view of the fountain.

There are so many statues in Palermo but this one of the best . I read that when the temple was first unveiled that people were upset because of the graphic nudity. Hard to get a good picture because it is so huge.

In front of the town hall this huge and hilarious piece of baroquery has everything you can imagine - animals and gods and copies of ancient sculpture and nymphs and monsters and allegories and balustrades and steps and dozens of water spouts. All cleaned beautifully and working

This fountain was designed for a Tuscan villa but somehow ended up here. A great site but would be grander in a more expansive surrounding.

text.wiki:
The Regional Archeological Museum Antonio Salinas (Italian: Museo Archeologico Regionale Antonio Salinas) is a museum in Palermo, Italy. It possesses one of the richest collections of Punic and Ancient Greek art in Italy, as well as many items related to the history of Sicily. Formerly the property of the Oratory of Saint Philip Neri, the museum is dedicated to Antonio Salinas, a famous archaeologist and numismatist from Palermo. It is part of the Olivella monumental complex, which includes the Church of St. Ignatius and the adjoining Oratory.


== History ==

The construction of the Olivella complex was begun in the late sixteenth century by the architect Antonio Muttone for the Oratory of Saint Philip Neri and completed in the seventeenth century. Following the law on the suppression of religious orders of 1866 the building was confiscated and became home to the museum.During the Second World War the director of the museum, Jole Bovio Marconi, moved all the material held in the museum to the monastery of San Martino delle Scale. This saved the collection from destruction by the bombing during the Allied invasion of Sicily. In 1949 Bovio Marconi was made responsible for the redevelopment of the museum, as the building was heavily damaged the building was renovated by architect William De Angelis D'Ossat. From 18 July 2011 the museum has been closed for renovation. As of September 2015, only a small part of the museum is accessible free of charge. It is uncertain when the full exhibition will be reopened.


== Sections ==

On the ground floor, a section is dedicated to the artefacts found underwater, including materials that were part of the cargo of vessels, stone anchors, strains of lead, lamps, amphoras and inscriptions ranging from the culture of the Phoenicians to that of the Romans.
The Phoenician section displays two large anthropomorphic sarcophagi of the fifth century BC from the necropolis of Pizzo Cannita (near modern Misilmeri). There are also sculptures of gods and Phoenician votive stelae from Mozia and Lilybaeum.
A reconstruction of the east pediment of the archaeological site of Selinunte is exhibited, displaying the Gorgon of Temple C, several metopes with mythological reliefs (Temples C and E) and sculptures of the archaic and classical period. In 1823, two British architects, Samuel Angell and William Harris, ventured to excavate at Selinunte in the course of their tour of Sicily, and came upon many fragments of sculptured metopes from the Archaic temple now known as “Temple C.” Although local officials tried to stop them, they continued their work, and attempted to export their finds to England, destined for the British Museum. Now in the shadow of the activities of Lord Elgin, Angell and Harris’s shipments were diverted to Palermo, where they remain to this day in the Archaeological Museum.
Artifacts from Himera are on display, as well as objects and sculptures from Solunto, Megara Hyblaea, Tindari, Kamarina and Agrigento. Among the most important works of art are the great Ram bronze of the third century BC from Syracuse, a Roman copy of a sculpture by Lysippus depicting Heracles catching the Ceryneian Hind and a Roman copy of a marble statue by Praxiteles depicting a satyr.
The Roman period is documented by a collection of sculptures and mosaics found in villas from Piazza Vittoria in Palermo, where the center of the Roman city was previously located. Even prehistoric cultures present in the caves around the territory of Palermo are exhibited in the museum.


== Collections ==
The museum is composed in part by private collections purchased or donated to the museum over the centuries.


=== University Museum collection ===
It is the oldest collection of the museum which was acquired in 1814 when Giuseppe Emanuele Ventimiglia, Prince of Belmonte left his collection to the University of Palermo at his death. The university in turn sold it to the museum.


=== Antonio Salinas collection ===
This collection is the largest in size with 6.641 pieces and gave its name to the museum. It was sold to the museum by Antonio Salinas at his death in 1914 by means of a will. The collection consists of books, manuscripts, prints, photographs, personal items and about 6000 coins.


=== Pietro Bonci Casuccini collection ===
This is the Etruscan collection which consists of sarcophagi, gravestones, urns and Attic black and red-figure pottery. It is considered the most important Etruscan collection outside of Tuscany. The exhibits come from Chiusi as part of the excavations carried out in the estates of Count Pietro Bonci Casuccini.
The collection was put up for sale by the grandsons of the founder, Ottavio and Pietro. The sale of the collection was prevented by the Kingdom of Italy in 1863, by the intervention of Michele Amari who was Minister of Education at the time. The state acquired the collection and transferred it to the Regional Archeological Museum of Palermo.

text.wiki:
The Capuchin Catacombs of Palermo (also Catacombe dei Cappuccini or Catacombs of the Capuchins) are burial catacombs in Palermo, Sicily, southern Italy. Today they provide a somewhat macabre tourist attraction as well as an extraordinary historical record.


== Historical background ==
Palermo's Capuchin monastery outgrew its original cemetery in the 16th century and monks began to excavate crypts below it. In 1599 they mummified one of their number, recently dead brother Silvestro of Gubbio, and placed him into the catacombs.
The bodies were dehydrated on the racks of ceramic pipes in the catacombs and sometimes later washed with vinegar. Some of the bodies were embalmed and others enclosed in sealed glass cabinets. Monks were preserved with their everyday clothing and sometimes with ropes they had worn as a penance.
Originally the catacombs were intended only for the dead friars. However, in the following centuries it became a status symbol to be entombed into the Capuchin catacombs. In their wills, local luminaries would ask to be preserved in certain clothes, or even to have their clothes changed at regular intervals. Priests wore their clerical vestments, others were clothed according to the contemporary fashion. Relatives would visit to pray for the deceased and also to maintain the body in presentable condition.
The catacombs were maintained through the donations of the relatives of the deceased. Each new body was placed in a temporary niche and later placed into a more permanent place. As long as the contributions continued, the body remained in its proper place but when the relatives did not send money any more, the body was put aside on a shelf until they resumed payments.


== Interments ==

The last friar interred into the catacombs was Brother Riccardo in 1871 but other famous people were still interred. The catacombs were officially closed in 1880 but tourists continued to visit. The last burials are from the 1920s. One of the very last to be interred was Rosalia Lombardo, then nearly two years old, whose body is still remarkably intact, preserved with a procedure.  The embalming procedure, performed by Professor Alfredo Salafia, consisted of formalin to kill bacteria, alcohol to dry the body, glycerin to keep her from overdrying, salicylic acid to kill fungi, and the most important ingredient, zinc salts (zinc sulfate and zinc chloride) to give the body rigidity. The formula is 1 part glycerin, 1 part formalin saturated with both zinc sulfate and chloride, and 1 part of an alcohol solution saturated with salicylic acid.
The catacombs contain about 8000 corpses and 1252 mummies (as stated by last census made by EURAC in 2011) that line the walls. The halls are divided into categories: Men, Women, Virgins, Children, Priests, Monks, and Professionals. Some bodies are better preserved than others. Some are set in poses; for example, two children are sitting together in a rocking chair. The coffins were accessible to the families of the deceased so that on certain days the family could hold their hands and they could "join" their family in prayer.
Famous people buried in the catacombs include:

Colonel Enea DiGuiliano (in French Bourbon uniform)
Salvatore Manzella, surgeon
Lorenzo Marabitti, sculptor
Filipo Pennino, sculptor
Son of a king of Tunis who had converted to Catholicism
Giuseppe Velasco also called Velásquez the Sicilian painter of Chinese Palace in Palermo.
Giuseppe Tomasi di Lampedusa is sometimes said to be buried in the catacombs, but he is buried in the cemetery next to them.


== Scientific research ==
The Sicily Mummy Project was created in 2007, to study the mummies and to create profiles on those that were mummified. The project is led by the  anthropologist Dario Piombino-Mascali of the Department of Cultural Heritage and Sicilian Identity in Palermo, and is backed by the European Academy of Bozen/Bolzano The mummies are X-Rayed and given CT scans in order to preserve the mummies, along with other anthropolicial and paleopathological techniques to confirm the age, and sex of the individuals. Piombino-Mascali credits the program with re-opening the discussion about death in Sicily;  

For many years the subject of death was taboo [in Sicily]. Now, given the scientific importance of what's emerging with these mummies, people are understanding that in Sicily, death has always been part of life. And for centuries many Sicilians were using mummification to make sure there was a constant relationship between life and death.
Forensic biologist Mark Benecke identified several insects that shed a light on the process of mummification.


== Tourism ==
The catacombs are open to the public and taking photographs inside is supposedly prohibited, with prominent signs making it clear to visitors that photography is not allowed.  However, the bodies have been shown on film in Francesco Rosi's Cadaveri Eccellenti ("Illustrious Corpses"), and television programmes such as the Channel 4 series Coach Trip, BBC TV series Francesco's Italy: Top to Toe, Ghosthunting With Paul O'Grady and Friends on ITV2 in 2008 and The Learning Channel in 2000. Iron grills have been installed to prevent tourists tampering or posing with the corpses.


== Gallery ==

		
		


== See also ==
Capuchin Crypt, in Rome Italy
Capela dos Ossos, in Évora, Portugal

Having read the reviews prior, it was more or less as expected and worth the €3. As others have said, the lack of information spoils it.

The respectful displays of the many deads in various states of decay and mummifaction are a reminder of our own mortality. There is absolutely no show aspect to the catacombs; the Capuchins are just monks respecting and taking care of the dead, whether they are monks, civilians,

Forget the Egyptians. If you want to see mummies. This is the place. Extremely interesting. I was beside myself on the thought process of wanting your remains displayed like they were.

Wandering the mummified remains makes one wonder about one's own mortality and is a thought provoking place to visit. Well worth it.

Got to be honest I didn’t quite get this or see the point. Lots of skeletons on display in clothing. It’s quite a walk outside of the main sites but doable if you’ve got the will or the time. If your sight seeing I guess you have to go but it just didn’t really inspire me. No

We knew this was a left field choice, but we were still surprised by what we saw. Definitely not for the feint hearted or children. If you are into horror movies this may be up your street.

No stories, no descriptions, nothing interesting. Literally rows of bones, bones and some straw in clothes. Meh.
A fair walk out of the town and unfortunately just timed so they had closed. Visited the interesting cemetery attached with Ornate crypts housing families.

No need of many words.. fantastic experience for 3€ in Palermo. Make sure you are brave enough and .... MEMENTO MORI.

Macabre but fascinating place to visit. Not for the feint hearted but an experience that you will never forget.

Worth a visit to get an insight into the complex relationship that Sicilians have with death. Not for the faint hearted!

Not in many other place in the word you can face the death in this way Experience to try. Unforgettable

Very powerful place to visit. Makes you really consider mortality. Absolutely fascinating. At only €3 for entry its well worth a visit. No photos allowed which is only right showing respect for the dead.

Nowhere else will you experience a spine chilling ‘touch’ of those who passed away a long time ago. We went there with young children, which gave us chance to discuss the less mortal aspects of life. Having said that, I still believe isn’t a place for the faint-hearted.
Interesting in a historical point of view but not suitable for small children as I found it a bit full on skeleton after skeleton all dressed and very ghoulish ! Just wantedto get out .

Not as big as I thought it would be but very interesting and for 3 euros entrance fee really good value loved it

text.wiki:
The Church of St. Mary of the Admiral (Italian: Santa Maria dell'Ammiraglio), also called Martorana, is the seat of the Parish of San Nicolò dei Greci (Albanian: Klisha e Shën Kollit së Arbëreshëvet), overlooking the Piazza Bellini in Palermo, Sicily, southern Italy. 
The church is a Co-cathedral to the Eparchy of Piana degli Albanesi of the Italo-Albanian Catholic Church, a diocese which includes the Italo-Albanian (Arbëreshë) communities in Sicily who officiate the liturgy according to the Byzantine Rite in the ancient Greek language and Albanian language The Church bears witness to the Eastern religious and artistic culture still present in Italy today, further contributed by the Albanian exiles who took refuge in southern Italy and Sicily from the 15th century under the pressure of Turkish-Ottoman persecutions in Albania and the Balkans. The latter influence has left considerable traces in the painting of icons, in the religious rite, in the language of the parish, in the traditional customs of some Albanian colonies in the province of Palermo. The community is part of the Catholic Church, but follows the ritual and spiritual traditions that largely share it with the Orthodox Church.
The church is characterized by the multiplicity of styles that meet, because, with the succession of centuries, it was enriched by various other tastes in art, architecture and culture. Today, it is, in fact, as a church-historical monument, the result of multiple transformations, also subject to protection.
Since 3 July 2015 it has been part of the UNESCO World Heritage Site within the Arab-Norman Palermo and the Cathedral Churches of Cefalù and Monreale itinerary.


== History ==

The name Ammiraglio ("admiral") derives from the founder of the church, the Sirian christian admiral and principal minister of King Roger II of Sicily, George of Antioch. The foundation charter of the church (which was initially Eastern Orthodox), in ancient Greek and Arabic, is preserved and dates to 1143; construction may already have begun at this point. The church had certainly been completed by the death of George in 1151, and he and his wife were interred in the narthex. In 1184 the Arab traveller Ibn Jubayr visited the church, and later devoted a significant portion of his description of Palermo to its praise, describing it as "the most beautiful monument in the world." After the Sicilian Vespers of 1282 the island's nobility gathered in the church for a meeting that resulted in the Sicilian crown being offered to Peter III of Aragon.In 1193-94, a convent of Benedictine nuns was founded on adjacent property by Eloisa Martorana. In 1433-34, under the rule of King Alfonso of Aragon, this convent absorbed the church, which has since then been commonly known as La Martorana.  The nuns extensively modified the church between the 16th century and the 18th century, making major changes to the structure and the interior decoration.The nuns of the Martorana were famous for their moulded marzipan, which they made in the form of various fruits. Although the convent no longer exists, frutta di Martorana are still one of Palermo's most famous and distinctive foodstuffs.
In 1937 the church returned to the Byzantine rite with the Albanian community present in Palermo. Today, it is used by the Italo-Albanian Catholic Church for their services and shares cathedral status with the church cathedral of San Demetrio Megalomartire in Piana degli Albanesi.
The church assumed and inherited the title of seat of the parish of the Italo-Albanians residing in San Nicolò dei Greci (for "Greeks" those Albanian populations were exchanged which, from the fifteenth century in Italy and Sicily, kept "Greek rite" or Byzantine, language, customs, identity) in 1945, after the homonymous church adjacent to the Italo-Albanian Seminary of Palermo was destroyed in the Second World War.
The church was recently restored and reopened for community worship in 2013; at that juncture clergy and the community was momentarily welcomed in the church of the Santa Macrina of the Italian-Albanian Basilian nuns in Palermo.
The parish of San Nicolò dei Greci does not have a real parish territory, but is the reference point for 15,000 faithful Arbëreshë  (the Albanian community of Sicily historically settled in the province of Palermo) residing in the city and who professes the Byzantine rite.
Since 2015, the airport of the "Arab-Norman Itinerary of Palermo, Cefalù and Monreale" as a World Heritage Site is one of the monuments proposed by UNESCO.


=== The name of the Parish ===

By tradition it continues to be called "of the Greeks", an improper definition, since the parish belongs ecclesiastically to the Albanians of Sicily (Albanesi di Sicilia in Italian). Greek was defined - by to the not Arbëreshë people, the Latins - the Byzantine rite for the liturgical language used. There is, however, the increasingly used variant today of "Parrocchia San Nicolò or Nicola degli Italo-Albanesi".
It is called by its faithful albanophones "Klisha Arbëreshe Palermë" or simply "Marturanë" and in the non-colloquial version "Famullia / Klisha e Shën Kollit i Arbëreshëvet në Palermë". You can also often read the title "Parrocchia San Nicolò dei Greci alla Martorana", this to mean that the parish is now based in the "Martorana" and not in the initial location in Via Seminario Italo-Albanese.


== Liturgy and rite ==

The liturgical rites, the wedding ceremonies, the baptism and the festivities religious of the parish of San Nicolò dei Greci follow the Byzantine calendar and the Albanian tradition of the communities of the Eparchy of Piana degli Albanesi.
The languages liturgical used are the ancient Greek (as per tradition, which was born to unify all the peoples of the Eastern Church under a single language of understanding) or Albanian (the mother tongue of the parish community). It is not uncommon here to hear the priest and the faithful speaking habitually in Albanian, in fact the language is the main element that identifies them in a specific belonging ethnic. Some young woman from Piana degli Albanesi marries still wearing the rich wedding dress of the Albanian tradition and the ceremony of the marriage (martesa).
A special celebration for the Arbëreshë population is the Theophany or Blessing of the waters on 6 January ( Ujët e pagëzuam ); the most important festival is Easter (Pashkët), with the oriental rituals of strong spirituality of Holy Week (Java e Madhe) and the singing of Christos anesti - Krishti u ngjall (Christ is risen). On 6 December occurs the feast of Saint Nicholas (Dita e Shën Kollit).


== Architecture ==

The original church was built in the form of a compact cross-in-square ("Greek cross plan"), a common variation on the standard middle Byzantine church type. The three apses in the east adjoin directly on the naos, instead of being separated by an additional bay, as was usual in contemporary Byzantine architecture in the Balkans and Asia Minor. In the first century of its existence the church was expanded in three distinct phases; first through the addition of a narthex to house the tombs of George of Antioch and his wife; next through the addition of a forehall; and finally through the construction of a centrally-aligned campanile at the west. The campanile, which is richly decorated with three orders of arches and lodges with mullioned windows, still serves as the main entrance to the church. Significant later additions to the church include the Baroque façade which today faces onto the piazza. In the late 19th century, historically-minded restorers attempted to return the church to its original state, although many elements of the Baroque modifications remain.Certain elements of the original church, in particular its exterior decoration, show the influence of Islamic architecture on the culture of Norman Sicily. A frieze bearing a dedicatory inscription runs along the top of the exterior walls; although its text is in Greek, its architectural form references the Islamic architecture of north Africa. The recessed niches on the exterior walls are likewise derive from the Islamic architectural tradition. In the interior, a series of wooden beams at the base of the dome bear a painted inscription in Arabic; the text is derived from the Christian liturgy (the Epinikios Hymn and the Great Doxology). The church also boasted an elaborate pair of carved wooden doors, today installed in the south façade of the western extension, which relate strongly to the artistic traditions of Fatimid north Africa. On account of these "Arabic" elements, the Martorana has been compared with its Palermitan contemporary, the Cappella Palatina, which exhibits a similar hybrid of Byzantine and Islamic forms.


== Interior ==
The church is renowned for its spectacular interior, which is dominated by a series of 12th century mosaics executed by Byzantine craftsmen. The mosaics show many iconographic and formal similarities to the roughly contemporary programs in the Cappella Palatina, in Monreale Cathedral and in Cefalù Cathedral, although they were probably executed by a distinct atelier.The walls display two mosaics taken from the original Norman façade, depicting King Roger II, George of Antioch's lord, receiving the crown of Sicily from Jesus, and, on the northern side of the aisle, George himself, at the feet of the Virgin. The depiction of Roger was highly significant in terms of its iconography. In Western Christian tradition, kings were customarily crowned by the Pope or his representatives; however, Roger is shown in Byzantine dress being crowned by Jesus in the Byzantine fashion. Roger was renowned for presenting himself as an emperor during his reign, being addressed as basileus ("king" in ancient Greek). The mosaic of the crowning of Roger carries a Latin inscription written in ancient Greek characters (Rogerios Rex ΡΟΓΕΡΙΟΣ ΡΗΞ "king Roger").
The nave dome is occupied by the traditional byzantine image of Christ Pantokrator surrounded by the archangels St Michael, St Gabriel, St Raphael and St Uriel. The register below depicts the eight prophets of the Old Testament and, in the pendentives, the four evangelists of the New Testament. The nave vault depicts the Nativity and the Death of the Virgin.
The newer part of the church is decorated with later frescoes of comparatively little artistic significance. The frescoes in the middle part of the walls are from the 18th century, attributed to Guglielmo Borremans.


== See also ==
Arab-Norman Palermo and the Cathedral Churches of Cefalù and Monreale
Arbëreshë

Eastern Christianity
Byzantine Rite
History of Medieval Arabic and Western European domes


== Notes ==


== Sources ==
The Green Guide: Sicily (Michelin, 2003)
Patrizia Fabbri, Palermo e Monreale (Bonechi, 2005)
Irving Hexham and David Bershad, The Christian Travelers' Guide to Italy (Zondervan, 2001)
Ernst Kitzinger, with Slobodan Ćurčić, The mosaics of St. Mary's of the Admiral in Palermo (Washington, 1990). ISBN 0-88402-179-3
B. Lavagnini, "L'epigramma e il committente," Dumbarton Oaks Papers 41 (1987), 339-50.
