Another great historical site to visit in Palermo. The workmanship and effort put into the site is impressive.
I wanted to see it as part of my trip - the artwork is beyond words. The bakery above was so inviting - but time was short. The history was so sad.
The most amazing example of the Byzantine Churches and mosaics in Palermo. The best time to see its beautiful mosaics is the early morning, when the sun rays make them shining...

Another amazingly beautiful church decorated with Byzantine mosaics of the highest artistic level, absolutely beautiful. The whole interior seems to shine due to golden backgrounds of mosaics. It was not the first place we visited in Palermo but would certainly go there again.

We then went inside the Church of St Mary dell Ammiraglio which still uses Greek Orthodox rites and is a mix of baroque and Byzantine interior design. It predates the Norman Palace chapel by a few years and has yet more of the glorious golden mosaics.
A beautiful little church with stunning Byzantine mosaics. It can get a little crowded but the beauty left us in awe. My pictures can never do justice to the mosaics.

This is a must see if you are visiting Palermo even if only for a few hours. It is situated in a small square just off the street crossing in the centre of town and is a delight of byzantine and orthodox decoration. The ceilings and walls are stunning in such a compact space.

We moved from the relative austerity of San Cataldo (Norman church alongside La Matorana) into a Byzantine church with many beautiful mosaics. It was a great introduction to the glories we saw later at the Palatine Chapel and also at the Cathedral at Monreale. Well worth a visit

Santa Maria dell'Ammiraglio (La Martorana) represents the history of Palermo. It combines Arab, Norman, Byzantine, and Baroque elements. Like Palermo itself, the effect is uneven and even contradictory. That's history. Most visitors on the day I was there went gaga over
Wonderful church richly decorated with some of the best Byzantine style mosaics you will see anywhere. Simply breathtaking. Not to be missed.
Church is stunning inside and worth taking time to wander round. The mosaics are amazing, not too expensive to get in

The church is beautiful and if you pay for the ticket, you get a discount in the church next to it. Not everyone knows that on the opposite side of the square there is a monastery - well wort a visit as well!
This is so picturesque! The piazza is inviting. You can get a cocktail or coffee in the square too in front of Teatro Bellini.

Beautiful church decorated by a large ensemble of Byzantine mosaics. The interior is exquisite, the mosaics, frescoes were extraordinary. It was originally an Orthodox church, but check out the Arabic inscription in the dome. As varied, multicultural and interesting as most of

Amazingly beautiful church decorated by a large ensemble of Byzantine mosaics of the highest artistic level! Absolutely to see, along with Capella Palatinate, Cefalu and Monreale cathedrals! The whole interior seems to shine due to golden backgrounds of mosaics. Iconography is

This church is the highlight of the classic half day old city sightseeing tour and so easy to do on your own. The Church’s Norman mosaics are amazing - this is a great partner to Monreale and another must-see
The interior is exquisite, the mosaics, frescoes were extraordinary. So glad we saw this. There was a wdding a day earlier so we went back the next day an so glad we did.
Possibly my favourite church out of all that we visited, lovely feel about it, amazing decoration. I would say its a must see.

A real joy to visit. The baroque is a later refurb (though pleasing to the eye), but the mosaics and general structure are the originals. Having read about the Normans years ago, I was especially looking forward to seeing this church and it didn't disappoint. Paid for by George

La Martorana is situated right next to San Cataldo. Both churches incorporate features from the time of the Normans. The Martorana's colourful interior contrasts with the spartan San Cataldo but together they provide an insight into the arab-norman architectural fusion in

This church is a one-stop shop to understand the history of Palermo and its diversity. Highly recommend touring the church with a guide to get the best experience. Worth the very reasonable entry fee.
We visited in the afternoon and where not so many turist. We couldn't make the tour because there was a wedding, but we admired from the entry.

One of the most beautiful and fascinating mixtures of styles I've ever seen. Mosaics, frescoes, inlaid floors, even a baroque alter, this church has it all. You can easily see the changes over the centuries, all different styles beautifully done. A unique church and a very

A small church with great mosaics of Byzantine manner. The church dates from approximately 12th century and Greeks visiting Palermo should visit it because of its Orthodox Christian origin. Entrance fee: 2 Euro.

We had some issues here with overcrowding. At the time of our visit, tour groups filled this quite small church and their guides were speaking in different languages. It made moving around inside difficult, and it wasn’t really possible to enjoy the interior in a quiet way. I
Spectacular church, fabulous mosaics and fantastic attention to detail. Even the floor is fabulous. Well worth the €2 entry fee.

This church does not strike you from the outside but it is a small Arab Norman church with extensive, elaborate and intact gold mosaics inside.It is near San Cataldo in the Piazza Bellini. Light from the windows enables you to see the mosaics in better detail. You can see the
Don't think I will ever see another church quite like it ever again. Rivals the Cistene Chapel in Rome easily
A most beautiful little church. Amazing to consider that all these beautiful mosaics have survived over the centuries. A church not to miss

The art and mosaics in the church are absolutely wonderful, with a mix of Byzantine, baroque, etc. in paintings and mosaics, but the tour guides preaching loudly to their customers and ruining the view of the ceiling with their laser pointers should be banned.
Splendid mosaics in between the baroque paintings, wonderful to see Christ crown Roger II, the first Norman King of Sicily and one of the first civilized Vikings of his time. A must for art lovers!

Not much to look at on the outside, but this is breathtaking inside. It remains my #1 top memory from my entire 3 weeks in Sicily last year. I have recommended this little chapel to so many friends and fellow travelers, and thought I should add a TripAdvisor review too. The

We visited this church on our last day in Palermo and were so glad that we didn't miss it. we had observed the ceiling of the church through the windows on our first night in Palermo and wanted to actually see it from the inside., so glad we did.

This is next to St. Cataldo. If you show your ticket, you can get a small discount on your admission fee. I love the wonderful mosaics in all the Norman churches whose interiors have survived numerous earthquakes. Lovely setting and well-worth your time.

This was the first of many churches we visited while in Palermo -our entry fee allowed us discounts at other churches.It small but light from the windows allows you see the incredible mosaics in such detail -my favourite was that of Roger 11 feet firmly on the ground being
I liked this better than the cathedral for mosaics. In the center of town, this historic place was lovely

This church and the one next to it is worth a visit. From the outside the church does not look spectacular or exiting but inside you will be surprised. All over wonderful mosaics. The church next to it with the 3 cupolas is very different (much more sober). I liked both very

For its size, well, it's got an enormous wow factor. The mosaics are extensive , elaborate and beautiful. And as a massive lover of mosaics, particularly quality, high quality mosaics, this place is heaven. It's another one of those places in this trip where I went twice in one
Stunning Norman style mosaics and frescoes with an impressive pantocrator. It can get very crowded, go early!

The moment you enter this 12th century church you will be in complete awe. The Byzantine mosaics literally overwhelm you by their beauty, colors, and detail. The expressions on the Saints faces are so real. It’s hard to believe that artisans of any period in history could

Similar to capella Palatina, or Duomo of monreale in style, but smaller and more intimate. Partially rebuilt in different style during the baroque period, so look for where the two styles join and contrast.

The most interesting thing about this church is that you can make a good comparison between the byzantine and the baroque style, since they're so harmoniously situated one next to the other. For me it's a tie... Anyway, beautiful church and the 2 euro admission is nothing
Notice the mosaic on the right: It´s Christ himself, who crowns the king Roger II. All the other mosaics are beautifull.

Not typical western-world church architecture. I see elements of Islamic architecture on the exterior. The interior also isn’t standard western-world, but it is extremely magnificent. I have been in many places of worship and of many faiths over the years, and this one seems

Although the church is not that impressive from the outside, the interior is filled with gold mosaics, and Arabic influence. It currently is an Albanian/Italian church. Palermo has several beautiful churches, each with their own glory. Be sure to check the entry times as many

Beautiful church, i call it beautiful because there is Islamic flavor in architecture as the church was built Arab workers and when you look at the domes on building, you can totally feel it. Worth to visit

Situated next to the San Cataldo church in Piazza Bellini, this is a complete contrast in styles although also built in 12th century. The interior has stunning mosaics similar to those in the Palatine Chapel and Monreale cathedral. Do check the opening hours though which did

This church is marvellous summary of Sicily history in one place, build on ancient city walls, in Romanesque style with Gothic-influenced campanile. Inside are beautiful mosaics, accompanied by tasteful frescoes. Interestingly, the church is currently run by Albanians and so the
Mosaics are in excellent condition. Fee to enter is reasonable. Also see church of Saint Cataldo next door.

The next time I go, I'd like to attend a service since I read that it's an Albanian-Italian church that follows the Greek service. The exterior is nothing special, but the interior floor plan and mosaics are fantastic. There was once a convent adjacent and the nuns there made

The sober facade of the Byzantine Church has a beautiful bell tower as a portal. Its interior amazes by the beautiful Byzantine mosaics that are in the floor, walls, domes, in the Abside a fantastic Christ Pantocrator stand mixed with beautiful Italian frescoes

We were fortunate enough to be given a tour of Palermo by a couple who grew up and who still live in Palermo. They took us to Santa Maria dell'Ammiraglio, as this was the church they were married in. My husband and both agree that this is one of the most beautiful churches we've
It is another wonderful Unesco world Heritage site. Amazing mosaics and a lot of history . Built in 1143 AD . Easy to come by, surrounded by alot of other beautiful historic sites.

From the outside this church in the historic centre of Palermo does not look promising, since the front was redone in baroque style. However, inside the central part dating from the 12th century is decorated with magnificent mosaics in Byzantine style. This is one of the

This church has one the most impressive interiors in Palermo! It is decorated with stunning mosaics with golden background and narrates the life moments of Jesus. The mosaics have greek inscriptions because it was ordered from George of Antiochia and it was to operate as an

La Martorana a Unesco World Heritage site is a jewel that shouldn't be missed. It was originally built in 1143 and later enlarged in the Baroque period. It is a unique blend of Norman features decorated with stuccos and enamel work. Some of the work is very similar to that of

I'd heard so much about it as a jewel. And so it was! The feeling you get when you enter this ancient church is exactly that of being inside a jewel, with its lights, gold, colors and the incredible work of Christian and Arab artists, the mysticism that emanates this place fills

Loved it and this should actually sum up my impression. I did fall in love with Palermo and the Norman/Arabic influence on its architecture. La Martonara is wonderful... I could have started at it for hours.

We read about these two little 12th century churches and were unprepared for just how amazing they were. The opulence of this church and the painting/ mosaics are some of finest we have ever seen. Please be respectful and soak in the atmosphere.

A person can be overwhelmed walking into this 12th century church commissioned by the Norman king of Sicily, Roger II. He was originally from Greece. The church has Norman arches with a Byzantine style. The mosaics throughout the church were well preserved and beautiful.

Decorated much like the Duomo in Monreale, but on a smaller scale. Very elaborate mosaics on the wall make it worth a visit. By showng our ticket from the church of St. Catherine we received a €1 discount on the admission.

This building has been substantially remodelled in a baroque manner, but it is still well worth a visit for the remaining Byzantine mosaics. The Nativity scene is gently intimate, while the image of Christ in the dome is a breathtaking combination of art and architecture.

this church has it all - all the different styles in one place - this is a unique find - could have spent hours and hours here - so much to see Again if you get the opportunity to buy the ticket that lets you get into most of the churches do it - it is worth it
The church has limited open hours. We waited a half hour for opening and it was worth the wait.Gold mosaic eye candy beyond belief. What a way to learn the Scriptures.
At the entrance, there is a mesmerizing tower. Inside, for 2 euros, the splendid mosaics can be admired in half of the church, while the other half looks more recent.

You might imagine that a mere church could line up pretty poorly against the magnificent Norman Palatine Chapel, the Cathedral at Cefalu and the Cathedral at Monreale but think again. Magnificent decoration and mosaic work everywhere. Overtime for the camera again. Don’t

The church of Santa Maria dell'Ammiraglio is an 11th century gem. It is well worth the 2 Euro admission charge. The mosaics inside on both the walls and ceiling are superb. Right next to the Norman church of San Cabral.

La Martorana has a fascinating history but today its one of the churches where you can see the wonderful Norman architecture and Roger mosaics alongside the generational architectural changes which were considered to be more suitable as the centuries passed. Here are the
A friend recommended visiting this church and it is absolutely amazing. If you don't have many days in Palermo, make sure you visit this church.

Founded in 1143, the church was decorated with beautiful golden mosaics around the same time as Montreale Cathedral. Later extended in baroque style, it is now an Orthodox church, and well worth a visit.
We stopped in to view a wedding in progress. Was only able to take a few pictures out of respect for the wedding party. Another awesome church.
This church has a beautiful interior and it is so relaxing just to sit inside and look at the mosaics. There are two more churches around, so you can visit them too.

Palermo and surrounds has 4 astonishing sites where Byzantine mosaics can be seen. They are all stunning. Cefalu, Monreale, Santa Maria dell'Ammiraglio, and the Palatine chapel. Visit them in that order if you do the Palatine Chapel first it will eclipse the other 3.

Three churches in the same square seem too many. In fact, they are so utterly different from one another, they form a perfect trio. Santa Maria dell'Ammiraglio has the most attractive belltower of the three, an elegant, lofty Norman structure made of blond sandstone.

This church could easily be overlooked. For a small entrance fee, which gives a discounted entry to other nearby churches, you can see wonderful Norman Byzantine mosaics. You can get a little closer to them than in Monreale and Cefalú. The choir, nave and domed crossing have

This is one of the must-see churches on the Palermo UNESCO World Heritage list of Arab-Norman art and architecture. Apparently, the nuns who ran this place in the 17th century destroyed many of the original mosaics, but fortunately they left us plenty of masterpieces to enjoy.
The mosaics were beautiful and they worth a visit and paying the entrance. Be careful because it is not opened all day long.
Beautiful church with splendid Baroque marble altar and incredible golden mosaics. Truly special. Do not miss this. Unesco World Heritage Site.

Beautiful 12th century church covered in sparkling mosaics and dedicated to the Virgin Mary. It is part of the UNESCO World Heritage Site that includes the Monreale Cathedral and other buildings in the area. This church closes down for a long lunch so be sure to check the hours.
This church is really amazing, with its gold mosaics, its incredible decorations and its mix of architecture style.....
A Unesco world heritage site with fabulous architecture . A terrific mix of Byzantine mosaics and Baroque decor , an amazing place!

We didn't schedule enough time to spend here, which, like everything in Palermo, takes some time to get to because of the bad traffic. The area is quite crowded, so parking is hard to find, but it sure was worth it. A spectacular church!
This incredible and breathtaking church is one of the most beautiful of Italy......Never seen something like this. Don't miss it!
A beautiful little gem, crowded but a must visit nonetheless. Interesting mixture of styles, stunning gold and blue mosaics. Entry was around 2 euros.

The interior of this church is filled with icons and Byzantine art. The ceilings have magnificent paintings, the walls have mosaics. On this island of exquisite and abundant religious art, La Martorana is not to be missed.

This is a beautiful church with all the decorations in mosaic gold being the predominant feature. The mosaics are a blend of Muslim, Byzantine and western catholic styles and are extraordinary The visit took approx 30 mins and it was greatly helped having an audio tour of the
Outside is simple, inside looks wonderful. It is top 10 must see place in Sicily. Normally it will takes about 30 minutes.
This church was one of the nine arab/norman buildings recognised by UNESCO. Must visit when in Palermo. It is next to San Cataldo church, also not to miss.
Stunning interior masked by a boring external appearance. It’s possble to miss this superb church by the uninteresting outside, but don’t well worth going in.

Located in the Piazza Bellini, the church is next to the famous Pretoria Fountain and Quattro Canti square. Inside this fabulous building, the design and artwork is again sublime – The main dome features a golden mosaic of Christ and the ceilings and arches are full of frescos

This church in Palermo, Sicily started the construction in 1143. Superbly crafted and finished with mosaic tiles. Gold, blue and unique colours. Fully functional and we didn’t pay to see it. May be because there was a wedding service about to start. Must see church in Palermo.
A highlight if you are interested in churches and a must to see in Palermo. Great cultural experience.

This elegant church has simply superb mosaics. One of the things I appreciated here was that there were chairs to sit on and admire the mosaics from all angles [and to rest your neck occasionally!]. Binoculars will show up extra detail.
Wonderful church with amazing mosaics. We purchased the entry tickets for "il circuito del sacro" which allows discounted entry for selected other churches.
Italian Greek Catholic Church located in Piazza Bellini in the centre of palermo. The church is renowned for its spectacular interior, which is dominated by 12th century mosaics.

It was very crowded, and it seemed to be led tours from cruise ships. Still, that's not the building's fault so still five stars (blobs?) for a truly superb interior (well, most of it anyway). Ignore the horrible baroque frontage and the extensions inside, tacked on to the

Although it was difficult to find the times the church was open, it is well worth your time to try to get inside. Beautiful with golden mosaic tiles, this church is small and quite an architectural feat.
A lovely church, beuatifuly decorated. There is another church bang next door that is even more beautiful.
Even though they charge 1 Euro to see the inside of the church, it is very well worth your visit. You also have to pay to see the monastery - gorgeous garden and artwork.

If you want to see mosaics take the bus up to Monreale to see them in a beautiful cathedral, for free. We went up to Monreale in the morning, and then Santa Maria in the afternoon. We paid 7 Euros per person, but the royal apartments were closed so the only thing we were able to

This attraction captured my eyes immediately; couldn't stop taking photos and I just really loved this interesting architecture! It's located right in the Center too, so you don't have to go and reach the location on purpose!
Loved this Chiesa - take time to notice the 'old' and 'new' halves when inside. Both equally beautiful. We sat for some time just taking it all in. Truly stunning.

Absolutly enjoyed my time here. The Baroque style facade and the Byzantine dome was just amazingly rich and beautiful. The majesty and the lavishness of the interior art work and mosaics took my breath away. A fine example of medieval multiculturalism. Just wish I had the
One of the oldest churches in Palermo dating back to XI AD. Great examples of multicultural and multi-religon co-existance.

This is a peculiar church to visit. You can admire and take one beautiful photos from the corner that you will see from the fountain (Piazza Pretoria). I don't like the fact that there is a fee to enter and not donations.
This is another one of those churches that you must see when in Palermo. The baroque lavishness is amazing and beautiful. The architecture is a mix with a large Arab Norman influence.
if you are in Palermo then there are so many sites to visit and this is one of the major attractions
Even if you've seen a million churches, you can't not visit this one. The outside just doesn't prepare you for what you'll find on the inside!

This is a lovely old church. It is quite small but it's easily accessible, peaceful, and has some glorious mosaics which are a joy to behold. Truly deserves to be on the UNESCO Heritage list. If you ask you get a discount when visiting the adjoining church...but it's not well

The twelfth cent. Byzantine artisans were at the top of their form, albeit a little late for my taste. The size and proportion of the church make the mosaics accessible and personal. The gentle Pantocrator is full-length. The palm and fruit trees are charming.
Fabulous place to visit.Spectacular building and so much to see. It is quite busy when we went, but a must.
This is one of the top sights to be seen in Palermo and I dare anybody to be disappointed by the majesty of the interior mosaics.

The church of Santa Maria dell'Ammiraglio, also known as "La Martorana", is an almost compulsory stop for a sensible tour of Palermo, together with the neighboring church of San Cataldo. It is a typical mix of styles as you would often find in Palermo, result of the continue
This church has great and unique architecture and is easy to find, but after seeing pictures here from the inside I even more regret we didn't had time to go inside and enjoy that as well.
Located just behind the main square on Palermo this beautiful little church is a wonderful sight to see... Amazing
Nice stop for a quick look at wonderful architecture as we wandered Palermo, which is the highlight of the city.

Nice church good place to visit while walking round Palermo. Also nice piazza near by to sit out in having a drink. Visiting the chalked you have to pay for keep the ticket and get discuout in other churches.

The church was small but it was a beautiful one. By paying the entrance fee, you get a discount in other churches around. Go this Church first before you visit the church beside which has 3 pink dome on top.

Fabulous example of Palermo's (and Sicily's) heterogeneous cultural and historical background. Once inside, mind the top of the first column on your right, which bares Arabic writings (it was taken from one of Palermo's mosques and used by the Normans as building material,
This place is just amazing to look at. I would have loved a bit more of a tour, but to be fair I didn't ask. Amazing hand painted walls and mosaic flooring.
Very detailed and beautiful church. A bit busy with tours but you could still enjoy it. We got a discount from visiting the surrounding churches as well so it was a very affordable stop.

The beauty of this church is stunning, but I also enjoyed the history of it. King Roger II, Norman, had this built and it is dedicated to a woman who made marzipan, but made with Arab and other architects. Check the history of Roger before visiting this church. He was quite

Forty years ago I found myself at a wedding in this church. This time, there was another one! Visitors don't get shepherded out, so watching is part of the experience. The church is a lovely combination of rich dim gold mediaeval mosaics and later baroque painted architectural
While not as incredible as monreale or the Palatine chapel, a fabulous monument and don't complain about the 2 euros. Same for more simple chapel next door.

This is an absolute gem- amongst the best of Norman 'Romanesque' architecture infused with Byzantine charm and created by Arab craftsmen. Palermo was the 'poster boy ' of medieval multiculturalism and this intimate structure is sumptuously decorated with mosaics and gold leaf.
All of the church's had fabulous architecture if you like this kind of thing then you will love it here, every corner has another building to reflect the way they have been built...
This has to be one of the most beautiful churches in the world. We were prepared to be impressed but this far exceeded our expectations. A must-see In amazing Palermo.

The small church of Santa Maria dell' Ammiraglio is outstanding example of the mixture of medieval mosaic decoration with later wall painting. The whole impression is pleasant. Although not so magnificent as Monreale Cathedral and Capella Palatina the Martorana church is equally
The Norman Arab architecture and decoration is just spectacular - I loved the mosaic works here. If you can't make it to Monreale (and every if you can), this is such a treat!
Anyone interested in mosaics should visit this church, the 3 euro per couple charge is more than worth it

What it lacks in size it makes up for in beauty. We've probably been to over 20 churches in the last month in Italy and this was one of my favourites. It's also cheap to visit at €2 relative to the other churches in Palermo that charge more and aren't half as nice. If you go to
Gorgeous and historically full of meanings: you could spend a lot of time inside. Unfortunately the available explanation were too syntetic: a guide would be convenient
What a stunning church, with an amazing and multifaceted history. Absolutely gorgeous from the inside. Unique.
A must see in Palermo with a truly stunning interior which takes your breath away - the mosaics were out of this world!

My wife and I visited the Chiesa Della Martorana in Palermo during a two-week vacation in Sicily. There is a modest entry fee (Euro 2 pp) and the ticket will give the user a discount at some other sites, although we discovered this too late to benefit from it. The interior is

This church has a fascinating mixture of different designs and styles from various eras. The mosaics together with the ceiling paintings are quite unique. On some days local school children volunteer as tourist guide and are very happy to explain the history and architecture to

The outside of this church (old and worn) hides the magnificence inside. Easy to miss, or just walk by, but make sure you see it. Beautiful church, with many mosaics and sculptures...including the only known portrait of King Roger himself.

Along with most of the churches & palaces in Palermo, Santa Maria would benefit from cleaning works (not necessarily restoration as this would belie the ageing process) but it's definitely worth a look at both the outside & the inside.

A little late in the morning, we benefited from a sunny day that helped a lot for natural light pictures inside the church. The elements of orthodox decoration are beautiful and the mosaics are worthwhile of a careful look.

This is a lovely church; not so small except if it is being compared to the much larger cathedrals around it. It was quite intimate though and had such lovely gold mosaics to be explored. My young niece (8) and nephew (10) even loved it and enjoyed trying to make out the scenes

The church is characterized by the multiplicity of styles that meet, because, with the succession of centuries, it was enriched by various other tastes in art, architecture and culture. Today, it is, in fact, as a church-historical monument, the result of multiple

Santa Maria dell'Ammiraglio is a small church and it is somewhat ordinary on the outside, but the inside is amazing and extremely beautiful. The front of the church is the original part and it is decorated entirely in mosaic tiles. The rear was an extension (I forget the exact

There are bigger and grander mosaics in Palermo bit this is the best place to see them in detail. The church is small and so you can get closer to them. Less busy than the Palatina which is awash with groups of bored looking Italian school children

Unlike some of the bigger churches, the smaller size of this church brings much of the amazing beauty closer for a more intimate inspection. Centrally located it is easy to find in your visit to Quattro Canti.

Visited while on a walking tour of the city. Nothing outstanding about the outside of the church so it is a surprise to see such amazing decoration inside. History of the church is interesting as it was originally planned as a mosque but was later given over to a group of

This is how the inside of the cathedral used to look before the disastrous modernization. Marvelous golden mosaics take you back 900 years. A small fee but worth it. Note:Save your ticket and get half off at other churches
Special place with Arab and Norman influences off a beautiful, quiet square, with adjacent Church of San Cantaldo. Both are open just for a few hrs each morning and afternoon w a small entry fee.

Dates to 1143, built on a Greek cross plan. Baroque interior. Stuccoes and enamel art. This cathedral is nice but average. Nothing not to like here but just not one of my favorite places in Sicily. If this review is helpful then please indicate so below.

This church was built around 1150 by a Greek: George of Antioch, an admiral of Roger II. Roger II is a story in himself...check out his home, the Palazzo Real. La Martorana was built with a cross plan. It is chock full of over-the-top frescoes (1600s), and grillwork, and of

Such a beautiful church. The style is so different compared to some of the other Churches in Palermo. The intricate design and the blues and golds are simply beautiful. I would definitely recommend visiting this church.

This is an amazing place, beautiful on the outside but quite magnificent on the inside. A great mixture of styles - arab, baroque and byzantine. But what makes it so stunning are the mosaics which seem to cover the whole of the walls and ceiling. I have never seen mosaics of

It was pretty on the outside but closed on sunday. We felt a little insecure because when we went, the place were alone and there were 3 or four gipsies asking for money and they started to insult us because we didn't gave them any money.

This was an amazing church that I was not expecting. After seeing the cathedral in Monreale, which blew me away, it was awesome to see what is basically a smaller version of the same. Wonderful mosaics, beautiful stone, and a mixture between the arab, baroque and byzantine, with

Along with Monreale Cathedral and Cappella Palatina, this Byzantine mosaic and painted cathedral is stunning. The trio of churches are in the top ranks of mosaic sites you will see any where in the world. Right in the center of Palermo and near other attractions, this is
if you visit this, you can save yourself a trip to Monreale - same type of Byzantine mosaics (but without the view over Palermo)

A small church in the middle of the historical part of Palermo, that is a must-go when visiting the city. I was able to visit is for free, but the ticket is not expensive anyway and it's totally worth the visit. A small and interesting church from the outside, that reveals
Pure history and art in this church from medieval times. Beautiful ceilings with bizantino art, wonderful mosaics and relics from the past. A must see piece of art.
I was just plain mesmerized by the mosaics and the other art. This place is loaded wth masterpieces and should not be missed. Sublime art.
Just visited here. What a wonderful place. Spectacular inside and out. Beautiful mosaic work. Recommended for certain.
Just visit this....similar style to the Capella Palatina but somehow more intimate, with some different touches too

Impressive church, not only from the eclectic outside, but also from the inside. I visited Monreale and Capella Palatine, when I was in Palermo, but this church was the more intimate experience. Furthermore the mix between baroque paintings and the mosaics make this a unique
The exterior may not be inviting but the interior is breathtaking with golden complex mosaics. Worth a visit!
It deserve a visit as one of the most impressive byzantine catholic church I have ever seen. Spectacular interiors, mosaics,frescoes. In a nutshell "unbelievable"

This fabulous church rewards the visitor who spends time here contemplating its wonderful Greek byzantine mosaics, blended with later Renaissance paintings towards the back of the church. There is such a wealth of religious detail here, seen from the Eastern Roman viewpoint but
Immerse yourself in beauty... the mosaics are so beautiful. For us, a bit of a bus ride, but completely worth the effort! Do leave yourself enough time, and check the hours.

This church, in the center of Palermo is quintessential Sicily, an island which has been a colony foe 3000 years and where dozen occupying civilization built with their own style churches and palaces. This is a church built by normans but with layers upon layers of contributions

The exterior of the church was underwhelming, but that quickly changed was you entered inside. This small church gave us a small tease of the mosaics we would see the next day at Monreale. These mosaics were just as impressive. Another interesting thing was that the church also
This splendid church displays decoration from the 12th to18th centuries, from mosaics to stucco. It includes a famous mosaic portrait of the crowning of King Roger.
When we first tried to see it, there was a wedding going on. So we came back another day and we are glad we did. The mosiacs and colors were very memorable.
Lovely church on the inside. We entered just before a wedding was about to take place, beautiful inside.
Wonderful church ,nice atmosphere ,well preserved site.many other interesting places around .a nice walk from piazza Politeama .guru the main Street of the spanish Palermo .
You need to see it.Largely unknown until recently Don t drive there. Walk to this historical site You will enjoy it.
Came here to see, what a beautiful church so many details and serenity it is a real treasure around this beautiful city
This church is not grand in scale, yet the mosaics are visually arresting. The architecture is simple in style. It's definitely worth visiting.

When we arrived we only had 30 minutes to visit the church because of a wedding taking place later. But because of the wedding the church was dressed for it and that gave it an extra touch. The interior is beautiful with lots of gold. It's a bit bigger than its neighbour but

Really unique church with all its gold. Definitely worth a short visit. It is a small church, so it won't take you a long time to visite. Combine is with the church next to it and you get a discount on the entrance fee.

The church Santa Maria dell'Ammiraglio or Martorana is one of the Palermo's wanders - it is a perfect open-air presentation of sicilian's cultural mixture, of Arabic, Norman and rennaisance Cristian Europe, carved into its Medieval stones. Definetely a must-see. It is in the old
we didn't go inside, but from the outside and amongst its local environment, it has a really impressive presence. its also a lovely area to walk around and soak up what is a very local experience.
I found this church through Trip Advisor; it is well worth a visit. I cannot but agree with the otrher reviewers here. Stunning splendour ...

Sicily has a few must-see sites, including four churches with brilliant mosaics. This is one of them (the others are Capella Palatina, Monreale and Cefalu). DO NOT MISS THEM. They are simply dazzling. If you liked San Marco in Venice and Ravenna, you will be happy you saw

The workmanship is amazing and the total effect astonishing. Almost every surface is covered in mosaics, paintings, tiles and gold. All of that said, we have seen other churches in Italy, Malta and Greece that while not identical are similar in opulence and workmanship. What is

This church established in 1143 is an amazing feat of early Greek Byzantine mosaics with later paintings. It is over powering on first viewing but needs careful inspection to appreciate the workmanship. Christ the Pantocrator is magnificent. A small fee to enter and we bought

Visit this church and then the little ex-church next door - great contrast both worth seeing. Sa. Maria is decorated elaborately with many mosaics. You have to pay about 2 euros to enter, but get a discount on the entry cost of the neighbouring very early church.

A fine Norman building, with some great original mosaics - The main part of the church has had the mosaics replaced by paintings (a shame historically, but it has produced an interesting mix of art which in my opinion blends well). The later ceiling paintings show scenes from
Pretty church. Is a mix of cultures, mix of styles and arts. But as a whole is excellent. Definitively a must in Palermo..

A very small church near by other known sights. Inside the church you ll have an very beautiful atmosphare with a lot of gold and old art works. Its nice and relaxed there. The entry fee is 2 EUR and absolutely worth. The give you also cloth to cover your shoulder.

The church Santa Maria dell'Ammiraglio, commonly called Martorana, is the most splendid example of syncretism elements of different religions, cultures and eras! It features a lovely mosaic iconography and decoration and the architecture is an excellent example of Byzantine,

This church is amazing. There are frescoes and mosaics, the décor is extremely rich. It is definitely worth a visit. Ticket is cheap, there is student discount. If you visit the Oratorio of San Lorenzo you will get a discount on this church.
We stopped by this place when we were walking around at night. Don't know much about it but it's very VERY old and probably has some good history if that sort of thing interest's you.

I visited here after seeing it was the number one of things to do in Palermo on Trip Advisor and I was not disappointed. Easy enough to find, we walked from the port in about 25 minutes. It costs only a couple of euros and is well worth it. The mosaics and art are stunning.

This church is stunningly beautiful both in architecture and for its registers of mosaics. It is a must before you do the Capella Palatina or Monreale and to appreciate the sheer scale my advice would be here first, then Capella Palatina then Monreale. The church is beautiful
This was my favourite church in Palermo, small and beautiful with exquisite mosaics inside. I would love to go back if I could.

This small 12 cent Church is a real gem in the very city center, round the corner of the City Hall. First, it's dual facade. Apart from the Norman style which dominates the exterior, there's a part of facade in Baroque added in the 16 cent. Inside, again dual decorations.

Loved this church as, like in the food, is a missmash of styles but all come together beautifully. The church follows a greek cross plan, but you can see the arabic influences particularly on exterior. The inside is small but stunning and dominated by a series of 12th century
Lovely interior with large areas of the walls covered in medieval mosaics - a must-see if you are into medieval art

This church is definitely an awe inspiring church. The ceiling and walls are covered with the most beautiful mosaics with images of Jesus Christ, Saint Mary and other saints. As you enter the church, the impact upon your eyes and mind is such, you just do not know where to
The memorial chapel of Roger II's admiral is notable for the brilliant portrait mosaic of Roger II just inside the front door. For that alone it is worth a detour.

This is a small gem of a church in a secluded corner of the Piazza Bellini. So many interconnecting archways give a magical appearance. They are covered with beautiful Byzantine mosaics. The cool blue colors were even more beautiful to me than the gold appearance of the Palatine

If you only do one church in Palermo, try to make it this one that covers history, architecture, art and has a natural beauty of paintings, mosaics, marble and artistry. It's huge, with crypts on the bottom and the best view looking over the city, with great vistas from its

La Martorana is is the most charming of Palermo's churches in that it reveals splendid layers of history which unfold before your eyes as you leave the glare of the hot Palermo sun and adjust to the interior lighting of this jewel of a church. This is one of Palermo's 'must see'
This is a beautiful little church. The altar is really lovely. It's the ceiling of the church that dominates though. Every inch of it is beautifully decorated. Worth seeing.
At €2 per adult to visit the interior of the church it is well worth a visit. Yet again I was in awe of the exquisite decoration of the churches here in Palermo. Just beautiful.

This is worth doing if u attend other Christians services...the orthodox blessing is the mirror image of the Roman rite...for sure we saw the magnificent ceiling at length and for free...a multi sensory experience to say the least...plenty of Frankincense...is this full

I got a taxi from mondello to the church at 9 on a Saturday morning & I had read previous reviews & was not disappointed. The church is utterly beautiful & with the sun coming through the centre it creates a very special feeling. I spent 20 mins just enjoying the ambience

There are 5 monuments in Sicily with the same characteristics and belong in a unique architectural style. The Norman Arabic! UNESCO included those monuments in its list! The point that make them special is: The combination of Norman (baroque) style, with byzantine style and

Finely done golden mosaics, which light up a church when the light is right are hard to find. These are beauties, and can be enjoyed in their own right, set in among the baroque alterations. It's a very lucky thing they were preserved. There is much else to catch the eye in the

A gorgeous church whose mosaics bring to life all the figures, Biblical and historical, they signify. Minimal number of tourists and tours, so there's the opportunity to view interior in peace and for as long as you like. Gold!
What a surprise when you enter this building. Beautiful frescoes adorn walls and ceiling in this beautiful church. Takes your breath away. Well worth a visit.
Beautiful sanctuary with outstanding mosiacs and a wonderful architectural history exhibiting the Norman period.
In the larger church on the left, the internal decoration is fabulous. Stunning. It is worth spending an hour looking at the details on the wals. It is so over the top as to be very beautiful.

Ok this is the tip to do it. San Cataldo il next door if you do them together is great or if you want to do one and not the other, it must be this one. However do it before C. Palatina as it is similar in style and less rich, but still very beautiful, close by is Ballaro market

It may not be Palatine Chapel but it is still stunningly beautiful. So far I am concerned you cannot miss La Martorana if you are in Palermo. The church is not big but the interior is gorgeous. There is a small entry fee and photography is allowed so long no flash is being used.

Small jewel of Arab Norman architecture with beautiful mosaics of Byzantine Arab influence.located in the city center but with odd visiting hours.do not miss the adjoining church,with the red cupolas the San Cataldo, belonging to the order of the holy grave of Jerusalem

The Arab traveller, Ibn Jubayr, visited this church in 1184. He described it as "the most beautiful monument in the world". He may well be right, but a lot of water has flown under the bridge since his time. At first, we didn't know whether to feel overawed, enchanted or aghast

This is another church that has wonderful mosaics, unfortunately much of the original was destroyed by a sect of aesthetically challenged Benedictine nuns in 1433 who extended the church and replaced a lot of superb Byzantine decoration with gaudy, tasteless, baroque

I am glad I went here before the Palatine chapel and the Monreale cathedral, both of which overshadowed it in my memory. Two particularly good mosaics near the entrance. Definitely worth a visit if you are in Palermo
Pleasant church set near the centre of town, worth a look but nothing special of note. Some of the architecture is interesting.

The Arabo-Norman architecture of Sicily is deservedly famous for its multiple influences: Moorish, Byzantine and what the Normans brought from France. This church was endowed by a famous Greek admiral in the employ of Norman kings. Wonderful, glittering mosaics at one end and
You won't find a blank piece of wall in this rather attractive Baroque church, go take a look if you are in Palermo.
Worth the money and time to visit this beautiful church in the center of Palermo (near Quattro Cantti).
The mosaics and paintings are very well preserved a great visit if you like history. The church is behind an older church & has a tall tower at the entrance
Small church - but not to be missed. The decoration is so rich, tick, coloured...that it is almost touching. Check the opening hours.

Santa Maria dell'Ammiraglio is better known as La Martorana. It continues to be used as a church and shares the platform with the Chiesa di San Cataldo. The bell tower is 12C but the façade was originally Norman but renovated in baroque style. The small portico protects the
This church has wonderful early mosaics probably from Greek crafts people. The church is in use as achurch so visiting needs to be planned.

If you love Mosaics....well you are going to see this site anyway. Other parts of Italy and Sicily are treasure troves for this art form. Bring a pair of binoculars as you travel around Sicily, they will come in handy, especially inside the many churches that are covered with

This very old church features yet more of the mosaics so famously used at Cefalú, Monreale, and the Cappella Palatina. Parts of the interior were baroque-ized, but that only adds to the sense of a long history; the tower retains its medieval air. The church is immediately
This is the most nicest church in Palermo. This take a seat and be amazed bij the barok and the golden mozaïek. Definately worth it.
We visited on a Monday and there were 2 weddings taking place. What a beautiful experience. There is a nice pizza restaurant on plaza Bellini in front of the church for people watching.

One of the top sites in the city. Beautiful arabic- normand architecture, fantastic byzantine mosaics-- it's nice to see it before the cathedral and other top sites, and it's well worth the time for the visit.
really beautiful, you should consider coming in if you like bizantine/baroque art - it's an interesting combination.

We visited a lot of churches in Sicily but this was the most beautiful. While we were there there was an art class going on so it was interesting to see the various drawings of the mosaic figures. I really enjoyed my visit.
Special place, close to another turistics points. The church closes during a part of the day, get inforation about the timetable.

This interior incurs a charge for entrance. It is right next door to the sweet church of San Cataldo. The mosaics in the apsidal end are good but then then later representations take over to complete the rest of the church.
This church is fascinating and beautiful - half of it is byzantine mosaics, and the other half is baroque paintings, giving it a strange fusion of styles
The building is stunning from the outside but it was closed so we didn't go inside. The streets around are nice for walking and enjoying the architecture .

We walked to this church while in port on a Mediterranean cruise. The outside of the church is simply stunning. I would have given a higher rating, but the church is currently closed so we could not go inside. I imagine it is truly beautiful inside though.
This historic and beautiful church is the location of the Byzantine Rite community in Palermo. Beautiful Services - especially at Pascqua.
Must see it is a mixture between Byzantin and Barouque arhitecture The mosaique it is gorgeous . Do not miss also st Cataldo church next door to this one . So simple so beautiful.

Sometimes we should remember how close have been the Christian and the Muslim Culture ( Thought for both culture holders). In Sicily We know very well by Centuries. Just a few word. To show is better than explain. Go to the Martorana Church to understand it. So simple so great.
The slighter younger sister of the neighbouring church, admire the construction and the mix of architecture.

We went in, but there was a mass on, so it was closed for tourists. I took a couple of sneaky photos, but unfortunately we couldn’t see the whole church. It would have been helpful to have a schedule posted near the door, to know when we could come back. I asked an official
Even though small, a very impressive gem of history in Palermo. Friendly helpful staff! The entrance ticket gives discount to visit the neighboring church (Amiraglio Church).

This church was very beautiful, and worth the $1.00 Euro entry fee. I just wish we'd had more time to spend there. The interior of the church is amazing. We were with a tour group, so did not experience any problems with the door lady!

One of these is stunning and very beautiful it's the one on the left as you look into the entries from the Piazza. The other is much more expensive and is privately owned and is very plain but interesting because of the domes. The two are an easy stroll from central station

And 'one of the most interesting and fascinating Palermo, a treasure trove of art works of various periods in history, but also full of beautiful mosaics, among which stands out that of the dome depicting Christ Pantocrator. Definitely worth a visit!
you pay two euro. Can't remember which but I think the ticket allows you in elsewhere. fabulous mosaics
The ticket costs 2 Euro, but do not hesitate to go in! It was one of the best church we have seen with the mixture between Byzantine and Barouque.
See an incredicble interior of this 900 year old church. Do not miss it though i do not understand why there are still money changers in front of the churches of Palermo.
This church is a jem in Palermo (a city of many, many jems) Byzantine mosaics are incredible. The church of St. Cataldo next door is also worth a visit.
You must go to see the interiors here. The mosaics are gorgeous, I could not get enough. It is not as spectacular as the other, kingly churches you will see in Palermo, but you can get closer.
A small little jewel of a church, in which different styles are skillfully mixed, as if each epoch kept adding pieces to the building.
Astonishing Byzantine mosaic in a greek-ortodox church. The Byzantine mosaic cealing alone does worth the visit!

The other 1 star reviews for this church were just cross that it was closed when they tried to visit - rather like reviewing a west end show on its day off! - So the Church itself was pretty impressive, although not nearly as striking as San Francesco of Assisi around the
Again just the exterior of this extensive building.. There were some very shabby buildings in this city but this wasn't one of them

Sicilian friends recommended that I see this place. I happened to enter on Christmas day, just as mass was beginning. Had never seen a Byzantine rite service. Much incense, elaborate vestments. Very interesting. Spectacular gold mosaics, equal to Monreale or Cappella Palatina.
Not to be missed. Can combine, on foot with Balkaro quarter, to see the colourful food market. La Martorana is beautiful. Take time and photos! Not far is the Ballaro food market.
I especially prized the portrait of King Ruggiero. Had read about this church in Mary Taylor Simeti's "On Persephone's Island."

One of many churches at or by the Quattro Conti - it's beautiful and if you're about churches, should not be missed! Took us aback with it's breathtaking Byzantine interior (baroque also) - the mosaic art work was unbelievable! It was started in the early 12th century - 1143ish

If you have seen beautiful churches in Rome, then this is small in comparison. Yes, its very pretty and the workmanship beautiful, but not as overwhelming as I have seen elsewhere. Certainly worth a look when in Palermo though. I'm no historian of architecture or artistic

Although the Cappella Palantine and Monreale are larger and have more mosaics, this small church is our favorite...it has such an interesting mix of Norman and Baroque, mosaics and frescos...and even arab-inspired designs on the lower walls. We visited it once with our tour
Sicily is full of astounding churches, but this one should be near the top of your list. The medieval mosaics are breathtaking, and include the only known image of Roger II of Sicily, being crowned.
Our tour guide took us to this beautiful small church, with it's stunning interior. The Byzantine mosaics are extremely well preserved and very intricate.

Striking mosaics in the 12th century La Martorana prepares you for Capella Palatino and Monreale Duomo... How beautifully restored they are... Amazing art! The Baroque façade with the Romanesque belltower and Byzantine dome gracefully blend together without being even a bit

La Martorana, in the heart of historic Palermo, was brilliantly restored in 2012. While the exterior is striking, the interior is truly stunning - a unique mix of Norman mosaic and baroque. Take your time to explore this extraordinary visual feast!

DO NOT MISS THIS PLACE if you are in Palermo -- it has some of the most amazing mosaics we've seen anywhere, and the place is small enough that you could actually see them. Often, you are in a gigantic church with high ceilings and you need binoculars to see and appreciate the
I attended a wedding there, and the whole church was amazing inside more so than outside. It is very well worth the visit.
almost a small Monreale. excellent visit. well worth it. take 10 minutes to have a look inside. next to another church you must see

The church is richly decorated with mosaics all around and marble floors and columns, makes great contrast to the church next door - San Cataldo, which is typical example of the Arab-Norman architecture, which is unique to Sicily. I would say a few churches we visited in Palermo

I went to the church twice, as the first time it was closed for the noon break. The second time we arrived at the same time as a bride in her Rolls Royce. We were not able to roam freely in the small church, but what we saw was awesome. It is full of golden mosaics.
Must be seen Walking distance from downtown and historical sights. Don't drive there if you have a car. It is very difficult to find a parking space
Incredible breathtaking church, with rich decorations of the golden ceilings, and amazing marble floors. An incredible lapizlasuli altar that completes the wonderful sight.
lovely church so much gold in their beautiful church went on a sunday morning and was too busy with lots of tourists
A high point and must see for the Byzantine mosaics. A guide would be helpful,but guide books specific to the site can be purchased there.

The church is in the middle of town and near the information office. Entrance is euro 2 and well worth a visit. The bell tower is original from the 12th century. The facade looked to be a baroque renovation. Glittering Byzantine mosaics from cover the interior and around the

You enter the church by the bell tower and you will be overwhelmed by the baroque interior, decorated with stuccoes and amazingly beautiful mosaics. I have never seen such religious splendour. The Byzantine dome and the mosaics are of exceptional interest with Christ
I loved the gold Mosaic work in this small church which sits in the downtown area. Entrance is 2 Euro. I spent about 10 minutes here before I walked on to the many monuments in the same area.
Great mosaics here..very accessible.Paintings on ceilings and metal screens at back of church are also impressive.very pretty church.

A fantastic church with wonderful art and architecture, but not in the top 3 for churches in Palermo in our opinion, a bit too highly rated on trip advisor. Overall, a nice, cheap, easy to see attraction though.
Beautifull church with fantastic greek mosaics. But a lot of the mosaics have been replaced with terrible baroque ornementations.
A beautiful church which reveals the impact of history with it's changing architectural forms ranging from byzantine, to gothic, to renaissance. Byzantine mosaics in particular are magnificent.
This church has the most amazing artwork covering its walls and is a combination of architecture from multiple civilizations.
We just had to stop and admire this building. Looks great with those palm trees around it. Unfortunately, we didn't have the time to check it out from the inside.
Beautiful, historic 11th century church in the heart of Palermo. A real gem. Not handicapped accessible.

La Martorana is a well hidden gem that truly amazed us. If it was not for the proprietor of La Bella Vista, we would probably not have seen this jewel. While not as elaborate, regal and of the grand scale as Capella Palastina, Palermo, it's mosaic and architecture is
One of many great little Palermo church's, for sure not to be skipped. There's two parts see them both

I've been in Italy for 2 weeks and other than the Sistine Chapel, this is my favorite church. It's quaint and simply amazing. The mosaic works, the columns, the floor, and most impressively the ceiling is stunning. It's only 2 euro to get in, and the audio guide is free. Be

The Inside is really something astonishing as the ceilings are part Byzantine, part Renaissance style. The architecture remains Byzantine. The Church is just behind the city hall, therefore very central.

Must see in Palermo if you enjoy the beauty of the old churches' architecture and excellent mosaic. This one goes back to Byzantine times. Don't leave Piazza Bellini too soon. There are plenty to see and enjoy nearby

When they talk about Arab-Norman Palermo this is one of the cathedrals they are talking about. It is unique to anything that I have seen before. You must go inside and pay the 3 euros to see for yourself. It is worth it. It was newly minted on the UNESCO world heritage list.
It's in such a nice area, tucked away. You come around the corner and see it, and it's so beautiful. Must see

If I have to choose the one landmark to visit, this would be my choice. It is easy to miss it because of its dull and weary outside look, but the real treasure is its interior. The mosaic work alone is incredible and well worth the visit.
The mosaic work inside the church is incredible. Be sure to ask for the audioguide, which is available in English at no extra charge. It's very well done and adds a lot to your visit.

We were pleasantly surprised of this shrine church . The inside is very unique and spiritually uplifting for all . Don't miss the place and enjoy to view of the city below on your drive to/from the shrine.

The main church is quite pretty, but there are a lot of very similar churches in Palermo with very similar decor etc. I think the main attraction is the old Arab Mosque which stands in the same grounds and has now been converted into a Catholic Church. However, aside from the
Not to be missed. Full of history - and the only portrait of the man who built much of Palermo, Mon Reale, Palatine Chapel.
Very charming church with all its marble, afrescos and norman-arab style. Must definitely be seen together with nearby desecrated San Cataldo. Quite a contrast!

Thus building is lovely outside and stunning in. We visited in the afternoon and it was pleasently quiet. The mosaics are stunning with s gold backdrop and beautiful detailing of faces which look so real.

This was our first viewing of mosaics in Palermo and we were really impressed (little did we know what was to come!) Situated in a lovely square alongside the chapel of San Cataldo. Obviously very popular with the locals for weddings as we saw two during our stay in town.

The USP of this church is the Byzantine mosaic of King Roger receiving his crown from the church, an impressive statement of his conviction of his appointment by God as much as a need to impress his subjects with that knowledge. An annoying downside is that access to the church

In the heart of the historic center of Palermo, this church I believe is one of the most beautiful in the city, within walking distance of major attractions and monuments of the city, within it are kept beautiful artwork including admirable frescoes on the ceiling. The entrance
Stunning. An exceptionally beautiful church with brilliant mosiacs and quieter than Monreale or the Palatine Chapel. Don't miss the Norman/Arab church on the same site.
The Byzantine influence is obvious here. Great mosaics and wonderful ancient artwork make this a don't miss.

After our Street food tour on the last day of our vacation we walked to this church with another couple and entered at afternoon opening time (3:30 pm on Monday); it's a small but potent example of Sicilian mosaics, not overwhelming but beautiful; a 1 or 2 Euro entry fee does
Our first church visited in Palermo and one of our favorites due to the Arabic influence of icons and domes. Gorgeous mosaics on the ceiling gave the church an exotic oriental feel.

The outside and the inside were very interesting. Go early in the morning or late in the afternoon to avoid the crowds. It was easy to find. Located on Via Maqueda, a major cross-street to Corso Vittorio Emanuele, the "main drag" in old Palermo. (I use the terms "major" and

This church is pretty much as stunning as it can get. You find it in a wonderful square, from which you can already admire its beutiful norman facade, with an impressive bell tower. Then you go in, and you have a series of wonderful frescoes, followed by amazing byzantine

The guide says there is a charge to visit this church but I just went in one day and no one was around. the church has some great frescoes and shows once again a mixture of Arabic and European architectural elements. The baroque facade seems to have been added at a later date.

The church was commenced in the 10th century and has been altered over the centuries by various people and groups. The final stunning church is the product of these people and the various cultures and should not be missed. Entry is best in the morning, whilst the crowds are

The outside is interesting, with its mix of architectural styles but the incredible gold mosaics inside make this a sight to remember forever. This ornate church stands out in a country which has thousands and thousands of churches.

Mosaics from 12th century shone like new. Beautiful architectural design mixing Norman and byzantine. A small entry charge but if the money is used to keep it in this excellent condition I must no complain.
Amazing religious mixture. Eastern Orthodoxy and Catholicism overlap on walls and ceilings. Even elements of the Arab influence are still present.
Very nice church - great square and neighbourhood. A pity you can not go to the first floor. Entrance 2.5 euros.
+++ The mosaics and Norman architecture and the Byzantine hymn written in Arabic ---- The appalling vandalism of the 17th century

or after 4:30 p.m. We tried to be there at 3:30, when it was supposed to reopen – which it did at 3:45. By then lots of visitors had piled up. No doubt the piazza Bellini with its 3 churches is a beautiful setting by itself and the mosaics inside are incredible. A Palermo visit
at first we could not find the church...but when we did, wow, it was incredible. The church was very busy with tourists and was incredible to visit.
the splendor inside is a complete surprise! It's a ubique church, never ßern anything like this,merita mosaics, frescoes and baroque stuccos.
Beautiful and peaceful with fascinating mosaics and icons. Allow time to linger. Lovely stonework on the outside too.
Try to go first thing in the morning watch the light hit the mosaics, and sit quietly and wonder at the beauty of the 12th century craftsmen.
in the heart of the shopping area, the church's byzantine mosaics are worth a stop. most noteworthy are those of george of antioch and roger II receiving the crown.
In this little church, it preserves the Norman-Arab Byzantine mosaic work as well as the Sicilian Baroque art. Don't walk pass it.

There are many free churches in Palermo that are great. This is probably the best one you can pay for, and it's still just 2 euro (way better than St. Cataldo beside it, which I do not recommend). It showcases a combination of many different styles of architecture.
I really enjoyed seeing the gorgeous mosaics in this church. They were stunning. Too bad some of them were torn down and replaced with a painted ceiling that are not at all as nice as the mosaics.

The belltower of this church is beautiful and classic arab-norman architecture. The interior contains mosaics which are ancient. Unfortunately, during the Baroque period a nun tore down most of the ancient mosaics and redesigned the cathedral in Baroque style. Sometimes
The church was built in 1143 but enlarger later. It has amazing frescoes and mosaics dating to the 12th century. Located at Piazza Bellini near the intersection of Via Roma and Via Vittorio Emanuele.

This wonderful La Martorana has a rich legacy of numerous styles down the centuries, as apparent from Arabic script on one of the columns. The mosaics are phenomenal, the work of Byzantine craftsmen. The nave dome is filled with the universal image of Christ Pantocrator. The

Palermo has many lovely churches. Some in are the sumptuous Byzantine style, which is well known for its golden mosiacs with its spare and unworldly religious figures. Some are in the over-the-top Baroque style. This lovely church combines the best of both types into one. If
another tribute to God by the normans, this little jewel in the heart of palermo surpasses the great cathedrals of monreale and cefalù.

Unbelievably beautiful little church in the centre of the old city. The mosaques in the Martorana are something to behold, the detail is exquisite and the frescoes in the more recent addition are as good as you will see. It will cost you 3 euro to enter both the chapels on the

Small but beautiful church with intricate design work covering every wall and the ceilings. Nicely preserved, easy to view and the admission cost isn't unreasonable. A nice stop to visit along with the other churches on the same piazza.

The inside of this church is utterly amazing with the mosaic work. There is very delicate mosaic work that depicts folded/draped fabric that is truly a sight to behold. An example can be seen in one of the photos I have attached, what appears to be a drape of some sort behind
Interesting church with beautiful mosaics. Deceiving from the outside. Worth a visit. Smaller than most and very intimate.
La Mortorana is a small church but well worth a visit for the mosaics, just sit in the pews and soak in the feeling of this friendly peaceful place
This small Church is a jewel both inside where two very different periods somehow blend rather well ,and outside. The mosaics are superb and rival the ones in the Palatina Chapel nearby.
