Forget about Virruchia market, this is where Palermo shops for their food. Amazing fish market and veggies, meat etc. Mouth was watering as we walked past the stalls. If you're a foodie and love visiting food markets, then you must come here.
I wish we'd been self-catering in palermo after wandering through this fascinating market. It's a photographer's dream and a great place to wander while you eat snacks from the stalls

The Ballaro street market, which runs for 3 blocks, in Palermo is the best of the street markets for food. Fruits, vegies, fish and meat are the strengths here, plus a few stalls selling some general items like spices, cheese, bread and other groceries. Everything is very fresh
Ballaro market was typical of street markets worldwide. Obviously a local favourite for daily produce and miscellaneous products .

A stroll through the market is a great way to spend a morning in Palermo. Amazing sights: beautiful and cheap fruits and vegetables, seafood like you can't imagine. Enjoy the very entertaining vendors and pick up a little snack.

I love going to markets in foreign cities. Whether it's the fun of bartering in Istanbul or seeing how beautifully food is displayed in France, I really enjoy tthem. While there's nothing "pretty" about the Ballaro Market, it's fascinating to see the huge fish being expertly

Our hotel was very close to here so we had a lovely walk through the market everyday. There is local fresh fruit and veg as well as fresh fish and meat on offer. As anywhere where fish is on sale there is a fishy aroma however it is not unbearable and most times I hardly noticed

It's in a little alley so don't be nervous to walk back there! Tons of fresh produce and meats. Personally, we didnt buy anything but it was neat to go look and see how people buy their food locally. I would def. go back! :)

If you are one of those tourists who find misery, dirt and derelict "pictoresque" you may like it. My heart sinks for the people who live in those conditions. Put away the camera and ask how is it that things have been let so much out of hands.
The market is an experience worth having. We walked on a Saturday morning, and the sights and sounds were a "cultural experience" that helped define Palermo for us.

Messy, dirty, smells fish, flies on the fruits and worst thing of all, bikes going through every minute with meat, fish and fruits exposed, I would not have bought a single thing to eat from this market. Streets around have a miserable feel, trash absolutely everywhere,

This place rocks! It is loud and noisy and colorful and full of life. The wares are in your face and I wish I had a kitchen to use so I could buy those huge mushrooms I saw or the strawberries that were stacked up precisely or those olives that had my mouth watering. The smells

Today we bought fresh tomatoes, olives, mozzerala di buffala and a couple of beers, in an ancient market full of singing vendors with home grown produce. This hodge-podge, long, narrow market, is full of people, locals shopping on their Vespas, tourists taking in the sights,

Great market for fruit and veg and particularly fish. If you're shopping for your own cooking best to shop further in as big fish counters near entrance (Station end) seem to cater for restaurant/large quantities buyers.
If this is your first market, it will be great, if it is your fifth, then not-so-great. There is nothing here that sets it apart from plenty of other markets around the world.

If you want to see one of Palermo markets, chose this one. Fish and vegetable stalls, noise and crowd - all as you imagine should be on a southern market. Shame you can buy more as a tourist (unless you chose self catering).
Best market in Palermo. Noisy, atmospheric, cheap, fresh produce. Do all my shopping here and it's a real pleasure every time.

This market was literally just below our hotel room..... nice for a walk... its mostly a food market that at the lower end kind of turns into an almost car boot sale thingy?! the fresh fruit is amazing and soooooooo cheap. its just nice to have a walk and enjoy seeing all the

This is a great market with masses of stalls selling fresh fish and seafood, fruit and vegetables. There are also plent of stalls selling spices and nuts - great things to take home with you! The market is noisy and busy - but that doesn't seem to deter motorcyclists from
If I stayed in apartment or self catering, it would be a great place to go to get all fresh ingredients

it was nice to wonder around this market, the fruit and veg are amoungst the cheapest I've seen in italy and looked good quality. there were only men around which could be a bit uncomfortable, but I had nobody bothering me. a nice place to shop or just watch the others!
A very long street lined up with stalls selling all the local produces, fish sea food, meats, cheeses and fruits. Colourful and fun, go before 2pm, although many stalls are opened after 2.

To stroll through this market gives one a wonderful, authentic and local feeling, which is one of the things i allways strive to find, when i travel. Here you defintely get it all. It's loud, caotic, colourful and just an experience not to miss.

We visited market while in Palermo. Our tour group was taking overnight ferry from Palermo to Naples and we purchased items (bread, cheese, salamis, vegetables and of course wine) to have a meal for the trip. A very nice example of Italian markets that weave through streets
In my (humble) opinion the best market to visit as a tourist in Palermo although our hostess shops at and swears by Capo

This is a huge market stretching through mant streets. We loved looking at the many differernt and,to us,strange foods on sale. The whole atmosphere is fascinating and worth a couple of hours. It is also close to other sights like churches,etc.

A cross between a medina and a street market, if you like to look and smell and feel, this is the place to go. Piles of carefully arranged vegetables, fish stalls, lighting shops, curtains and shoes and clothes and street food and utter tumbling chaos. A feast for the eyes.
This market is overflowing with fruit, veg, fish & meat. Everything is as fresh as could be, and very inticing. the selection of fish is fascinating. A cook's delight.

the small streets and little squares in the Ballaro district are the setting for a abundance of impressions: fresh fish, meat, and many many sorts of vegetables. Sellers are shouting out to praise their goods and to attract your attention. Although frequented by tourists, also

Through a labyrinth of streets and back alleys you are suddenly thrown into the middle of a world that could be in the 21st century or back a hundred years! The streets are full of vendors selling fruit, vegetables, meat, fish, cheeses, bread and pastries - customers arguing

We stopped here for some snacks for our room - green olives, salami, semolina bread, fresh fruit. However, the best thing in the market is the place that serves panelles (fried chickpea patties in a semolina bread) and crocces (fried potato with lime).
This street market is fabulous and one can find great trinkets and treats. I love markets so this is always a pleasure to explore the cities oldest expressions of the merchant trade
Great street market, selling mainly fish, fruit and veg. An amazing atmosphere, full of local life. A "must see". An amzing array of different fruit and veg - things we don't see in the UK.

Like a giant flea market. Kind of fun. Best during the week. We liked the arab market. Both have interesting food and flavor.

An amazing array of fruit and veg - violet aubergines the size of your head; tomatoes of every variety; prickly pears by the barrow-load; beautiful, flat peaches; and the first time we had seen whole swordfish on sale. What we expect of continental markets and rarely encounter.

Ballaro is a nice market in Palermo, typical street market, selling all kind of food, vegetables, meat, fresh fish (morning only!) and any kind of "made in china"-items you can imagine. as in any market, beware of your belongings :) DO try: the dried fish, the fresh ricotta,

I've was there everyday until I leaved there!I love to see some fruits and the shop!I've bought a lot of fruits and tried so many Italian food.Everything was so nice,But just I don't like the meat shop!!
they say its like a middle eastern market - but it just felt like a normal italian market with the vendors yelling out what they have on special. If you have been to istanbul this will be a let down

If you want a small, dying glimpse of old Palermo, this is it. Open air, with scooters buzzing around you, great values on everything from eggplants to goats' heads. Do try and get there early, as the fresh fish and mat is usually gone before it gets too warm.

I was born in Palermo and trust me, this is Palermo, there you can find the kind of food that you can imagine, cocked and not, with the seller that shout to attract you. It's very populous so pay attention , is not dangerous but pay attention to your wallet or to your camera

Very nice and showing lots of fruits, vegetables, exotic ingredients, fresh and dried spices, meat of all kinds, very red pomodori, cloths... all together forming a surrealist kilt of a cook dreaming cometrue.
A wealth of choice, and extremely inexpensive. I tended to buy too much!

Ballaro is a lively market with impressive fresh produce and vendors of all sorts of merchandise. I think I was most astounded to see half a pig's head (ear, eye, snout and all) in a butcher's display case alongside some goats' heads. But I suppose people love and eat these
Wonderful and very big and spread out market - you can find everything!

Great way to spend a couple of hours walking through the stalls filed with fresh fruit and vegetables. Many butchers, with every cut of meat imaginable, and some unimaginable. Lots of fresh fish on display as well. A dramatic change from the sanitized supermarkets here in

Anyone travelling to Palermo should experience this market. It's an authentic Itailian market with lots of food and general merchandise. My parents found socks (5 pairs) and tee-shirts (3) for souvenirs for less than $20 Cdn. That was a bonus. But, the smells, sights and
Busy and hectic but a slice of real life. Don't go if you dislike the smell of fish n cheese. oh and skinned goats heads.
Very interesting and a great experience. Good way to see local products and local people shopping and bartering. The sights, sounds and smells help make it a real Sicilian experience one not to miss.
Great for a stroll among the raw meat, raw fish and remarkable array of fruit and vegetables

Nice market, if yo know itallian you can easily engage in conversation with the endors, very frienldy. Just keep an eye on the bags as after all this is Palermo. If you go by car it's very difficult to park as there are no parking spaces available
Not much to see and having to walk through a rough neighborhood to get there would make this a "never again" on my list of places in Sicily.
This is definitely a local spot with great people watching as well as great prices on very fresh produce.

I would recommend you have lunch at a small restaurant at the edge of the market called Salumeria. The owner is Carlo and no english spoken but of 13 days meals in Sicily on this my 3rd trip to country, this ranks among top 2-3!! Great food, great price and Carlos is a real
Brilliant market - fresh fruit, veg, fish, nuts. As well as other bits and bobs. A must see

Wandering around looking at the high quality food on offer is a joy and listening to the housewives demanding certain cuts of the tuna etc an education. Try sampling from any of the little eateries here, excellent value and quality
Great European market that stimulates the senses, with noise and vibrancy.

Typical steet market, lots of stalls selling fruit, vegetables, fish, meat, habidashery and bits & pieces. Sanitation zero. Defintely send all northern european health inspectors for a visit to educate them on how not to go over the top.

The most beautiful fruits and vegetables imaginable, interesting fish (many still alive), and street food (sandwiches, pizza, pastries). Cleaner than the Vucciria. Be sure to try some sesame seed cookies (biscotti regina) sold at any bread store.

We were lured in what was promised to be an exotic fish and vegetable market combined with old-world bazaar. Instead we found only bizarre. Outside of the fresh food on display, the only items we saw for sale were dollar store rejects.
A vibrant, bustling market sprawling through many streets. Here you'll find amazing fresh food, wonderful photo opportunities (if that's your thing), and friendly locals. This market is a must!!

Lots of variety as you view all the amazing colors of fresh fruits and vegetables, especially to see them in winter. The meat and fish places are equally amazing. The sellers are very colorful too - makes for a fun morning!

..it was fun taking a walk in here because there was a bit of everything.. we went there at about 17:30 and we got a real good bargain for a Kg of king prawns which we brought back in our apartment and grilled. they were really fresh and delicious!! it is very crowded and
very interesting food market. Colours, sounds and scents will remind you a north african market. Watch out of the bag snatchers, don't wear luxurious wrist watches, jewels and stuff.
Definitely worth a visit to see raw, local ingredients - not for faint hearted vegitarians!
Make this a definite stop on your visit to Palermo.

Walking through the Ballaro Market you feel transported back in time to Old World Europe. The sights, smells, constant motion and noise, the variety of things for sale is fascinating. We found the Ballaro market to be more interesting and diverse than the better known Vucciria

Busy, chaotic, smelly, abundant, alive - everything a market should be. This (and the Capo market) were the best things in Palermo itself for me.

in the mercato you can hear the sicilian dialect, you can find people who live there, and touch fruits, vegetables, herbs, things that are not for tourists, at first, but that are the very heart of Palermo. can lose everything but this mercato!
Wonderful place to shop and later cook at home. Nice people, helpful and sincere.

I was there in the morning and during the day and night, because I stayed in accommodation that was near by ... incredible experience! Market changes over 24 hours and always takes a different look and atmosphere. This is the heart of Palermo and is really something special and

Bustling market with a great selection of fruits, vegetables, meats, fish, spices and many more local produce and products. Feels like you’re somewhat set back in time, as you don’t have that experience often.

Huge large and beautiful outdoor market, take a long walk, here you can discover the Palermo you don't expect.  
You will be invested of sounds, colors, herbs and voices, reflections, to the point that you will want to stop to understand where you are. 
I recommend having lunch in some equipped market stall.

Really fun to see and walk around this local market. The guys at the stalls are competing with each other with who is chanting the loudest. Some of them are even scary as you wouldn’t see that anywhere else. The stuff sold there is fresh and cheap. For better price, better to be accompanied by a local.

Markets are not entirely my thing. Tons of counterfeit goods and lots of shouting. But for the food alone this place is worth a visit. If you're a vegetarian, Sicilian cuisine uses eggplant as though it were the last fruit on Earth and you will not be left out. If you enjoy seafood, try the octopus. Worth a quick tour.

Nice walk and nice market. Beautiful fresh fruits and vegetables. If wanting fresh seafood, go early. Nice culinary gifts to bring back like the cream of pistachio. Cheap freshly squeezed pomegranate juice and orange juice to drink on the …
Lovely market to walk through and try things. We went as part of a food tour and it was a great experience
This is something different. Go and enjoy market and it's street food.
A marvellous market. Authentic with typicals foods. You have to visit it.
As ever, busy but fantastic atmosphere. Great service from young lad on fish stall about half way through
Lots of stands with fresh vegetables, seafood and meat. Not as much street food as expected though. Still worth a visit
Little shaddy but nice
Is 💯 African market. I really like that place.
Every vegetable and fruit you can imagine. Every type of fresh seafood that Sicily can offer.  Street food I've not seen before.  Toto, we're not in Kansas anymore!

If you are in palermo you have come to this market and experience the culture. It's so fun.

As a cuisine lover,to visit loal street market while travelling is my interest to discover what's produce in another land, the food, the smell,the sound,and the dealers often refresh my childhood memory in China,shopping with my sister or …
The popular markets of Palermo are changing rapidly but here you can still breathe something genuine.  Multicultural and above all good food.

Such a big market with many things that you can buy. 
Fantastic experience!
Very quirky local produce market.
A place where locals buy their fruit and veg, good for better prices than supermarkets. Some stalls open most of the day.

I love this place, so much fresh produce and puts the UK to shame in my opinion. Loads of fresh fruit, vegetables and meat, fish. Everything glowing with goodness and treated with care by the stall holders, non of the chucking fruit on top of others that I constantly see at home.

Good local market used by locals. It's a cash place.
typical sicilian a lot of alleys food venders. and a lot of local vegetable
Amazing experience - for free! But you'll want to sample the amazing fruits and vegetables... and cold treats like Granita!
best open market in town for tasty, healthy local fruits and vegetables at unbeatable prices
Authentic.  Wide range of Sicilian products and fantastic streedfood flavors
It traditional market, you can buy vegetables and fruits at lowest price. Even you find fresh fish of different types.
Such good food! Get here early if you want to see the fresh fish.

If you’re debating between this market and Capo - come here. 
There’s tasty street food and nice people.
Fun to walk through. Variety of vendors, everything from cheese to fish and from olives to shoes

Super dope place. Very intense. Food isn't good
 But worth checking out for an authentic Sicilian experience.
If you enjoy open food markets with lots of noise, color and atmosphere, then Ballaro is for you.

These guys have to get electricity for their fridges.

 Great place to visit as a tourist but the food hygene is a long way off. Eat at restaurants near by.

Cozy crowded fun
Vibrant market with fresh produce, street food and fresh seafood.
Great bargains and great access to local traditional food

Culinary heaven. Much bigger than other Palermo market Vucciria. Mainly fruits, vegetables, Sicilian specialities. Also fishes, frutti di mares. Also small dishes ready to eat, snacks, freshly squeezed juices. Few tratorias. Few souvenir stands.

A truly wonderful market in the heart of the city
Nice lLove you please
Huge market, got perfect gamberini for very good price

Chaotic and sometimes bad smelling areas but when you are looking for fresh fruits and vegetables or other things you can't buy in a store this is the place to go.
Very Sicilian with all those Italian guys screaming and singing to offer their products and the trouble. I like it very much

When the tourists meet the local life. Nice spot to buy fresh sea foods/vegetables or grab a meal with fresh foods.
Cheap, fresh, variety. Beware of pick-pocket and always remember to check the scale or the exchange they gave you, they may not be correct.

If you ask me worth to visit? Ah well if nothing else to do yes.  Nothing special if you ask me. 
You get stuff from supermarket and not much safe as many motorcycles passing by very fast.

In Ballarò it's Easy get places to eat local food (as the sandwich with milza, octopus, fried fish and so on), as the typical Arabian market in the world offers all kind of spices and foods. Mandatory

Large market where you eat, drink and buy anything- I bought evening clothes for €10!!  S myst go especially for lunch.
Not bad, but it's absolutely not good in Summer because too hot weather with cooking and grilled food.
Adore BALLARÒ, I always feel at home whenever I'm at BALLARÒ.

A great experience 
Reminding me of Warrorot Market in Chiang Mai
Real sicilyan market. A must see place and eat.
Nice market nice place for lunch
Fish amazing. All kinds of sea food available. Also meat cheese and clothes stalls.
For all the hype, not that great of a market.  Bigger than Capo.  Good for fruits and vegetables.
Came across this market whilst on route to Norman Palace.  It was our last day so didn't buy any fresh produce but it all looked great!
Such an interesting place, the vendors like sing to each other, the food looks better than it's...too expensive for a market.
You can get a lot of different food here
Traditional market where you can find Sicilian ando some Africansand Hindus products...so good!!!for me one of the best markets in Europe💚💜💛💙
One of the most vibrant markets I've seen. Authentic and full of delicious things
Full of life and tastes place! Food, veggies, fruits, cheese, Sicilian bread and more! Only morning visits.

Good market! A huge amount of see food, meat, vegetable, fruits and another stuff! We bought the biggest  shrimps!! You can find lemons, mandarins,cheese, salumi,    a different  kinds of olives, capers etc....you can also eat street food. For instance we eat octopus!!! Amazing octopus...
Exiting and busy , great place to see the locals buying there essentials . Loved every minute .
So much fun!  Great food and wonderful warm people
Typical market, nice atmosphere, large, much more than Vucciria, definitely worth a visit.
Great place great food!

text.wiki:
The Ruffo di Calabria family is one of the longest-standing noble families in Italy. It was already one of the seven most important houses of the Kingdom of Naples; their notable members include Rembrandt's patron Antonio Ruffo, the flying ace Fulco Ruffo di Calabria and his daughter Paola Ruffo di Calabria, queen-consort of Albert II of Belgium.

text.quote: The lifestyle of Sicilian nobility showcased in a centuries-old palace with opulent furnishings.
trip: I loved this Palazzo. The visit is like travelling back in time and see how the aristocracy used to live 250 years ago in Europe. Silk wall coverings to every room, fine furniture, murano crystal chandeliers, precious finishes, exotic porcelains...A mix of rococò, neoclassic and
We were the only people visiting this palazzo, which still has most of the original furniture and paintings.

Small, fascinating, Palazzo. Lots of themed rooms, a range of furniture, furnishings and objects, some exquisite, some a bit over the top. You get a real sense of the family that lived here. For instance there's a tiny theatre that must have been used by the children,either to
There must have been immense wealth here everywhere you look in the house is ornamentation a real insight into the past

Unfortunatelly I couldn’t enter, since there were two nice ladies at the entrance who didn’t have change. So they have sent me across the street in a store, in order to change the money. Sorry I didn’t get to see it, be prepared if you arrive and don’t have small change.
What a gem! An eclectic mix of a life time. Just some wierd and wonderful, not too sure why some ornaments had mini balaclava's on, or the baseball bat with Jesus on it was about. But loved it!
Representing life at the top in the 19th century, this villa is lovely and gives an great contrast to the Vuccira market down the street

Interesting glimpse into another era. Written English guide to house is confusing and incomplete. The house contains a jumble of styles from different eras, not particularly curated or displayed to great effect. But then perhaps this is how the family left it.
We were very pleasantly surprised by this palace which brought back memories of the Hapsburgs' in Vienna but this one is less luxurious
A rambling and crumbly Villa left as it was when the last incumbent died. If you like OTT Rococco the fountain is a must (I don't!). Very quirky...

An interesting old palazzo with a beautiful Pompei inspired courtyard and fountain seen from a window. Furnishings and pictures etc. otherwise undistinguished, but still a window onto how the aristocracy lived.

Out of the way, but well worth the effort. Self-guided tour of "how things were" for the rich and famous. A lovely mix of opulence and practical, functional homeliness that even the rich and famous may have craved.

The Palazzo Mirto is a rare survival from the opulent days of Palermo, while many other palazzi are decaying or in ruins. It was the lavish 18th and 19th home of the princes of Lanza Filangieri, though the building is older, and the family obviously kept up to date with the

Definitely not be missed when visiting Palermo .. a super chance to re-live “the Leopard “ experience and get a first hand feel of the lifestyle of Sicilian nobility.. perfectly preserved Palzzo Mirto in all it’s past glory .. super !!

We really enjoyed our visit to this Palazzo that is near the Spanish Inquisition Graffiti Museum near the Garabaldi square near the road along the waterfront. We came across this wonderful snapshot in time while waiting for a late afternoon English speaking tour of the

We had a couple of wonderful hours in this beautifully furnished estate. As we walked through the rooms we felt the lifestyle of the wealthy. There is enough written information regarding the rooms that it made the experience even more enjoyable.We loved the details, tile,
Not too big, not too small, full of beautiful rooms, tiled floors and decorations. A charming house where you can take great photos. My favourite attraction in Palermo.

Entry Euro 10 ( also gets entry to Palazzo Abatellis ). Photography allowed. An interesting look into the lives of the Sicilian aristocracy. Rooms are furnished as they would have been when the last of the Princes left in 1983. Then the family donated the building and contents

Outstanding self-guided home tour that should be more highly rated. Absolutely worth the walk and admission fee. It is a vast house with amazing furnishings. We particularly liked the tortoise shell clad pieces in the collection. We had the house to ourselves and it is great to

this palazzo has an eclectic collection of furnishings,paintings,and decorations.There are many many steps to climb and no other access available. Unlike some private palazzos, this one is in need of restoration in many rooms.Nevertheless,it's worthwhile to visit

This is one of the few palaces which open to the public. It needs some restoration here and there, but it gives a nice view how the rich lived in Palermo. Room after highly decorated room keeps you in awe.

You can really get up close to the exhibits as there were no barriers. There was only the 2 of us walking around being very discreetly followed by a curator (after he woke up and realised he had visitors). You could get a good idea and feel of how it used to be back in its day.

The Palazzo is quite tricky to find, and we nearly missed it as there is another nearby with a similar name that is boarded up and derelict. However, it is utterly fascinating and full of rooms and courtyards that illustrate many aspects of a family's taste, history and way of

The house was not over the top. One could imagine living there. It is great that it is preserved for the Nation.

Felt we need to view a Palazzo during a short break in Palermo. Modest entrance fee and I think we were the only 2 visitors during the time we took to look around. You follow a self guided tour through the rooms using rather well thumbed printed sheets. We got copies in English

A chance to see how royalty really lived! An inside look at all the aspects of upper class titled living.
Nice to see but nothing really ashtonishing except perhaps the chinese room. The other saloons and rooms are average compared to many others I have seen.

We got caught in the rain, on the way back to our apartment on the next street over, so thought we would nip inside and take a peek. Palazzo Mirto is incredibly ostentatious, decadent, over the top and absolutely glorious all at once. The oldest part of the palace dates back

This palazzo is not popular with tourists: I had the place to myself on a Friday afternoon (lunchtime I will concede). It's a strange illustration to what happens to interiors and works of art when keeping the windows open to the elements and not looking after the roof for rain

An astonishing glimpse into how the wildly wealthy of Palermo once lived. Gorgeously appointed, every room is filled with priceless treasures and trinkets--a family's belongings in a whole other time. Like most of the other sites we visited, we had the place to ourselves. Loved
I was pleasantly surprised by the Palazzo Mirto as previous reviews had led me to believe it had become rundown. Definitely worth a visit if you're in the Kalsa area.

Again very little advertised and unless you know about it and where it is you will never go there. A palace untouched by time, enriched over centuries and arrived to today time intact. Full of the glory of decorations, objects and furnitures from 16th to 19th centuries. Very

An interesting peek into the lifestyle of the wealthy - another world. The palace has a fascinating collection of artwork and furniture. We were there during a solo concert and would have loved to have stayed to listen - we had no idea that such wonderful sounds could emanate

An intimate peek into how the landed and noble gentry lived. Many original items from 18 and 19C. Most impressive.

Beautiful old mansion which is in its original state . Beautiful furnishings, ornaments chandeliers and the biggest bath I've ever seen. Some more extensive information in English would have been useful. Toilets atrocious. However worth a visit.

Spent two hours here, going slowly room by room, reading the free guide & enjoying the entire museum! Beautiful fabrics & window treatments, wall coverings, amazing painted ceilings, gorgeous furniture & chandeliers... wonderful to savor this glimpse into the life of Sicilian

"time capsule" because the interiors are not quite maintained all that well. it looks like what a several hundred year old home would look like today - kind of and more or less. in this regard it does not come across as a Disney World view of the "Old' - all squeaky clean. it

Wow, don't miss this palace, it seems all the better for not being overly restored and as if the family left about 10 years ago. It is spectacular and actually quite hard to take it in in a single visit.

We really enjoyed this house with a varied collection of paintings, furniture and decor. Needs some restoration in places with water damage, not enough info in english, needs an audiotour.

This Villa will take you right into the time of the "Loepard", the last of the golden era of grand Palermo. The Villa is intact and furnished with many interesting details. The curators and are extremely helpful and happy to share some secrets.
The palace includes the original furniture and all facilities it had in the 19th Century. I know no better way to show how the Sicilian nobility lived at that time.

What a gem. We had a great guide called Anna - without her we would have missed a lot of detail, secret rooms etc. if you are interested in social history or decorative painting this palazzo is right up your street. Unfortunately no photos allowed

Stunning and the villa houses the original pieces of furniture, artworks, etc that the family used during their life there. It would've been great to have access to an English speaking guide as we would certainly have benefitted from this visit more. Luckily one of the staff

This is a very interesting place. There's lots and lots of rooms and two floors so there is a lot to see. It was fairly quiet when we were there so we could explore in our own time. There are so many treasures and works of art so there's a lot to learn too. We also saw some
It was nice to see inside a Palazzo and see how the Italian Aristocracy used to live. It is a little frayed around the edges but still interesting.
Palazzo Mirto is one of the few old palaces still furnished and gives you a glimpse of how rich aristocratic families lived in Palermo in the 19th century.

We went here on a wet day to avoid the rain and for a change from the churches. We were not disappointed. A former royal palace, unchanged for many years, with much to offer. Many rooms with a story to tell, furniture, decor, and works of art.

You get an idea of how the Italian aristrocrats lived. The furnishings and room decorations are rather frayed but you can get an idea of how it was in the past. Is it worth the pay and go see? It's depend on your taste. If you like to see the inside of palazzo and original

As a fan of Il Gattopardo loved being able to experience walking through a palazzo that has retained its' history. While some of the fittings are copies the overall impression does not suffer for this. Yes, it is limited access currently but, there is a phased restoration and
We enjoyed the visit especially as aged EU citizens we got in free. The ceilings on the first floor were lovely. The private apartments on the second were rather dreary & where did they sleep?
Went here almost by accident as it scarcely gets a mention in the guide books. A 18th century aristocratic town house with the interior just as it used to be. Plans for restoration but see it now!

We forgot about siesta time and had to wait a short while before being allowed in but this was a treasure worth waiting for. A superbly decorated and preserved Sicilian villa in the centre of Palermo the Palazzo Mirto is hidden behind Carrefour's supermarket. It has a rich

Opulence and decay in one- I've spent there good hour or so. Unfortunately taking pictures is not allowed and guides don't speak English, but still, it's not to be missed. Make sure to take some small change for the tickets.

One of the best things we did on this trip to palermo (our 2nd visit). Gives you the opportunity to see what life was like for the very wealthy in this city. Such extravagance and beauty! It's really worth seeing

We were recommended this by the owner of the Bagheria villa where we stayed in one of the 'cottages', as it had been in her family before being given to the State. I'm very pleased she did as it was one of the highlights of our visit to Palermo. This is one of the few palazzi

At just €2 to enter it is a fantastic museum. It has not been recreated in quite the original fashion as when it was occupied by the original family, but more as a reference to the styles of the periods and as examples of the magnificent artifacts once in private ownership and
Enjoyed the artifacts, but wasn't really set up like when the family lived there. We used a printed self-guide in English that described some special items in each room, but there was so much more.

its a magnificent Palazzo in the centre of Palermo. you can park 2 minutes away in Piazza Marina a walk to the palazzo. fantastic baroc decoration, shame you cant take phots and no guide available, i would certanly go back.

Never did manage to see this as despite being listed in our guide book as open daily it was, along with a number of other places we had hoped to see, closed on Sunday afternoon and Monday.

The only drawback was that one is not allowed to take photos inside. This however meant I spent my time admiring the many rooms and their contents with no distractions. It really felt as if I had walked onto the sets of "Il Gattopardo" and would find Burt Lancaster reading a
Very nice building with nice furniture.all the furniture desgin for each room seprately and completly special for that room and all together nice to visit

As i walked and gazed inside this beautiful historical museum of a mansion embellished with history, elegance, and mystery; I couldn't help but ask questions and be curious about how the family had inherited such richness through generations, such masterful, cultural antiques.

We went through in early December 2012 and were the only visitors in the museum. It was definitely worth the time to see how the ruling class lived. We were the only people being escorted by our guide and, since it was a quiet day for them, it let us into the dining room which

I was in Palermo on 1st January. The most of the shops and museums were closed but Mirto Palazzo was open!! The rooms were well decorated and well maintained. I was impressed at carriages outside also.

Palazzo Mirto is a few yards from Piazza Marina on Via Merlo in La Kalsa. We were not sure what to expect (we were the only visitors) but it turned out to be a real treasure. We were accompanied by an attendant over two floors of a richly furnished aristocratic palace which just
An extraordinary building with superb furniture, porcelain and glass and interesting pictures. We were there about 2 hours.

That was the year that the da Mirto family gave up the Palazzo to the city. And it appears to have stayed precisely the same since then. It's a fascinating place, a real insight into how the well-off of the 19th century lived...and how they could run out of money to support

We visited this old palazzo as we were wandering the streets of Palermo. It was the home of a rich family who have only fairly recently moved on (probably to some tax haven!) It has the feeling of a family home with photos dotted around and no doubt was the scene of lavish

Take a fascinating step back in time, as you stroll through the sumptuously decorated rooms of Palazzo Mirto. Though the staff seems bored and are not particularly helpful, the beautiful palazzo speaks for itself. Highly recommended.

I agree with all the other reviews and wish they had English brochures so I could learn more about the place but it was a fascinating visit nevertheless because it gave me a glimpse a different side of Palermo. I find Palermo very complex - it has a kind of delapidated charm

One of the most interesting aspects were the rather eclectic range of books in many shelves. Many in German, Schiller and works on German art etc., some in English - 12 Vols.of David Hume's History of England, "10Years Captivity in the Mahdi's Camp 1882-1892" by Major Wingate,

A brilliant yet sad tour of a Princes Palace in a tucked away part of Palermo. We had a personal tour as no one else was visiting at the time. Brilliant insights into the lives of the aristocracy in Palermo.

It was interesting to see how this mansion was maintained. One could get the obvious sense of wealth but the collections seemed disjointed as if collecting without a purpose. We did not have a guide to help us so relied on the tour books. Were not allowed to take pictures

One of the most beautiful hidden treasures of Palermo. It took us some time to find it, which, in some way, added to its breathtaking charm. Ok, there is no information in English and no English-speaking guide on hand, but that didn't cause us any problems. In fact it was quite

we would have appreciated some information regarding the history of this palace, but the guides didn't speak English or have brochures with a floor plan to give us an idea of the size. All in all, I don't think they were too interested in tourists. Well worth a visit in any

Nice collection a little off the beaten track. Worth the side-step if you like antiques
Although in some rooms the decor is falling apart and clearly needs restoration the Palazzo is great. It reflects what it must have been to live as a noble in excess. Now impossible to sustain.
Stunning, impressive interiors and furnishings.Every room, every corner is to be discovered
Really nice and interesting. Self visit, with good documentation provided describing each each room.
An interesting surprise. The outside doesn't match with what is inside. Grandeur from the past. Absolutely worthy to spend your time there. Took me more than an hour and I enjoyed every minute of it.

It looks stunning from outside.  From architecture to ceramics, this palace allows you to travel through centuries of history. I loved the ceramic collection.
Dreamy palazzo inhabited by the princess up to recent decades. The throne room is most impressive with brocade wallpaper. At 5euros its a bargain and more impressive than most other palazzi in Palermo.
Great building with beautiful interior decoration and lots of old furniture. The place is like a giant puzzle with tiny rooms all over the place. Some wonderful ceilings and interesting furniture.
Very opulent and elegant.  I recommend to visit!
Very beautyfull place
Great experience
Must see when in Palermo. Excellent for families with kids
Fantastic!

text.wiki:
The Church of San Cataldo is a Catholic church located at Piazza Bellini in central Palermo, Sicily, Italy. Erected in 1154 as a notable example of the Arab-Norman architecture which flourished in Sicily under Norman rule on the island, the church is annexed to that of Santa Maria dell'Ammiraglio. Since the 1930s, it belongs to the Order of the Holy Sepulchre. 
In 2015, it received status as a World Heritage site.


== History and overview ==

Founded around 1160 by admiral Majone di Bari, in the 18th century the church was used as a post office. In the 19th century it was restored and brought back to a form more similar to the original Mediaeval edifice.
It has a rectangular plan with blind arches, partially occupied by windows. The ceiling has three characteristics red, bulge domes (cubole) and Arab-style merlons. The church provides a typical example of the Arab-Norman architecture, which is unique to Sicily. The plan of the church shows the predilection of the Normans for simple and severe forms, derived from their military formation. Moreover, the building shows how international the language of Norman architecture was at the time, as the vocabulary which marks parts of the church, like the bell tower, can be tracked down in coeval buildings like the cathedral of Laon and the Abbaye aux Dames in Caen, both in Northern France, or the cathedral of Durham in England. At the same time, the church shows features shared by Islamic and Byzantine architecture, such as the preference for cubic forms, the blind arches which articulate the external walls of the church and the typical spherical red domes on the roof.
The interior has a nave with two aisles. The naked walls are faced by spolia columns with Byzantine style arcades. The pavement is the original one and has a splendid mosaic decoration. Also original is the main altar.
The old City Wall can be seen running underneath the Church.


== See also ==
Arab-Norman Palermo and the Cathedral Churches of Cefalù and Monreale
History of Medieval Arabic and Western European domes

trip:
Overview This small church of San Cataldo was built in 1160, during the Norman occupation of Palermo. Address:
Piazza Bellini, Palermo, Sicily ItalyMap

After visiting the famous neighbor Santa Maria dell'Ammiraglio, aka La Martorana make a short stop. The Outside is under construction but you still can see the three cupolas. Mignon, delicate and very beautiful, a perfect place to think, admire, pray.

I stopped in here on a photography tour and really enjoyed taking a moment to sit and enjoy the inside of this church, which is fairly unique. The ticket was 2.20 euro and apparently I could have used it for several other sites along the “Route of the Sacred.”
Powerful in its simplicity and very spiritual. Amazing history of this church. Stone work inside amazing.

This small Norman chapel a wonderful. Plain, without adornment and almost stark in its simplicity. You feel you are transported back in time. A real contrast to its decorated neighbour. There is a small admission charge but really no more than a donation. The ticket gives a
So many beautiful churches in Palermo, this one is set spectacularly a bit above the Bellini square, which makes it especially beautiful.

This church is one of the early churches started around 1160 and is very Norman in appearance, although the red bulge domes show Islamic and Byzantine influences. This was inevitable in a city where Muslims and Christians, among others lived in harmony for many years under the

San Cataldo is the oldest church on Piazza Bellini. Unlike La Martorana next to it, it was not stylistically upgraded over time. It is a pure example of 12th Century architecture and Christianity, a simple and sparsely decorated space that invites quiet meditation and prayer.

This church is built in the 12 Century and relatively (compared to many around it) unadorned. Visited two years ago whilst it was being repaired. Repairs now finished and it is a lovely peaceful haven

Although small, this is a building of such historic importance that no traveller to Palermo should miss it. The fabric has been very sensitively restored by the Knights of the Holy Sepulchre, whose chapel it is.

San Cataldo is situated right next to the La Martorana church, very near the Quattro Canti intersection. For anyone on his way to visit the Cathedral and the Norman Palace, a short stop at San Cataldo and La Martorana is worthwhile and recommended.

The outside of this church is Norman with Muslim influence, the inside a combination of Byzantine-style mosaic, frescoes and more modern statues and altar, Baroque-style, combining to form very rich decoration. Less impressive than Capella Palatina, but definitely worth a visit.

This old church is perhaps worth a view if you find this kind of church architecture interesting. The interior is very plain and stark.The adjacent Martorana church of the same era is far more interesting and truly gorgeous and only costs €2 entry.
Val and I came upon this place while looking for La Martorano. It’s a little different from all the highly decorated churches we’ve been to which makes it interesting and very worth the stop.

We visited this church while in Piazza Bellini and were glad we did. we had originally thought it was Arab Mosque because of the strange domes but it was a chapel built by a rich mnfor n]himself. Too bad they 'washed' to for public use yers ago. It was probably spectacular on

Unlike most of the churches in this style, the mosaics and other decoration is gone. This demonstrates how heavy the walls and how small the windows were. I found that quite interesting. As there were few crowds, you can sit quietly for a few minutes and contemplate the

For architecture's sake I had to see this one. Not garishly decorated but a wonderful blend of Arab and Norman confluence that make one see Palermo's history. Best photo op is from the 2nd floor of the Parliament building!

Spare but wonderful. Ancient and distinctive. See it at different times of day. We did. The light changes how it looks even more than the typical church. It has a tremendous spirituality, as far as I am concerned. If I lived in Palermo, this is where I would pray. Right next to

I had been in this church before but the rest of the group had not so we went in. It is a nice Church but they should collect donations rather than charging to enter. The exterior is the main appeal to this church.

Built in 12th century and originally a chapel of a palazzo, this church in the Arab-Norman style is a complete contrast to the other churches nearby. Very plain inside with no works of art or statues and just some small, high windows and mosaic flooring, it is the beauty of the

Both the exterior and the interior of San Cataldo are very simple. However, this small church has its charm in showing the walls, arches, vaults and stone domes with a beautifully decorated floor with a large mosaic of white marble with colored tiles

As a contrast to the ugly rebuilding in Baroque style of La Martorana, its neighbour San Cataldo also dating from the12th century is almost untouched. The interior is serene; there are no mosaic decorations, but the Arab-Norman architecture makes it very interesting!

The marvel of this church is its simplicity and austerity. Small windows, no big paintings or statues give to this intimate chapel the sense of peace and communion with divinity so missed in our days. A must see in Palermo.

This is in my opinion one of the most beautiful sites and views of Palermo city. This very old church has a mixture of roman, gothic and arabic architecture. With the palm tree in front and the arabic (eunuch) cupolas it looks very exotic. Very simple and though so beautiful to
There was a fee charge to enter the Church of San Cataldo. I had never encounter this before. I did not think the Catholic Church allowed such practices..

Built in the 12th century this Arab-Norman church belongs to the Papal Order of the Knights of the Holy Sepulchre of Jerusalem. This church is in the heart of Palermo and is next to the Unesco site of La Martorana and across the square from Santa Caterina. The Church is not

I like this little chapel. It has virtually no decoration inside but the architecture is truly fascinating. Each of the columns has a different capitol and the sheer simplicity helps it to feel more personal and spiritual.

Unlike so many Palermo churches, it's the plain interior of this building that makes it so special. Rather than wall mosaics, admire the plain but elegant stone work and the 3 beautifull domes. Also look down at what's under your feet..

I loved this little church because it is so different from anything else in the area. The very plain architecture is Arab-Norman from the 12th century. Since the 1930's it belongs to the Order of the Holy Sepulchre.
I loved this little church - from it's unique external to its very understated internal yet architecturally interesting internal structure
After all the baroque churches we visited this little church was utter bliss. Absolutely unadorned and in its simplicity quite enchanting. A place for reflection and peace. A Must-See in Palermo
This probably looks more impressive from outside, în terms of architecture. Inside it is very simple, no painting, no mosaic, but peaceful beauty.

A very small church - but one that utterly enchants. The light diffused through the small windows in the dome, the reflective quality of the stone and marble columns, the sheer simplicity of the space fulfills its function perfectly. Add in the beauty of the mosaic floor and you
The church of San Cataldo looks like a mosque because Arab architects designed it. It is actually Norman. The inside is quite stark with little decoration.
San Cetaldo, unlike other churches of the period, is devoid of mosaics. It has a slightly austere beauty to it. There is little to see beyond the architecture, but it is a gem.

This tiny church, which during the nineteenth century did duty as a post office, was well worth a visit. Of great age and architectural interest it stands in complete contrast to the many baroque churches which you can find all over Palermo. Mérite un détour !

No worth it as a destination in itself but worth it of you are visiting La Martorana next door. It's interesting to see an undecorated Arab Norman church and compare with the amazing mosaic of the the other Arab Norman churches.

one of few such old churches in the world. moving and humbling. i do not wantn to add. worth siting a little and reflect

sights.name: Sanctuary of Santa Rosalia in Monte Pellegrino

text.wiki:
Saint Rosalia (1130–1166), also called La Santuzza or "The Little Saint", and in Sicilian as "Rusulia", is the patron saint of Palermo in Italy, and three towns in Venezuela: El Hatillo, Zuata, and Anzoátegui. She is especially important internationally as a saint invoked in times of plague (disease). Today she is being invoked by the citizens of Palermo to protect the city from Covid-19.


== Biography ==

Rosalia was born of a Norman noble family that claimed descent from Charlemagne. Devoutly religious, she retired to live as a hermit in a cave on Mount Pellegrino, where she died alone in 1166. Tradition says that she was led to the cave by two angels. On the cave wall she wrote "I, Rosalia, daughter of Sinibald, Lord of Roses, and Quisquina, have taken the resolution to live in this cave for the love of my Lord, Jesus Christ."


== 1624 plague ==
In 1624, a plague beset Palermo. During this hardship Saint Rosalia appeared first to a sick woman, then to a hunter, to whom she indicated where her remains were to be found. She ordered him to bring her bones to Palermo and have them carried in procession through the city.The hunter climbed the mountain and found her bones in the cave as described. He did what she had asked in the apparition. After her remains were carried around the city three times, the plague ceased. After this Saint Rosalia was venerated as the patron saint of Palermo, and a sanctuary was built in the cave where her remains were discovered.Her post-1624 iconography is dominated by the work of the Flemish painter Anthony van Dyck, who was trapped in the city during the 1624-1625 quarantine, during which time he produced five paintings of the saint, now in Madrid, Houston, London, New York and Palermo itself. In 1629 he also produced Saint Rosalia Interceding for the City of Palermo and Coronation of Saint Rosalia to assist Jesuit efforts to spread her cult beyond Sicily.


== Veneration ==

The feast of Saint Rosalia is on September 4.The celebration, called the festino, is still held each year on July 14, and continues into the next day. It is still a major social and religious event in Palermo. In 1995, 1996, 1997 and 2001 the celebration was produced by Studio Festi.Also on September 4 there is an event related to the festino and St. Rosalia; a tradition of walking barefoot from Palermo up to Mount Pellegrino. In Italian American communities in the United States, the July feast is generally dedicated to Our Lady of Mount Carmel while the September feast, beginning in August, brings large numbers of visitors annually to the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn in New York City.


== In biology ==
Saint Rosalia was proposed as the patron saint of evolutionary studies in a paper by G.E. Hutchinson. This was due to a visit he paid to a pool of water downstream from the cave where St. Rosalia's remains were found, where he developed ideas based on observations of water boatman.


== In Art ==
Saint Rosalia was an important subject in Italian Renaissance and Baroque painting, particularly in sacre conversazioni (group pictures of saints flanking the Virgin Mary) by artists such as Riccardo Quartararo, Mario di Laurito, Vincenzo La Barbara, and possibly Antonello da Messina. But it was Flemish master Anthony Van Dyck (1599-1637), who was caught in Palermo during the 1624 plague, who produced the most paintings of her (see also above). His depictions of a young woman with flowing blonde hair wearing a Franciscan cowl and reaching down toward the city of Palermo in its peril, became the standard iconography of the saint from that time onward. Van Dyck's series of St Rosalia paintings have been studied by Gauvin Alexander Bailey and Xavier F. Salomon, both of whom curated or co-curated exhibitions devoted to the theme of Italian art and the plague. Recently the New York Times published an article about the Metropolitan Museum of Art's painting of Saint Rosalia by Van Dyck in the context of the Covid-19 virus..


== See also ==

List of Catholic saints


== References ==


== External links ==
 Herbermann, Charles, ed. (1913). "St. Rosalia". Catholic Encyclopedia. New York: Robert Appleton Company.

sights.name: Church of Saint Catherine of Alexandria

text.wiki:
The Church of Saint Catherine (Italian: Chiesa di Santa Caterina or simply Santa Caterina) is a church in Palermo, Sicily, southern Italy. It is located in the heart of the historic centre, between Piazza Bellini and Piazza Pretoria, in the same area of other well-known architectural landmarks like the churches of Martorana and San Cataldo (both of them are World Heritage Sites), the Fontana Pretoria and the Palazzo Pretorio, headquarters of the Palermo municipality. The church is a synthesis of Sicilian Baroque, Rococo and Renaissance styles.


== History ==
In 1310 the last will of the rich Benvenuta Mastrangelo determined the foundation of a female monastery under the direction of the Dominican Order. The new monastery was dedicated to Saint Catherine of Alexandria and was erected in the area  where the old palace of George of Antioch, admiral of Roger II of Sicily, stood.In 1532 the widening of the building was decided. Between 1566 and 1596 the church was rebuilt under the supervision of the Mother Prioress Maria del Carretto. For a long time the architectural project was attributed to Giorgio di Faccio, architect of another church of Palermo, San Giorgio dei Genovesi. However, more recent studies show the involvement of architects like the Florentine Francesco Camilliani and the Lombard Antonio Muttone, already engaged in the project of Piazza Pretoria. The dome was designed by Francesco Ferrigno. The church was inaugurated on 24 November 1596. Many years later, on 16 March 1664, the church was consecrated by the archbishop of Palermo Pietro Martinez y Rubio in the presence of the Viceroy of Sicily Francesco Caetani, 8th Duke of Sermoneta.During the 19th century the church was damaged on several occasions: during the uprising of 1820-1821, the Sicilian revolution of 1848, the Gancia revolt, the insurrection of Palermo (1860) and the Sette e mezzo revolt (1866).


== Art ==


=== Paintings ===
Oil on canvas:

Deposition of Christ, school of Jusepe de Ribera
Jesus under the Cross, unknown author
Last Supper, unknown author
The Adulteress, unknown author
Washing of the Feet, unknown author
Our Lady of Mount Carmel, unknown author
Transfiguration, unknown author
The Virgin intercedes for the souls in Purgatory, unknown author
Immaculate, unknown author
Adoration, unknown author
Birth of the Virgin, unknown author
Pious V blesses Andrea Doria, unknown author
Albigensian massacre, unknown author
Stake of the forbidden books, unknown author
Our Lady of the Rosary, unknown authorFrescoes:

Triumph of Saint Catherine, Filippo Randazzo
Glory of the Dominican Sisters, Filippo Randazzo
Triumph of the Dominican Order, Vito D'Anna
Allegories of the four continents, Vito D'Anna
The Soul in glory rises to Heaven, Antonio Filocamo and Paolo Filocamo
Exaltation of the Eucharist, Antonio Filocamo and Paolo FilocamoThe church houses other precious artworks (statues, altars and frescoes) designed or made by artists like Giacomo Amato, Giovanni Battista Ragusa, Andrea Palma, Antonello Gagini, Francesco Sozzi, Alessandro D'Anna and Ignazio Marabitti.

text.wiki:
The Foro Italico is a lawn along the seafront of Palermo, Sicily, Italy.
In 1582 Vice-King Marco Antonio Colonna created a walking path in this part of the coast, that became a favorite destination for the leisure of the upper classes of the city in the 17th and 18th centuries.It is entirely pedestrian, is approximately 40,000 m2 in size, with Mediterranean flora of various kinds, benches, trees, ceramic sculptures, a bike path, night lighting and a wide scenic walk along the coast. It was redeveloped in 2003, when, the lawn, the pedestrian paths, the public lighting and an irrigation system were improved. The project was carried out by the technicians of the municipality of Palermo.


== References ==


== Bibliography ==
G. Venturini, Sicilia, Touring Club Italiano, Milano 2002, p. 59.

text.wiki:
Piazza Marina is a square of Palermo. It is located down the Cassaro street, in the quarter of the Kalsa, within the historic centre of Palermo. The square is dominated by the great Garibaldi Garden.


== History ==

In the Middle Ages the area of Piazza Marina was a swamp connected to the ancient port of Palermo, the Cala. During the 14th century the area was cleared. In the Spaniard period, the space of the square was used by the Inquisition (whose headquarters was the adjacent Palazzo Chiaramonte) for its convictions.
In 1863, Giovan Battista Filippo Basile designed the Garibaldi Garden, named after national hero Giuseppe Garibaldi, at the centre of Piazza Marina. This garden is famous because the biggest Ficus macrophylla of Europe is situated in it. In the zone of Piazza Marina are also located several buildings like Palazzo Chiaramonte, Palazzo Galletti di San Cataldo, Palazzo Fatta, Palazzo Notarbartolo di Villarosa Dagnino, Palazzo delle Finanze, the Hotel de France, the Teatro Libero, the churches of Santa Maria dei Miracoli, San Giovanni dei Napoletani and Santa Maria della Catena and the Fontana del Garraffo.
On March 12, 1909, the New York police officer Joe Petrosino was killed in Piazza Marina during a top secret mission against the Mafia. Later a small memorial (an engraved brass plate on a pole) was erected on the square in his remembrance.


== See also ==
Giardino Garibaldi
Fontana del Garraffo
Palazzo Chiaramonte

text.wiki:
The Church of the Gesù (chiesa del Gesù), Church of Saint Mary of Gesu (chiesa di Santa Maria di Gesù) or Casa Professa is one of the most important Baroque churches in the Italian city of Palermo and in all of Sicily.


== History ==

The Jesuits arrived in Palermo in 1549, and by the late 16th century began building a church adjacent to their mother house (Casa Professa) using a design by the Jesuit architect Giovanni Tristano. The original design called for a single nave with large transepts and several side chapels, but it was changed by the early 17th century, to a more grandiose layout typical of Jesuit architecture. Natale Masuccio removed the chapels' dividing walls to add two side naves to the central one. The church was consecrated in 1636.
The interior decoration included marble bas-reliefs on the tribuna depicting the Adoration of the Shepherds (1710–14) and Adoration of the Magi (1719–21), by Gioacchino Vitagliano, after designs attributed to Giacomo Serpotta - both reliefs survive. A fresco of the Adoration of the Magi was also added to the walls of the second side-chapel to the right by Antonino Grano in the 1720s. The church also contains a relief of the Glory of St Luke by Ignazio Marabitti.
In 1892, cavaliere Salvatore Di Pietro, former rector of the Casa Professa, philanthropist, prefect of studies at the seminary, and member of the Theological College, of the Academy of sciences, letters and arts and of the Accademia di storia patria, convinced in 1888 the minister of public education, Paolo Boselli, to decree the church a national monument.
In 1943, during the Second World War, a bomb collapsed the church's dome, destroying most of the surrounding walls and most of the wall paintings in the chancel and transepts. These frescoes were replaced during two years' restoration work, after which the church reopened on 24 February 2009 with a solemn mass presided over by Paolo Romeo, archbishop of Palermo, and attended by several Jesuits and civil and military officials.


== Architecture ==
The facade is divided into two sections by a cornice. In the lower part there are three portals, above are niches with statues of St Ignatius of Loyola, a Madonna with Child and Francis Xavier. The upper section is divided by pilasters and framed on both sides with corbels and statues of saints. The facade is surmounted by a curved-segmented gable and the Jesuit emblem. Masucci originally planned belfries, but these were not completed, and the current 18th-century campanile was built on the adjacent Palazzo Marchesi. Behind the church, the Jesuit chapter houses the town library.
The layout is in the shape of a Latin cross. The nave is 72.10 m long, 42.65 m wide and 70 m high and is decorated with polychrome marbles, stucco and frescoes. In particular, the marble reliefs with their figural and ornamental motifs on the pillars and the marble mosaics are unique. The rebuilt structure has a double dome and stained glass windows.


== Decorations (selected) ==
Decorations by:

Pietro Novelli
Vito D'Anna (fresco depicting scenes from the life of Saint Rosalia)


== Gallery ==

		
		
		
		
		
		
		
		


== Bibliography ==

(in Italian) D. Garstang, Giacomo Serpotta and the Stuccatori of Palermo, 1560-1790, A.Zwemmer Ltd. London 1984.
(in Italian) S. Barcellona, Gli scultori del Cassaro, Ingrana, Palermo 1971, riedito in Scritti d’arte: studi e interventi sulla cultura artistica in Sicilia, edited by G. Bongiovanni, Brotto, Palermo 1992.
(in Italian) S. Piazza, I marmi mischi delle chiese di Palermo, Sellerio, Palermo 1992, (in part. pp. 37–44).
(in Italian) Maria Carla Ruggieri Tricoli, Costruire Gerusalemme. Il complesso gesuitico della Casa Professa di Palermo dalla storia al museo, Ed. Lybra, Milano 2001.
(in Italian) Luca Mansueto, I pilastri absidali della Chiesa del Gesù di Casa Professa in Palermo, in Karta, anno I (2006), num.4, pp. 10–11.

Do not let the bland exterior for you. The interior of this magnificent church is astonishing and more so knowing that was heavily damaged during the war and rebuilt.
You see so many beautiful baroque palaces and churches, but this one really stands out, quite amazing and a must see.

Although the more recent ceiling frescoes are not up to the standard of what remained after 1943 bombing, the marble and stucco decorations of the entire inner fabric are simply incredible. A building of remarkable unity of form and no holds barred imagination.

Don't be fooled with a simple and usual outside Baroque facade. Inside, this Church is astonishing, so please enter, you wont regret it. I think the interior is in the top 10 worldwide I've seen. So much decorations, marble and stucco work is a feast for the eyes, words cannot

Loved this church. A very distinctive style of baroque you can only find in Sicily when ruled by Spain. Great flashes of grotesque masks and colored inlaid marble-some of the best examples in the world. Just south of the Barallto market.

Luscious, luxurious, whatever the label you want to add, this is a baroque masterpiece. We visited when a wedding was taking place, and were able to witness the people's fervor and devotion to the church rites, incredibly, the church was empty and clean in just a few minutes so
The most beautiful church of palermo, though on the inside. This church has the nicest decorations inside i have ever seen. Every wall has paintings, statues, ornaments etc. a must see

Intricate, beautiful rare gem of a church so densely adorned with marble it's hard to believe. Great paintings as well. Fantastic bas relief marble sculptures that tell us stories and offer the sculptor's lens into bible legends. Just beautiful.

The pictures posted here do not do justice to the intricate and colourful work that occupies every recess of the church. You could easily spend over an hour tracing the vines and peacocks that lead to roses and putti in relief. My neck was sore by the end of it!

We had visited many beautiful Baroque churches in Palermo and elsewhere but this was one of the most beautiful. It is relatively small and not on the main tourist site lists. Do not miss going here. It is magical.

This is a cute little church hidden in a local neighborhood close to the Quattro canti. You have to pay 5 euros to get in, but it's worth it. A great example of Baroque art, this church is a great destination for everyone visiting Palermo. The decorations inside are amazing.

I spent two hours in this stunning example of Baroque art. There wasn't an empty Place on the walls but instead they were covered with mosaics and inlay Stone work. After one week of church going in Palermo this one was my favorite Place to feed a need for beauty.

Magnificent baroque decoration, exquisite work in marble throughout, and ceiling done in a marvellous modern painting commissioned after the original roof of the church was wrecked in WW2 bombing. Awe-inspiring!
Sicilian Baroque style with every square inch covered by relief sculptures and fabulous patterns. Even if you feel you've seen more than your share of churches in Italy, don't miss this one.
This is well worth a visit, and was free to get in. So much beautiful architecture in Palermo, but inside this church is far more impressive than the inside of the Cathedral!
This is a Baroque church with amazingly detailed decoration. Make sure you don't miss the unusual ceiling paintings!
Not a spectacular church but the illuminated name of god in Hebrew letters Adonai, Yud Hay vav Hay is displayed high above the alter.
Looked at many churches during our visit to Palermo but this one takes some beating. Entrance fee included a museum and crypt, which were both interesting.

The most beautiful place. A 'must see' when visiting Palermo. Tricky to find but completely worth it! So many fantastic places to visit, I would advise making an itinerary for sightseeing in advance...be sure not to miss this one!

The interior of the church is absolutely breathtaking, you have to take your time,read about the Jesuits and savour slowly the exquisite carvings and marble panels that cover most of the walls, the workmanship of the carvers comes as a direct line from the antique Roman art, it

The incredible baroque church took us completely by surprise. Well worth a visit. Its also in a very historic part of Palermo so there are lots of other things to see. Our surprise fave was City Hall where we got a private tour by one of the security guards.

This was not down as one of the main attractions of Palermo and is down some side streets, but the interior was very impressive baroque and on it is on a grand scale. There's a small fee to visit (and a museum which we did not have time to see)

Of all the churches we visited this one was the most remarkable. The interior is simply the most outrageous riot of Baroque that you are likely to see anywhere. You may love it or hate it but it really is unforgettable. It is also one of a route of 4 churches in the Kalsa

This church has a very ornate interior. Lots of inlay stone work and stucco sculptures . This is a Baroque style of church and was a Jesuit church. This style is very different from most churches in Italy so if you have not yet seen a Baroque church this is a great one to see.

The artwork on the walls is pretty amazing. And then you view it up close and realize it's all intricately fitted hand-cut marble! The marble work in this church is truly amazing, from the floors, to the walls, and the ceiling. Too bad they don't allow pictures.
Worth visiting on a walking tour of central Palermo, this ornate baroque church has a simple exterior and a beautiful ornate interior with attractive ceiling painting.

Interesting church amidst interesting neighbourhood. Spent some time in there gazing at the ceilings. Go there and see why.

Beauty and history are the two are here represented in a church that express the might of the catholic religon in the past centuries. Every touristi should see it

this is a beautiful church hidden amongst a very ugly surrounding. the surrounding buildings are desolate and the area looks like a ghetto but once inside the church the beauty of the interior is breath taking.

I agree with recent reviews, this church has a plain facade but the interior is breathtaking in its decoration. There is an entry fee, but well worth it. One of the attendants also offered information without being pushy.
A riot of colour in this Jesuit church, in elaborate Baroque marble inlay - walls - columns - floors. The facade was used for the film "The Godfather".

Of all of the churchs in Sicily, this has the most over the top interior design. The Jesuits really went for it in terms of church decoration. The Jesuit 'Men in Black' feature in a heroic role in many of the decorations. It is in a rough area, so take care with valuable

This was my No. 1 place to visit in Palermo. It is quite breathtaking, with every square inch covered in amazing carvings, inlaid stone work or frescos. The workmanship is wonderful and the overall impression is almost too much to believe. We nearly did not go in as the
This was not at the top of the list of churches, but in our opinion, it was more impressive than the Martorana. Definitely worth seeing, and there are a lot of great restaurants nearby.

When you walk up the stairs, and are still looking to a normal church's entry.. you go inside.. and it's not Palermo! It's something else. It's just perfect! Men's most astonishing marble perfect work.. Not as Sheikh Zayed Mosque.... but just beautifull! You could stay there for
Beautiful interior with all the marble. Neighbourhood a bit rough. One of my favourite churches in Palermo.

From the marble bas-reliefs ,to the ceiling paintings and the stained glass there is a festival of beauty . The work in the stones that almost seemed paintings are really amazing !!!! Something unforgettable !!

A church and a museum. Very well preserved and admirably atmospheric. The visit costs 5 euros and you get to ghe see the small museum and the crypt (which is nothing special). A great place to see in Palermo.
Plain exterior hides an interior that is more than the eye can take in. Baroque stucco to the extreme, with added marble inlays and flooring. Truly excellent craftsmanship and well worth a visit.

A plain exterior but once inside this is a magnificent church. It is possible to look inside for free but to get full access to the fabulous decorations, art works, wood carvings, marble etc. etc. it is worth paying the entrance fee and be guided around. Be aware the church

Magnificent church from the inside! Amazing decoration in barock style! This church is jesuits', as I understood. Free of charge. Definitively recommended!

A highly decorated baroque church. It screams over decoration on every level and it shouldn't appeal to our streamlined simple tastes, but it works and is a huge surprise after the plan exterior.
This is a splendid example of Baroque building. The artistic part is undoubtedly predominant inside, decorated with the same baroque style, for lovers of this genre is undoubtedly a must-visit place.
Every surface was either sculpted white marble, mosaics and we received a tour of the sacristy (beautiful carved wood) and art museum. Absolutely gorgeous. We loved it.

Do not miss this church ! First rate baroque architecture and amazing marble decorations. There is a small charge but the passionate and knowledgeable guides are included in the entry price. Leave at least an hour for the entire visit.
The sculptures, paintings and marble were too ostentatious for my taste in church architecture. However looked at separately, they were splendid and the view down the nave was superb.
Do not even dare to miss this Church. The Interiors heavily decorated with the marble carvings will deeply touch you with the extraordinary craftsmanship

a rich church where you can admire the beautiful mosaics , I was lucky enough to see an Orthodox rite

wow. What a beautiful church. The level of detail in the interior decoration is simply stunning. Do not miss this one. It does not look like much from the outside but the inside is spectacular. One of the mostly richly decorated churches I have ever been in.
The church is incredible and once it is fully restored, it will be even more magnificent. Well worth the visit.
One of my favourite churches in Palermo, located in Piazza Casa Professa. If you're only here for a short stay, put this on your list.

This church is beautiful. Every inch is decorated with intricate motifs and statues. Apparently the church was bombed during WW II but rebuilt/reopened in 2009. I can only imagine the time and effort that was spent. Highly recommend a visit if you have time.

This church is absolutely gorgeous. Every inch is richly decorated. It was a visually overwhelming experience. Out of the 14 churches we visited in Palermo this one stood out for me. It is indeed a gift to humanity that the Allied bombing of Palermo did not destroy this church.

We stopped in to view the interior of the church and were surprised to see how beautiful it was inside relative to the simple outside. Every inch of the interior is covered with something. The ceiling, walls and alter are magnificent. It is worth a visit to view the Baroque

Overwhelming. Ornate - a work of art. You could visit 100 times and discover something new each time.

The church is so beautifully decorated inside you will be amazed. Their were cherubs everywhere and as others have said every square inch of the walls are covered with something. Be prepared to be overwhelmed. Gorgeous. You can view on your own without paying a fee.
This is probably the most important baroque church in Sicily, and there are many, in fact it's importance could stretch far wider than that. It is a complete over-the-top masterpiece. A must see.

The church was closed and so we were not able to visit interior. But there us easy access to this church and would normally be open. The facade is more austere than others which U.S. interesting given the rich architectural history if the city.

The exterior is unimpressive, but the interior is excellent. This is the oldest Jusuit church in Sicily. The marble work on the pillars and altars is exquisite. A must see if you are in Palermo.

This church doesn't look like much on the outside but inside every inch is decorated with animals, birds and cherubs from the biblical creation stories. Not well lighted but interesting if you are in the neighborhood.
The art work and restoration were excellent. Damaged during the war it was restored in a beautiful fashion. A must see in Palermo

Though plain on the outside this church is amazing on the inside. One may say it is a bit ostentatious. I am not really in to visiting churches, but this one is definitely worth visiting, even though it is a little (and I stress a little) bit off the beaten track.

This is by far one of the best, if not the best church I saw in Palermo. The location is a little off the church parade on Vittoria Emmanuel but it is worth the excursion. I find church artistry can sometimes blend and blur but there is an arresting magnificence to del gesu

Incredible church like nothing I've seen before. One wonders what got into them. A bit off the tourist trail but if churches are your thing you have to go there.
Just an ordinanry church on the outside... Just walk in and discover an amazing and truely unique church. Quite splendid, and beautiful.

When we went to see this church we expected it to be quite plain inside -- we'll we got that wrong. It is unbelieveably amazing with the marble work and the statues everywhere. It is very beautiful and definitely worth a visit.

a stunning interior to a huge church which is accessed from a not so great street, was a real surprise to look in!
